Notebook 18, Page Image 6; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 2v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_006.jpg

[K.B.]

“I said, I will water my best garden,

& will water abundantly my

garden-bed: & lo, my brook became

a river, dry river became a sea.”

Ecclesiasticus XXIV. 31

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 7; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 3r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_007.jpg

[K.B.]

“Let not him that seeketh cease from his

search until he find, & when he finds he

shall wonder; wondering he shall reach

the Kingdom, and when he reaches the

Kingdom he shall have rest.”

“All Heart they live, all Head, all Eye, all Ears,

All Intellect, all Sense, & as they please,

they Limb themselves.”

Milton’s Paradise Lost bk (in reprint] VI

lls 350

“Che necessario è navigare,

Vivere non è necessario”

Gabrielle d’Annunzio

Notebook 18, Page Image 9; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 4r; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_009.jpg

[K.B.]

1904

New Year’s Day.

I look forth at midnight to grimmest

fog, fog that is as a garment to the

bitter wind.

A moon in the heavens, bells & cannon

on the air. Then a human cheer

across the waters 1904 is with us –

for our fashioning

More and more I feel this, we are

weavers of the stuff of time

Henry2 says there was lack of

spirituality in us last year. I

remind him the Holy Ghost has his

seasons, winter & spring & summer.

We have been with God, creating.

We need clemency & breadth –

acknowledgement of no boundary.

Strange! - Henry, not having read

this, saw far-open horizons.

He smelt pine & carnation; that is

what is comfortable in the

descent from the opened heavens.

It is terrible to begin with raw time

again, just when one was at

work on a nice bit of mellow stuff.

I feel that my business this year will

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 10; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 4v; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_010.jpg

[K.B.]

be loving - I have scarcely touched the

power of loving within me. I mean

that plastic loving that is influence.

Little Amy 3 writes that her motto for

this year is – “Let us beware lest we

act as he did in the fable, who stood

watch in the lighthouse, & gave to the

poor in the cabins about him the oil

of the night’s lanterns that served

to illumine the sea. Every soul in

its sphere has charge of a lighthouse

for which there is more or less need”

Failures & sins of 1903

No influence from art, none from

literature, except the re-reading of

Rénan & the power from Aristophanes

Glimpses from Nature we had,

Heaven bless her!

I will try to read a little this year –

one or two big-lettered books.

But there will be little leisure –

accomplishing, reaping, singing; but

only as we bind the grain – this is

revealed our destiny.

There is an Imagination to feed

dearer than my own, & a soul to

cherish in her cell.

I want to write of Diana of Poictiers4,

& of the French Renaissance.

I want my Beloved to write Caesar’s

tower all by herself.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 11; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 5r; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_011.jpg

[E.C.]

We are in our fresh, spring-like

Room again – & an old Persian

Rug lies on the hearth – It is

quite a creature to lie on the

hearth, is a Persian Rug.

I have set our affairs in order,

while the Eastern frost has

been dissolving into southern

fog. My Love has brought me

tender anemones, & three

lily-buds as green & crisp as

New Year itself.

[K.B.]

January 5th

My Chow5 is ill with gastritis – I suffer

with him. Francis6 is here, so we are

with the Past.

Ernest7 writes to ask us if we will

suffer ourselves to be “re-maindered”

they are removing to premises.

I write to him.

“It makes one’s skin very hot to think

of being “remaindered”. It is one of

those uncomfortable processes,

like what goes on in the grave.

But we in our free spirits are

apart from both these processes,

– so what matter!

So “remainder” freely.

“Tommy”8 who left us without good-bye

& sent us no cake[?] – writes to

excuse himself. He has been

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 12; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 5v; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_012.jpg

[K.B.]

lost in the ceremonial of marriage, &

then his mother’s death came on him –

I reply

– Of course we rolled you over the

abyss as a lost friend on New Year’s

Eve. And therefrom[?] you have to toil,

with Marie to help up too! I shouldn’t

wonder, if she helped you up: we shall

see …

We in England have been spending the

time like Masters. Doubtless you will

see the artists’ new pictures, & Ricketts’s

great deposition ....

January 6th

Epiphany – the gracious Star Feast.

– the intellectual recognition of Christ

Wise & with Wisdom wise these

that recognise him, & knew it is

worth while travelling far to

worship him.

Little Francis John before his bubbly[?]

bowl of milk. “Mother, is this

bubble a kiss from Auntie Ethel,

or from God.”

the Mother, I fear, did not

answer “Straight from God.”

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 13; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 6r;Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_013.jpg

[K.B.]

It is on this blessed feast of the

Epiphany a new play is given to

Henry – a play of Redemption –

Henry must write

But I am with the Savage, blood-

-dripping old grandfather Herod,9 with

his lust for love. He must have

love – Mariamne’s10 love – his children’s

love. He has a burning lust for

love – the love of his wife, his offspring

– his people. He has not the instincts[?]

of his ambition – none. He would like

even to be loved of God, & in profanity he

dedicates the temple. He murders

love wherever it might spring up.

He is a man who seeks tears as

other men seek gold. He would

leave lamentation behind[?], &

regret as a heritage. He would

transfer emotion – the great office

of art – but he is not an artist.

He works in a medium of which

he has not the secret.

Mariamne is to him beauty & desire –

her refusal to love him transcends in

wonder – And that his children

should not love him & that the worms

alone should love him & cleave to

him!

He is not despicable. He has sought

for the best thing life can give.

He seeks to attract & to possess, not

as a God.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 14; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 6v;Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_014.jpg

[K.B.]

I saw in the night a scene with

his children. the body of Mariamne

in a sarcophagus in a dim corner

of the room. His Sons still children

have stolen in.

- they approach, but cannot look in.

Do not let us talk of it.

No: we shall remember better if we

do not speak.

It is something they must learn

in silence. But is it our Mother? –

O Aristobulus11 – I do not care. I shall

be a great soldier – let us play now

at taking – Vienna[?].

(they sit down & play at taking

a city)

Herod enters: he stands for a long time

by the coffin.

To-day I hate thee.

To-day I will arouse thy sullenness.

that hate in the metres of a woman’s face –

that frenzies – No:

No, Mariamne – deal more patiently,

as I shall weary of this solemn face –

And beauty that is absent as the sky.

Well, children at your play –

(they rise & leave the toys on the

ground. Well, children, children!

Come back! …

Why were you playing in this room.

Who gave you leave – What scares you -

(the children stand trembling

violently before him)

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 15; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 7r;Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_015.jpg

[K.B.]

Herod convulsively clutches them, & holds

them down one on each side.

– You love her

You shall always love her.

Listen, you know she is a goddess now

Your Mother – She –

But we must be afraid of her, she is not

Close by you on the earth, as I am close –

She cannot understand. But you – my children.

I love you in your play – I would not break it –

This⟨a⟩ city you besiege it.

One of the boys nods: with trembling

hands Herod sets up some of the pieces.

I will play with you. No – do not watch

me. I will play with you. You must

talk, & teach me how to play.

(He sobs as the children remain

stubborn)

What would you like to do? You are dull

Should you like me to tell you a story?

(They shake their heads]

Not a story – not of – he gives lists of the

Great moments of his life.

You will become great as I am

great. I can teach you that

Will you not listen? When I was in

Rome –

Aristobulus

Father, we wll. go to Rome –

Lead us away to Rome. (they spring away, frightened

Herod – at themselves.]

To Rome – he remains staring[?], at the thought –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page 16; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 7v;Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_016.jpg

[K.B.]

the younger one turns back, &

kisses his hand.

– May we go father, may we go – We

shall come back.

Friday January 8th – the Palace12

Painter13 is sitting over the fire –

a little bilious. We close into deep

talk, & cannot go on to the Manor –

From 3 to 5.35 we converse.

Painter, believing it is the last

night of the old year, starts for

the theatre on January 30th.

Deep horror freezes his vitals as

he recollects he has not ⟨re-⟩lit the

stoves; & that he will return to

a palace of dead ashes!!!

He prophecies a year of transition –

inevitable transition

“Herod, I have brought you his

history. Consider whether Cleopatra

may come in – not of course Shakespeare’s

Cleopatra – the sweetly[?] disastrous

little wretch of reality.”

John Gray14 has sent another little

blue book. He has called at the Palace.

Ricketts was out, & Shannon15 “denied

himself”.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page 17; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 8r;Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_017.jpg

[K.B.]

Designs of the gigantic Sabbatai ring are

shown. There will be many windows –

“Will there be any doors” – & this childish

talk between consideration of Cleopatra –

– reaches into art & drama.

The Painter is formed Architect &

Sculptor. vide[?] – his ground-plan of the

ring.

“I am right – he never forgives. A

plant that has been cut, may

shoot out in other directions – not

where its life is destroyed”.

He has done a most exquisite thing –

laid the softest coloured shells in

a bowl of dried rose-leaves.

1st Sunday after Epiphany.

Anyone can see that the rose in the

sky is of the spring – the gale brings

Herod, & the first stage direction to Henry –

– he forms in the round; he is no longer

a fresco.

I write

Shells musical as Eolus had stirred,

Shells moulded finely as the waters mould,

In bloom of ivory breathing through her gold,

Or white of foamy curd

I gave; & found preferred

to a great bowl of rose-leaves where they lie

In open burial crystal to the sky.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 18; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 8v; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_018.jpg

[K.B.]

II

A shell! – It is a lovely testament,

A bequeathed relic, & a treasure wove

Breath upon breath; it holds each element

As in an urn; shall it not speak of love?

Heralds there are of Love, the dusky flock

Of sparrows, or the doves in snowy brood

that steer her chariot through the tempest’s shock,

Or bees, a honey-heaving multitude:

Heralds there are & tokens of our state,

And there are symbols set among the stars

Of Man, his destiny, his chainèd Fate,

the way that opens & the way that bars:

And in between passing from hand to hand,

there is the jewel and the signet-rose,

– Censor, or brand of warm & piny[?] smell;

I, in my mysteries pluck none of those;

But trust for all my spirit would command

the silence & the perfume of a shell.

Sunday – January 10th.

[E.C.]

Delicious American remark on

''Let this be a lesson.'' - ''Nothing

is a lesson, for you always break

out in a new place.''

(16A punctilious old man of Dundee

Who taught little owls to drink tea,

For he said to eat mice

Is not proper nor nice –

That punctilious old man of Dundee.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 19; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 9r; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_019.jpg

[E.C.]

Jan. 12

I approach my birthday (Tues.) with

toothache that for an hour or so

every evening is like Othello’s

sword of ‘ice-brook temper’. The

pain comes out a little distance

into the air, & is a power that

resists touch.

The day before I write the first

scene (end) of Herod. We over-

-work it on my birthday morning.

Amy comes from the old Manor,

charmed with the new matting

& the white rooms in their

bounty of flowers. Re-ceived[?]

lilies, many-budded roses,

a pouting[?] garland for the

white bowl of anemones & their

curls of leafage – young lilas[?] –

all these are from my Love. Amy

brings bubbles of milky ⟨vale-⟩lilies,

& tulips in rathe scarlet. And

the light from the river falls

on the delicate creatures rec[?]

receptively.

My gift from Michael is Placidia

– the satinwood chest that

enwombs Works & Days. Her noble

extra Detmold’s Macchiavelli comes

not. Amy sweetly & unwillingly[?]

gives a cheque toward an old

Eastern rug.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 20; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 9v; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_020.jpg

[E.C.]

Thurs⟨Wednes ⟩day. Jan. 14 th

Michael is in Sloane St.

at 4 – the bee-hit!

I am conscious with pain –

strained in looks – I see he

hesitates to stay. But I

re-assure him that the

actual pain is at night.

I am much vexed he has

hurried to return the vol. of

Graetz17 just on the day Michael

had not offered for a visit –

He explains Thursday & Friday

are engaged – so he trotted

over the first possible day

& never thought of absence

as possible.

He is sombre, unreflexing as

Mist, & makes a dead-set against

Herod,18 whom he conceives as

simply a figure of Eastern

yearning – the desire that

has no ideality. When Caesar

dreams ambitiously it is

to found a world – an order,

a new order. There is ideality,

which is creativeness in him –

in Alexander. But the ambition

of the East is a hunger. It

is like the yearning of the North

for the South – it wants the

limitless stupidly. Only round[?]

the Mediterranean is ambition.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 21; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 10r; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_021.jpg

[E.C.]

a mode of creation. Fay 19 can-be20

interested in nothing that has not

been ‘Mediterranianised’

He is not even caught by the

Arab strain in Herod. The Arabs

are only thin Jews – they merely

lack the fatness of soil of Judæa

The Jews have only given ⟨The world⟩ a

moral code admirable for

barbarians & the lower classes –

the Arabs have added to

Manners on their ⟨a⟩ more superficial

side. They have a calm, a grandeur –

something nobly caressing in

their ways.

The Jews are effective, & therefore

an Artist must admire them;

but they have been a curse

on civilisation blighting it

two fold – by the family & by

their moral code.

In Greece men were reared to be

citizens – the family was but

the means. Life meant the

spiritual conflict of the males.

Wherever Jewish influence has

been preponderant – civilised

life declines – as when the Puritans

ruined the civilisation of England

till a Latin influence ( that[?] of

France) partially restored it.

Morality is a matter of pure

convenience – what is best to do to

get the best results (as gardening

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 22; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 10v; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_022.jpg

[E.C.]

is the art of getting the best

flowers) – this the Greek took

for granted; but the Jew

came & made morality

absolute – a Code not an

Art, & this is the Semitic

Curse.

Christ was not by mind a

Jew. His delicate scepticism

was utterly different from

anything found among the

Jews – his ways of behaviour

were opposed to Jewish

morality. The influence

of Christianity has been

Pauline & therefore Jewish

It is only as it were aside &

mostly in free-thinking times

that the direct influence of

Jesus can be traced.

Yet when all is said against the Jews

Fay finds them almost the only

people to talk to in England –

They have two virtues – they are

always foreigners & they have

a tradition behind them. One

always knows what to deal

with – there are order & cleanness

in them … not that incalculable

confused element found in

semi-barbarous people like the

English, who have no permanent

tradition as a nation – only in certain

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 23; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 11r; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_023.jpg

[E.C.]

families & castes.

Fay does not find wishes to rub in

the unessentialness of the Jews

– he thinks it is necessary for us,

considering Michael’s old-fashioned

education in the Psalms – “O God,

give me a good dinner” – “O God,

give me health.” &c

He does not find the Knudos[?] in Herod.

He is full of the Tragedy of the

Bloody Mary 21 (he has dropped

Queen Elizabeth).

She should be treated as the

Virgin Mary in history – she who

felt that the deliverance of England

was from her & of her child.

Only by her means could God’s

Kingdom be established & a

light shine on her people. She

dreams the child – she takes

as husband the perfection ⟨paragon⟩ of

Catholic tradition – The King of

Spain that the child may be

born – then the seven swords

enter her heart. As she decreases

the gay princess Elizabeth, the

symbol of all the irreligion

Mary would stifle, increase, &

throws[?] gleams over the doom[?]

that measure its profundity. As

women, Fay thinks, we should be able

to treat the frustrate religion & maternity

of the woman.

See 1722

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 24; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 11v; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_024.jpg

[K.B.]

January 19 th.

Tuesday evening.

The long month so fat with

business & pettiness – mere wash

of refuse to the billows of Herod

– rolls along.

We are firm in Herod now

– the dead eyes are kindling[?] – Cypros 23,

Salome24, Mariamne25 – Herod.

I have seen Herod with his arm

round Aristobulus26, caressing

him.

Lady Anne Blunt’s 27 “Poets of the

Iignorance” comes to us a sheaf from

Arabian store-houses.

We feel the white teeth of the camomile28 –

–we love, & grow weary of love,

& ride to war, & boast, & grow

weary with age.

This Arabian poetry, with Josephus29,

will, I think, stand “back of Herod”,

as Renan and Aristophanes30 stood back

of “A Messiah.”

We are living divinely great days.

Henry is in a cloud.

I increase in vision – vision too of all

that leaps in the heart.

Imaginative speech is however growing

difficult to me.

A beautiful directoire gown is completed.

It is paid for &, perfect: in that direction – peace.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 25; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 12r; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_025.jpg

[E.C.]

On Friday

I continue Fay’s visit –

He came up, fussed as to wh: room

we should sit in – was commanded

into the sitti Sun-Room, & then he told

how Rodin31 heard that Shannon32

admired the torso of his St. John

Baptist (as a study) shown at the

International & offered it through

a third person in exchange for

a picture by Shannon.

It was as if Francis Joseph the

oldest Royal Person in Europe,

of the oldest race, had offered

an ⟨order⟩old (“The Golden Fleece”?)

to Shannon. It was like the

Renaissance. Rodin is the

oldest monarch of art among

the most artistic people of Europe.

The Shannon pictures are the

artistic triumph of the exhibition –

The Deuil Marin of Cottet33 is the

social triumph & the Spaniard

Zulodga34 the popular triumph.

Fay catches sight of The Century35

with pictures of Mrs Gardener’s36

Palace of Art & some of its treasures.

He sends congratulations to Bernard37

that he bought the Holbein [⟨Dürer⟩] & knew

it as Holbein ⟨Dürer⟩. If the face had been

unstippled it wd have been the 3rd or

4th in importance – even as it is it is

about 7th. Fay has always called the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 26; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 12v; Wendy Walter and Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_026.jpg

[E.C.]

picture his Holbein⟨Dürer⟩ – because when

shown at the Old Masters no

one had the penetration or courage

to support him in his certainty

it was a Holbein⟨Dürer⟩.

Tho’ announced, the book on

Raphael38 will not be written ..

It wd provoke the hostility of

all camps – for Guilio Romano39

decreases & Raphael increases –

& most of what Morelli40 said

is unsaid or would be.

I ask him to dine with us

next Tuesday, & he departs, leaving

me weary, & sore vexed to hear

Michael’s ring a moment

or two later.

Friday Jan. 16th

To town in sunned[?] coldness –

at the Carfex[?]41 we look round

at the Blakes, having been

made to pay toll of it for

a Catalogue. Bobbie Ross42 soon

comes to us & presses to return

the toll. He is humorous as

a dog is good-tempered – on a

natural & noble scale.

He shows us the admired of

Shannon “Bathsheba at the

Bath” – “The Bard from Gray43” – that

is what a Ricketts will become

when he is mad – & The Deluge

where the sea is of[?]might[?]to[?]

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 27; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 13r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_027.jpg

[E.C.]

cover a Universe with its ridged

field of waters. There is an

Entombment – very simple, with

a light before the black veils of

the mourners – there is an

Ascension, where the springing

form, with aerial colour in it,

is seen from the back. Ross thinks

this figure unconsciously suggested

Fay’s44 back-treatment of the

Crucifix in Oscar’s45Sphinx46.

Upstairs is the gem – as of course

the perfect witness[?] of all.

Judging Fay has pronounced

on it – The River of Life47, Cap. Butts’48

lovely water-colour. What deliciousness

to swim through meadow-

lands on that stream – in flight

with its flying crystal – with

flutists piping your sylvan

salvation, & the air a

tapestry of the fruit of life!

And such a light in the sky –

yellow as sun setting, before it is

sundown, & while there is not

any sadness in it.

For the rest Blake had a repugnant

effect on the eyes that had not seen

him for many years, & among

the hideousness of nightmare

it seemed quite sane to hear

Bobby giving an account of all the

mad murderers at Broadmore49.

Terriss’s murderer seemed to think

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 28; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 13v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_028.jpg

[E.C.]

we⟨he⟩ had been just a little hasty –

& a man who had cut the throats

of his wife & many children had

made a stained glass window

for the chapel on the subject

‘suffer the little children

to come unto me & forbid them not’.

Fay has refused, like me, to

believe – but Bobby swears as

if he were in chapel. The governor

had never seen anything re-

markable in the window.

Bobby is to come to us on

Septuagesima Sunday & he

actually has wit to see the

humour that lurks in such

an intention!

The Dentist chops to my nerve –

but promises no-more ice-brook

pangs.

Off to the International. All Shannon’s

pictures look more beautiful

than in the studio – They & the

beauteous Symphony in White50, with

together with the Valparaiso51, of

Whistler52 are the things of beauty

there. Fay’s profound Entombmen

Burial is high – he angerly

calls it Skied – It is too high, & a

vile study by a young woman

of a white mousy young woman

chalks the eye sight ascending

gravely. The Committee should

be taken out & shot for such

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 29; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 14r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_029.jpg

[E.C.]

an insult. Shannon has spoken

his mind to the Scotchmen of

The Butter-Scotch Club53, as he

sardonically calls it.

We came on Shannon wandering –

with his lonely[?] gait, his drawn

cheek. He takes us to the

pictures & he talks with

reanimating eyes.

Suddenly – “There is the Monster”

& Fay sidles[?] from the pictures

in a white ill-mood. He

has written he cannot come

on Tuesday & has proposed

Wednesday. The Rodin-Shannon

exchange has been bungled

& turned to exasperating

issues by the influence of

‘so many others’ –––– We see

the torso54; it is lean & vigorous

as archaic Greek work.

Fay takes Michael to his likes &

his dear dislikes – storming

wavily on the Rodin subject –

Latin rage deep in his eyes.

Shannon & I talk the Palace

Pictures – a theme I am not

laggard at. We soothe – we

are nicely dressed – [?] Michael

delicious in the Directoire Hat –

& the occasion prospers. They

have to leave us for a business interview

at the Carfax[?].

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 30; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 14v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_030.jpg

[E.C.]

Friday, Saturday – Sunday – I go out.

I fill my being with air, &

the cold glory of the North

aspect of the wind.

Then Monday – all melted

putrifaction of the Spring.

But such great days with

Herod & Mariamne – our

Arab & Jewess. Our imaginations

have to toil like Explorers –

& we are exhausted to

stupification stone at night

with the effort.

Tuesday - Jan 19 th

By chance I open The Times to

see – & my heart rushes on

the track of my eyes – that

Arthur Strong55 is dead.

Relief for Bernhard56 is my immediate

feeling – the cruel enemy, who

had boasted he would utterly

crush him in England – gone into

the forbidding absolute of

silence! Then I rush to

Michael, & we feel together the

curious pain, as at the loss

of a thing of value, that we

always knew we should feel

when the unknown Strong passed.

Would we could have met

him once! Frailty – scholarship (For

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 31; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 15r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_031.jpg

[E.C.]

wh: women always have a yearning

devoutness) – a humanism, an

inhuman tongue – a face like

Erasmus’57 – he had lure … &

therefore doom is realised

in his having died.

Alice Trusted writes –

“There is always some scarce spectacle in

the valley that fills me with awe

like aerial things are wont to do.

On the 11th it was a rainbow that

shifted from the sky & hung on the

golden elms, for the cluster was

still arrayed with foliage above the

convent. The colours strengthened,

waned & brightened. Picture those[?]

prismatic hues alighting &

tangling[?] several moments on

gold. As the rainbow faded

a gentle shower fell. Not any

wind was stirring through the

valley & the rain drops, clearer

than pearls lingered on the fringe

of these golden leaves in the falling.”

Pater58 would have god–fathered

this catching or seizure of a

moment.

Mary59 writes of a woman’s lunch

at Boston, & how a lady, who is

writing an article upon pictures of

Circe ( she cd not imagine herself one

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 32; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 15v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_032.jpg

[E.C.]

as she resembled an animated rag-bag)

wanted to embrace Mary’s knees

when she heard she knew

Duse60 –– she said she had done

it to a lady who had been in

She continues – [?]

“William Yeats gave a rather silly

but nice lecture – in manner &

Trevy[?] & Roger62 . . . after the

a poet – He seemed pleased

though, & he told me he was

making more money than he

had ever made before in his

life. He is going to California

& has 20 more lectures to

give.”

Didn’t we find he liked the wreath!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 33; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 16r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_033.jpg

[E.C.]

Wednesday Jan. 20th

The Artists came out of the fog to dine - again

not beautiful as diners should

be – but they plead the frightful

weather, and indeed the star Earth

is getting a terrible place to

live in.

Michael wears her black striped silk

Directoire with fischu of ivory net

darned with green and bowed with

green velvet – a scarf of black

crêpe with underfrills[?] of green.

I bear the Manchu necklace

of on my old gold blouse.

Menu

Orleans Soup –

Cod à la crème [?]

Hare (roasted)

Plum pudding & zabajone

Canapés de S. Iral[?]

White Port & old dry Lisbon.

The dinner is, our guests say, “beautiful” –

we have good stories to tell from

America – but . . . there is Fay’s

hard prejudice against Herod & the

Arabs, & there is the dark abysm

of Strong’s death – these to us

spoil the evening. Manlike, Fay

skims the gulf elaborately – yet

once or twice I catch on him

that curious, consternating beauty

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 34; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 16v; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_034.jpg

[E.C.]

that seems to burgeon with the

thought of death.

The subtle heightening that

love gives to the appearance

of an animal – so that

its hair is more toyful,

its colour more pricking

to the sense, & in its motions

it lingers & yet is pregnant with

charm sparkle – this subtlety[?]

of effect the thought of death

evokes in Fay & makes him

lovely under it.

The only really good story he

tells is of Bobby Ross at

Edinburgh – during a literary

gathering that discussed Shakespeare’s

Sonnets. An elder of the Kirk

deplored the deep blot on what

would have been a blameless

reputation "But perhaps after

all Shakespeare meant no

harm" said Bobby weakly –

& it happened that just at that

moment the cock crow three

times.

The idea that Cockerell had leant⟨lent⟩

us Lady Anne Blunt’s Arabic

poetry seemed to chafe Fay – and

even Shannon turned abusive . .

Fay called our strip of old Persian

rug “Cockerellian” to punish us

– & then a cloud came round

the god, chilly and mumping[?]

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 35; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 17r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_035.jpg

[E.C.]

– yet at moments ⟨whiles⟩ vaporous

as if about an altar. So

he went, with cold fingers –

mortally cold adieux.

[K.B.]

the day after the artists have dined

with us, I write to Painter.

–

You are painting to-day, – you

are as a bee at her honey. I can

speak to you.

You can listen to one or two of my

songs about shells – & a sonnet, &

another. I have chosen, but who knows

how wisely, for the poet cannot choose,

or distinguish one song from another.

Comfort yourself with anything you

like in these dateless fragments, &

forget the rest.

We are happy this morning in a

big moth-brown Josephus. We have

just read how Cleopatra entreated

Herod ⟨Antony⟩ to give her Judea & Arabia.

These were the ages when one could

play with life, & toss the nations about

in the hollow of one's hand.

It is foolish, Painter, not to enter into

my joy in these great Jews & heathens.

Let this sentence convert you.

"Then were their glorious vessels

carried into captivity.

– there is a verse to move you!

Michael

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 36; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 17v; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_036.jpg

[K.B.]

The poems I send are –

Camellias – Onycha II. "Heralds there

are of love, the dusky flock.’’ “For Ever” &

the lovely shepherd

Friday. Bitter fog.

I write

Better it were that ball on finest wires

Frail Jenny Wren63 should perish of the cold

In the thick rime afar from winter fires,

Far from the crumbs that in my hands I hold,

Far better than the murder I have done,

Letting thee see the verse that I have writ,

Too deft, too delicate the couplets run,

Subtle in fancy, tender but in wit. –

Thou wilt not freeze them, that is not my fear –

Terror will strike them dead against the breast,

and very wintry[?] thou wilt make their bier,

And the bare ground, instead of woven nest.

O Sorrow that a woman must not speak

Save in pure symbol from the lip, the cheek.

It is Saturday Jan 23rd – More bitter

fog.

I strive by candle & by tallow-fog

light to read an Arabian ode, & a

chapter of Josephus.

It is awful to think of a studio

in the light of tallow fog also.

We cannot pass in or out.

Strong is in his grave, the whole

world is a grave above his grave –

We are shut up: on the line there are accidents –

"Bellina"64 is a widow now.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 37; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 18r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_037.jpg

[K.B.]

I write

I have left thee. Was our parting at the grave?

So wide it seems, nothing there is that dooms

And no impediment; I am seeking thee,

As from the river-head one seeks the sea,

Ever thou art, ever affronting me,

And the moon blooms.

Apple-Sunday – Jan 24th

Our Milton is very wonderful this morning

– Adam's appeal to his Creator for a

fellow – Heaven's sly response – the male

understanding – the perfect union of

the angels.

I come to Herod's story – to the great

chapter of the apple & the knife – I have

read this before – now I write it.

Heaven be praised. What precious stones

have been set in this baleful January!

In the afternoon – it is again the South

wind that does it – Henry's brain opens

its windows, & the Scenario.

Joseph. Mariamne – the Sous-Antipater

of the play is built up.

the fog is gone; there is no sunlight –

but we have been greatly visited, greatly

blest.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 38; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 18v; Hao Hoang Nguyen, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_038.jpg

[E.C.]

Tues Jan. 26th

We go on damp ground to town

– only for shopping & a dental

appointment. We see Whittaker

Wright65 has been condemned

to 7 years penal servitude. There

is a rush along of news boys –

He is dead.

The charm of the Man was

the velocity of the immense

stream of his idael idealism.

It drew into its own current.

The scale of it lured reason

itself – reason that Tommy66

declares in his own Paper on

Proportion (Monthly Review of the

Month) to be the antagonist of all

known forces other than itself &

therefore its most essential character

is the hope & desire to control &

transform the Universe?

Whittaker Wright perfected this

his Universe and consented to

let it exist on the condition

of dreaming it in millions.

Nothing lures & touches men so

much as a great scale.

A man in the Court is reported

to have murmured "He's had

thousands mine, but, upon my soul,

I could cry to see such an ending to

such a career.”

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 39; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 19r; Hao Hoang Nguyen, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_039.jpg

[E.C.]

During ⟨the last day of the⟩the trial he was doomed

or had doomed himself to death.

“It was as if the inner soul of

the man was living more rapidly

than the body could follow”.

After he was dead, six bare-headed

officials bore the Convict’s

coffin, & a little knot of men removed

their hats & helmets – he had

become the representative of

Death’s Empire.

Tommy’s Idea of Proportion is

full of fresh things said with

many pebbles in the mouth.

He has hit on my parallel

between artist & saint. He

puts it excellently – “both are

convinced, neither understands.”

Tommy also thinks the thoughts

of Bernhard67 that Art can

give Peace when the imagination

has trained reason to see a

friend in her enemy – the physical

order, & “we spell out from that

wh: Nature presents to us, the

desired word, the congenial” – as

Göthe68 says.

That incarnate dream from Egypt, I

have cut out, finds something

“congenial” in the Korean Post-

Master. I am grateful that Nature

made him.

[Page]

Now I must return to Monday

January 25th

[K.B.]

Sabbatai – the ring-day

Painters69 comes from ice of a tram-top[?] –

we talk quietly over the fire in the gold

-room till he thaws. He puts aside

the Lettere da Siena . . for a little while –

afterwards: “there are 2 of the poems

I greatly like . . . one might have been

in the Shakespeare Sonnets, & it

appears to me rather taller than some

of his . . . He suggests designing for

me a little writing-table[?].

Tea – then it is announced the

ring in its first modelling is here –

It is a gigantic ring, as Painter says

one of the largest rings in the world.

We lay it on his Baudelaire 70,71 with the

pendant: he gazes at his work. They

are 2 very beautiful objects.

He is persuaded to stay to dinner

& the time goes smoothly &

naturally.

If I were a poet he has said

to me, I should treat of disillusion.

Chopin72 is full of a glittering irony.

Even in painting he wd like to give

something of disillusion. But his

great desire in painting is to

express compassion.

Henry reads to him several of

my Sonnets, while I am in a

cloud of cigarette-smoking, puffing

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 42; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 20v; Hao Hoang Nguyen, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_042.jpg

[K.B.]

out my his atmosphere at⟨by⟩ the

balcony-window. I am well

started now on this path of

abstract passion I have chosen –

the air is rather fine & trembling[?]

& I suffer, & can report[?] nothing

of what is going on around me.

[E.C.]

Alice Trusted writes deliciously of St. Mawgan[?]

“There has been rime in the valley

for a few days; the gentlest breeze

would have shattered the en-

-chantment & not a breath stirred.

Picture Castle Dinas[?] with an even

mantle of hoar frost & the land-

-scape, soft, sunny & soothing: a

flaxen light falling upon the

waves of the little Path.”

Notebook 18, Page Image 43; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 21r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_043.jpg

[E.C.]

My version of Jan. 25 – Monday.

When I come into tea Fay73 is thawing

– he has promised, I hear, to be

very nice when he has thawed.

On the side-table are the Sonnets

in their Italian cover. Fay is

recalcitrant over mustard & cress

– in a sandwich the second bite

of them is corrupt on[?] the taste –

but when he finds them embalmed

in the new Gentleman’s Relish74 –

the bellamy[?]-like hand of

the Fay catches at several.

During tea we hear more of Bobby

Ross75 – & receive charges for the

occasion of his visit. We are con-

vinced that Bobby is being so

elaborately sent in order to

savour our “legend”, & then to

spread its charming meshes –

dyed in the rays of Fay’s glory.

Bobby has the fabulous lips,

touched with the light of humour,

that can assure a tradition.

While I am lighting the Sun-

Room (it is on the verge of a

flood of white-washing, & only

contains some fresh-cold

tulips that wave cleanly) Fay

suggests that he will design a table

(if possible) to stand under the

picture & support the pale flower

that is of ritual beneath it.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 44; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 21v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_044.jpg

[E.C.]

When Michael & he reach the

Sun-Room, now divided between

the open twilight & the straggling[?]

candle-light Fay proposes that

the Sonnets be read aloud.

Something this side of the

perfectly abstract makes him

say “Let your Fellow Read” – &

I put on the whole armour of

the Abstract, securing every

buckle, & read OchynOnycha,

wh: he had thought was not

quite uni[?] where it passed from

the flower to the shell. My voice converts

him.

I concluded

“And of the busy brain left desolate”

– without parting. Michael has

been standing in blackness

against the twilit window, &

her cigarette was is vaporous

for her screen.

Then I read Cammellias – but

this is even too long.

Finally I read, by the mantel-shelf

The Shepherd of the Wild. He greatly

praises the great exposition of

the first line – a master’s way

of beginning; but he objects to

“O Love, O mystery” as weak in effect

I complain “if we are to have

no statements & no interjections,

what are we to have?” He only

likes interjections when they are

purely instructive & have no trace

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 45; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 22r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_045.jpg

[E.C.]

of formalism or of the literary.

Verlaine’s are perhaps the most

perfect. “O toi “Qu’as tu fait, o toi

que voilà,

De ta jeunesse?”

There is nothing considered about

them.

All this time we have been cold

as moonbeams – he has been

as inquisitive as a moonbeam

into the art of these love-poems.

Yet all through the evening there

is that⟨such⟩ jewelled satisfaction

about his aspect that⟨as⟩ makes

the laurestine resemble the

holy myrtle itself, in a very wide

sense.

Suddenly we learn the Sabbatai Ring

is come in its first state – or is brought

out, with its doors, & spotted

dome, its butresses & its windows,

through wh: a loose emerald

flashes with ranging green, &

the tinkle of it is heard like a

God inside. What fancy assails

& prompts one in this strange

inward life of sound & flash[?]

from their prison! It is a wicked

way if making beauty court on

the sly, when she has conquered

by frank design & ornament. Yet

the courting beauty, though

transparently wicked, is utterly

delightful – & Fay’s joy in it is

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 46; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 22v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_046.jpg

[E.C.]

as a wit[?]’s joy in the rustling

laughter he evokes.

The ring Fay would like to be

ready for Sunday76, & indeed there

is in it an inherent legendary

element to be wished for

Bobby’s attention. It sits

on Michael’s finger like a

blue falcon, soft & indifferent

to any suffering. It does not

care for the blasphemers – it

sits invested in dignity.

Indeed as it lies on Baudelaire77

with the pendant I cannot

wonder that their author finds

them most beautiful.

Fay has been feeling his life shrunk[?] –

he must read Shakespeare.

We speak of Troilus & Cressida

– he writhes with excess of pleasure

in it. Then we press him to stay

& dine, winning his acceptance

when we promise a telegram to

Shannon78 & a nice dinner,

though the cook is out.

During its course we mostly talk

of Mary79 & Berenson80 who are now

at Chicago, visiting pork-kings &

steel-kings –! some with houses

that suggest an orgy – some with

Japanese servants who lecture at

the University on social science

& philology on their evenings out. One

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 47; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 23r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_047.jpg

[E.C.]

Magnate of the Meat-market disbelieves

in war between Russia & Japan81

just because the orders are not

such as accompany the extreme

course[?].

The Fairyman takes daintily[?] & with

content his soup, roast lamb,

junket & damson tart.

Then upstairs over coffee great

talk begins – only to be broken

by arrival of model blouses,

that must be seen & immediately

returned by the bearer. One[?], in

ivory net & black velvet, is

confirmed to me, with a few

sharp-edged⟨eyed⟩ improvements of

a value scarcely believable.

Outside the messenger steals my

money & departs with it.

Then we talk of delusion. It is to

him the poetry of What remains

– of the pot-pourri, of the light

after sunset, of love when

passion is gone, often of religion.

⟨It is what remains of precious in the ashes.⟩

He would love to give it in music.

Baudelaire gave it in literature.

Rossetti82 in the dusty[?]inns[?] has

touched it beautifully, but it is

a very rare theme.

Baudelaire is brought – he reads in

his rapid French too rapid to be

transparent to one’s understanding,

several of his [ his]⟨Baudelaire’s⟩ most cherished poems:

L’Aube Spirituelle.83Le Cr (specially

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 48; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 23v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_048.jpg

[E.C.]

dwelling on the marvellous phrase

“stupides orgies”) & Crépuscule du

Matin84 (full of pity – that

most rare quality in Art) &

La Rebelle.85

The last 4 lines of the Crépescule

ought to have been omitted.

The greatest of Baudelaire’s poems

is La Géante86 – the vast impersonality

that denies its very sex, everything

& expresses itself in a form

so vast & yet plastic. It is

perhaps one of the most remarkable

things man has done.

Next to it comes La Beauté87 – then

L’Aube Spirituelle – then

Femmes Damnées88 (without its last

exclamatory verse)

Just before the reading of Baudelaire

I had read Tommy’s89Don Juan90

aloud – first to the entreaty I

wd leave out the iterated Don Juan

then to the entreaty I would

leave off altogether. Fay sprang

up, stamping[?] & declaring the

childish – almost infamous in

taste. Don Juan is a grand gentleman

– the type of the Debauché wh:

gives the world vast pleasure

& takes on himself almost the

pains of a saint: A creature enjoyed

as a saint is worshipped almst

for his idealism. He would make the

world nearer to the heart’s desire –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 49; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 24r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_049.jpg

[E.C.]

& Don Juan faced damnation for

his dreams – he never recoiled

fearful . . . & then to be told

he wore silk stockings & they stuck

out under his cloak when the

dance was ended by Death –

Tommy ought to be birched.

Baudelaire’s Don Juan aux Enfers

with its magnificent last lines –

"Mais le calme héros, courbé sur sa rapière,

Regardait le sillage et ne daignait rien voir"

is far more, though not wholly,

adequate.

Then talk goes to the meeting with Bernhard

& the friendship with Oscar91. Fay says

they & Oscar never talked anything

but inspired “rot”. As women, we

probably have no idea how playful

men are among themselves.

Fay said scarcely anything. –

nothing serious – Oscar tried all

his newest paradoxes on them ⟨or⟩

elaborated exciting, fantastic

projects. Before dinner I had

shown Fay our two letters from

Oscar & delighted him specially with

Oscar’s desire to see our characters

in golden masques (we are to show

these letters to Bobby – as two

bricks in “the legend.”)

Then we ⟨have⟩ fine merry times over the

Artists’ Orders – over the Cochon d’Or92– [?]

That we lay for in vain “avec soif

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 50; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 24v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_050.jpg

[E.C.]

inassouvie”.93 No hope of it in

Paragon! Only Sappho can

have it among women, & she

partly from politeness.

Baudelaire w d have all the

orders – Cochon d’Or – L’Oiseau

bleu94 & Couronne des Épines.95

The last, Fay thought, I might

have, with a few thorns

added from time to time for

delapidations – Michael

refuses L’Oiseau bleu, even

with 4 wings, & confesses on

her death-bed she means

to wring Fay’s heart to give

her the Cochon d’Or.

Keats is very difficult to decorate

– he ought to have all the

orders & they none of them have

quite fit.

Shakespeare – Michael denies him

the Cochon d’Or – he is too much

like herself. But Fay says yes,

for the sake of Troilus & Mid-

Summer Night’s dream & such

things as

“Her bed is India & herself a pearl” –

“My God, what a fluke!” – he wrings

his hands with Cochon d’Or Ecxtasy.

Bobby may be made an Associate.

Moore has no Cochon d’Or in him –

Nor, we have to protest, had Browning

enough for the order – dissent too

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 51; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 25r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_051.jpg

[E.C.]

shrewdly fretted the golden floor of

Nature, the Cochon d’Or must

have. Shannon has to have it only[?]

because he is a fellow divinity[?]

by the Grand Master Ricketts –

Mary Berenson might have

the hope dangled before her – if

she would induce some Meat-

Kings to buy it at an enormous

price.

The sm badge is a Golden Pig, with

a pearl in his mouth & the

legend Sweets to the Sweet.

Ah me - - - ah, me! – ah, ah, me!

The Crown of Thorns is only for those who

struggle & agonise for Art’s own

sake – The Oiseau bleu is

for the chosen spirits of

culture and art – those who are

rare & charming in personality.

On this fun we part – after 6 hours

of converse & scarcely tired.

Shannon thinks Fay “forgiving” – we

assure him he is the contrary –

wh: Fay supports by saying of

his enemies “I take the air

from them.”

Fay has looked beautiful at times,

with a crested & lively appearance.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 52; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 25v; Stephen Lagos, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_052.jpg

[E.C.]

Fay quotes for richness, such

as our[?] literature used to have,

Crashaw’s “tender crumbs” – of

the dust of a body.

[K.B.]

On Saturday even Jan 30 th after

a long week of disorder. Whitewashers[?]

& rubs[?] – not pictures on the walls,

we are at work again ie we are

in our rooms, we pace.

Oh the re-lighting of the altars!

A shrine where the blasphemers

have left marks!

Four times I seek flowers -

White, sepulchral with arums –

– the air cannot float a wing[?]

Four times with bitter rain

piercing[?] me to the flesh – [?] I wrestle –

by candle-light time – with Lady-

apples, with Love apples, with

tulips “in answerable style”, & the

red – points[?] of P96Settia[?]-life is

established visible among us.

The first flickering narcissus

flickers on the shrine. A periwinkle

with trailing[?]-wreaths hangs outside

the casement of the lesser gold room.

A

Love-Apple Sunday.

I review the month. We have

fought well in it, facing many things.

Now we must face the publisher

Our mottoes of Diligence & Oassiu[?] must

continue. The pine & [????] scent

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 53; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 26r; Stephen Lagos, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_053.jpg

[K.B.]

must come as they will - they will be

scents across the battlefield.

God knows that where He plants the

foot on the sand, He must set the

mirage. It is the absence of a little

cloud before that is making life

so difficult now. One cannot

be looking down on the sand one is

treading.

We turn again to Herod, to the

Creation of Cleopatra.

February 3 rd.

Days large & blank with spring.

I am weary even of my prayers.

No call from Heaven or earth –

I go a’shopping. but mercy I say to

myself: “Why should one buy stockings,

if one has not happy feet?”

Maccabees97 we are reading in the morning –

miserable & wordy & of no account –

with here & there an unforgettable phrase.

Rossetti’s98 complete edition of Christina

arrives. It gives the love episodes of

her life. How this unhappy brother has

blurred the images of his great ones!

One of the purest creatures he has

known; but pure-blank, like a yard

of calico.

Apparently religion was as a deteriorating

influence on her humanity & on her art.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 54; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 26v; Stephen Lagos, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_054.jpg

[K.B.]

She is the creature who could have given

us a cradle-song.

Woe to the gods that ruined her.

For she is essential poet - the female–dove.

She has neither out-look or inlook; she

Knows nothing: she has music &

Fragrance & flight; she passes among us

A singing-bird, & her song drops spices –

Never shall she written what does not

Float, or fall, or pass as a mourner.

Movement always – & a stirring of

feet that are happy.

Take her anywhere - she is the

poet.

“She listened like a cushat dove99

That listens to its mate alone:

She listened like a cushat dove

that loves but only one.”

[E.C.]

Feb. 5.

I can do nothing but watch

the gray almightiness of the

flood – the inward and

fountainous upheaval

by which it attains the

volume of its power. The

light rolled on it. It is far more

brilliant than the spring sky.

It motions wonder over

it. It arrives like a King’s

silence.

And Herod grows like the river.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 55; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 27r; Stephen Lagos, Holly Laird (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_055.jpg

[K.B.]

Friday February 5th

I take love-apples to the Palace, & the shell

is turned out of the Murano jar to make

place. One stained crimson apple pushes

up from the satinwood.

The Sabbatai ring is there - the generous

ring: – the shrine, & the presence, & the blue

dome. I see also a worthless ring

given to a model for a bet. The distance

is immeasurable.

“This ring will cause much offence”

Painter100 says, & I add “That pleases you.”

Tommy’s101 Jewel is seen – still twinkling,

& uncertain, & the just-finished

picture of the Son in the parcelle[?] of the

vineyard.

I pass on to the manor, & see the

small, dear One in her vast

drawing-room. I return to Henry –

– the chief miracle! Henry reads

me in the type-proof Sabbatai Act II – and

part of the 2nd. Cleopatra scene in Herod.

Henry rises from depression to a living

spiral flame. Long after I have fallen

asleep in my bed she is exploring

North’s Plutarch.102

To-day, I feel as if my fields were

covered with Manner[?]

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 56; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 27v; Stephen Lagos, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_056.jpg

[K.B.]

Monday. February 8th.

A wild, west gale.

We are absent from each other, being

each present with Herod of Jews.

The ring with Painter was to have

come to-day.

– War is declared between Japan

& Russia

– I write a little of the scene of

Herod’s Return to Mariamne (2nd scene)

these curd-winds of the spring –

the waste, the vanity!

Again I read Christina.103

Her tiny[?] lyrics are like showers

of blossom from the tree.

In multitude they are lovely –

they are shaken down from

the tree of life: they do not grow there.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 57; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 28r; Stephen Lagos& Kellie K. Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_057.jpg

[K.B.]

On beholding a ring set with a star-Sapphire

What is it? – not the fetter of Arch[?]-plight,

What is it? – not the signet of a King,

Nor deep-inscribed, nor holy, perfumed ring

With phial for the venoms that requite,

Nor wrought for any separate delight;

It is a dream, a mighty compiling,

A shrine from many windows flickering,

The prison of a tinkling chrysolite.

His religions, for its azure vault

Burys a star above the thick assault

Of golden doors; & it is given us:

It will work much offence, needs must it be

To the wan world matter of injury,

Being of itself profound & generous

Feb. 8th 1904

Of Wednesday, February 10th

Shannon104 calls it “Solomon”, & the

tinkling within “The Song of Solomon”.

It is the most perfectly successful

achieving, of all the jewels. Its

doors are to be smeared with

ambergris, so that it may

appeal to all the five senses.

In its soft cloud a star beams.

But it is not as a ring it excels.

Blessedly, an old, cleaned, favourite

blouse, low, square, with velvet

stomacher[?], turned up.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 58; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 28v; Kellie K. Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_058.jpg

[K.B.]

& I put the ring on “breastie[?]” by a gold-

-chain, the full Pegasus-ornament

below on black velvet …

Henry[?] & Painter105 fell to adoration – I

could have laughed at them.

But we were all very happy, &

there is no conversation to

report in the year-book.

My Beloved wore a new blouse, &

the Chinese necklace, & looked

the sweetest. Her grief had been

I should have nothing to wear. But

that gracious old blouse had all

the effect of a “sling.”

A guest is expected to lunch to-

day. Henry has had to plead

for fresh dishes. I wanted him

to have the flaws[?] & bones of

last night’s banquet – bone of

Welsh Mutton, stone-cream

drawn together, chestnuts & apple-

jelly patted down.

However, I consent to one new

cutlet.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 59; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 29r; Kellie K. Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_059.jpg

[E.C.]

Yes, February 10 th, was undescribable

indescribable as the changes of

light.

It begins in the wild drift of rain

& wind that is our outward life

now-a-days.

We have given up Fay106 for tea –

when suddenly he comes, more

enlivening than many pots of

tea. The ring is tossed down …

“Here is the distinguished stranger!”

I am allowed to found[?] it on

my finger for a while – such

an exquisite building – a

little gem of space-composition

enshrining a presence, an

emerald green as jealousy – a

song that water-brooks make.

Fay has shown it to the buried

Bobbie Ross107, & bore it on his

finger when he met Roger Fry108

at the Burlington Art Club109. He

was extremely disgusted Roger

took[?] no notice of it; when but

was restrained from himself calling

attention to it by remembrance

of a friend’s remark to Baudelaire110,

when ⟨he ⟩⟨protested ⟩⟨made an⟩ infuriated ⟨protest⟩ that his blue

powdered hair had not received

attention “Oh, everyone is wearing

blue powder just now”.

Bobbie Ross last year took a cabful of

pictures to an ⟨American⟩ Millionaire’s hotel – was

kept waiting 2 hours – laid picture after

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 60; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 29v; Kellie K. Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_060.jpg

[E.C.]

picture out on the chairs only to

hear the millionaire instruct

his son “give the young man

from Carfax’s[?]111 half-a-crown, &

tell him to take the pictures

away.

We are afraid Bobbie

did not keep the half-crown.

He ought to have had it

pierced for a chain!

Fay is full of the giddiness

of spring – he has little

wings at his heel – &

is attentive to the folly

of the birds – the little

hoopoes in every bush.

His desire is upon Italy.

After dinner we talk long,

Long – of “impressions d’ Italie”112

Fay’s time, that he cannot

forget, is night, when the

spirit comes out from the

past of a place – when

the shadows are so black

– they are neither blue nor

green. The air too of our

Italian night is so gushing

& large in its freshness – the

solitude, save round the

social lights of several cafés,

is complete.

Shannon is tired & fearful

at night-time on their travels

– he sinks down to old numbers of

[Page]

[E.C.]

periodicals – then the Latin restlessness

comes on Fay; the climate does

not hurt him – he goes out in

to the shadows where the old

Genius is also & they are together.

Another thing that has struck

him is the way the very buildings

soar into the night air indifferent

to all life of today or tonight.

The Ducal Palace113 is high away

from the Piazza.

Fay loved the Pinciano[?]114 where Messalina115

gave her fashionable dances –

Via Sacra!117

He too have ⟨has⟩ felt the charm of

Adige, the colour in the light –

so that blue makes one think

at once of pink, & pink of

the green of the sea.

Also the sturdy growth of foliage

round Bergamo118 had arrested

that in a fortnight he could trim

pronounced beautiful; & the

[Page]

silver bowl edged with rusty wallflowers

Fay is much struck with Michael’s

He also agrees with her that,

Another remark of Michael’s that

Christina Rossetti & [?] vaunted

Purity, that it is ⟨blank⟩that of as

piece ⟨a yard⟩ of new calico.

Fay has noticed that I seem always

to be defending my opinion from

a blow. He knows I have not

talked enough in my life. This

causes me to be very slow in

approaching a good remark & so

swift in uttering it that it is lost –

& falls ineffective, unless special attention

catches it.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 64; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 31v; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_064.jpg

[E.C.]

The whole 6 hours of this visit

were filled with confidence –

the quiet passing of time

over a deep harmony.

Fay spoke about his longing

to have a clean way of

getting his living, & of

the difficulty of realisation

seeing he is illiterate

though cultured. He

dwelt on the Catastrophe

of having stooped once

from his haughtiness

& thus allowed a

picture of his to be skyed

(wh: it really is not).

He is not well – dreaming

of this time last year when

he had influenza, till

the dream tends to become

reality.

[K.B.]

February 14 th

Bobby Ross comes – using very

skillfully the wild[?]rain[?] for penitential

tears – to pray forgiveness

Feb 15th A Season of the wildest

floods – with spring sunlight lying

in them.

The Thames rushes past.

One walks in weakness & hope

Notebook 18, Page Image 65; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 32r; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_065.jpg

[K.B.]

I spent Saturday Feb 13th with Amy Bell.

lunching at the Sesame Club.

“Do you know, Kaing[?], “why Edith

should have been born in February?”

“No, Amy”

“Because, Kaing[?], geniuses are always

born in February” &, “She continued,

(Knowing[?] my birthday was in October?)

Generally people of importance are

born in the first half of the year!!!

“I was born”, she added, with a smile

that illuminated the event between

the day & the dark at half past six.

We drive about Camden Hill & Kensington

looking at the tiny houses – featureless

as toast – in one of wh. She hopes some

day to live.

“Great idealists are always good

house-keepers – You, Kaing[?], are

a good house-keeper. It is true.

She refuses to discuss Fitz-Gerald’s

life. I loathe him. I loathe the

weak pessimism of Omar.

By thee I find the book has been

given as a present – where it

will do harm.

I am hoping to get a book – the

Youth of Balzac.122

He cured love of the prejudice of

Youth it is finely said of him.

[E.C.]

Wicked story of ⟨an⟩ old Quaker –

Butterman.

His daughter had been

married, but it was difficult

to bring the him to admit

it when questioned. At last

he confessed the fact with

a groan – that she had

married a man employed

in the manufacture of

pianos. “But” he added,

“it is a matter for rejoicing

that the young man is

not employed upon their

carnal parts.”

This from Mary!

[K.B.]

February 17 th

Ash-Wednesday & – my Father’s123

birthday. He is now in mortal

years, an old man, over ninety.

I bless & honour him. I look

-forward to making his acquaintance

in the Hereafter. I have received

of his power & manhood.

He has bequeathed himself

to his race. The lyric of his

life is sung in Sabbatai

Notebook 18, Page 67; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 33r; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_067.jpg

[K.B.]

Vitality must be the watchword for this

Lent – a constant feeling of life – the fare

from Heaven bounteous[?] – the Eljah Ravens

staggering beneath the load on their

sumpter[?] wings.

Henry after a week of suffering

is, I hope, healing softly by the fire.

Last night we read Callirrhoe 124 – the

work of well-nigh twenty years ago.

How soft, & crescive it all is.

In Herod. I am chipping out Alexandra.

We have decided there shall be

2 plays, one treating of Mariamne,

One, possibly of the sons.

Now Henny is happy – a great

weight is removed from her

brain – Fast & hurrying the tide

can spread itself to the sea!

[E.C.]

Yes – Ash Wednesday; & Miss Bray

sends up a box of red camellias

– one falls in a cone, the others

are founded[?] in our glass-vases.

The contrast of these creatures

of Oriental grain, of the brilliancy

of a syrup, with ashes & salt

fish is entirely piquant.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 68; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 33v; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_068.jpg

[E.C.]

Friday Feb. 19 th

At last, at last!

I have had a snail-walk

to the Terrace this blessed day –

the laurels of the slope in

their shining & dapple, the

channels left by the low-tide

of the flood below me.

And I have seen catkins

waggle.

This morning Barr125 sent some

purple hellebores & they have

been making the light into

wine . . at the same

time a little pair of black

& white evening-shoes appeared

for Michael126, quite as adorable

& worthy of a royal guard

of glances as any Tyrian

flower.

Yesterday Michael brought in

Rochefoucault’s Maxims127,

picked up for 6d. They certainly

are the Panopeptone of Wisdom

– its Essence of beef & wheat.

Our education has been

starved. Not to know Rochefoucault

except by quotation & by name!

Also yesterday Herod128 formed

into two plays – The Asmoneans’

Slave & The Roman – the first on

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 69; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 34r; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_069.jpg

[E.C.]

Herod’s passionate love for ⟨& rage against⟩ Mariamne,

the second on his love for & rage

against his sons.

Everything comes straight now;

& we have the motto of

the two plays, that will

have an Over-title of

Herod of Jewry, in Crabbe’s129 –

“The Shapeless purpose of a soul that feels

And half-suppresses rage & half reveals.”

This we found in the Life of Fitzgerald130 –

that record of a sublime crank.

Dr Garnett 131, at lunch the other day,

was marvellously struck with

our conception of Herod’s passion

for Mariamne, as the first

great instance of Chivalry at

the Arabic source. To treat

Herod racially is to have the

germ of a new type – Herod the

Idumæan explains himself . . .

“The voice is that of Esau”- the

love is that of Knight-Errantry.

We have been reading again Callirhoë132 –

with what fresh, young grip it does what

it wants. The lessons of our youth

are penetrative.

We have recalled that day in early

June 1884, when the local publisher

sent a horseman to tell us that

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 70; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 34v; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_070.jpg

[E.C.]

there was a review of columns in

The Spectator. Amy133 & I rushed

To Clifton Down, while Michael

watered the roses & lilies in the

round bed before Stoke Green.

No “engagement” has ever changed

the movement of the Spirit

through the flesh, as that

announcement there was a

New Poet – changed the substance

of my youth. I slept no wink,

the paper under my head; & I

heard the rustling summer-

storm pass with its skirts &

gather them together in

the ⟨great⟩ chambers of the night.

Last Sunday Bobbie Ross came

to apologise for his failure to

appear two Sundays before.

He came under penitential

rain. I was wrapped in the

black & golden Persian veil, round

my afflicted cheek – Michael

had to be dressed by Lillias134.

We treated Bobbie as a Deadman

but he insisted on regarding

our Come in as a Viaticum.

Very skillfully with deliberation,

he prepared the story that was

to conquer our forgiveness.

He had been to Florence.

On his return his friends did not ask

[Page]

him about the Baptistry, about

!!! . . . ??? . . .

“Berenson was not by Berenson”

The sensation was indescribable

Mrs Berenson was packing

up.

Then we talked about Fay136 –

on the ₤250 Bobbie has got a

Bimmie137. One day – if there might

be a happiness for Fay.

Little is said on this short visit, of
