[E.C.]

mind & spirit, at the same time

there is something illusive about

this man, with his romantic

kindness, & his wit as

deliberate as a growth. We

do not yet understand him.

The face is dark-skinned – square

about the jaw – a little mastiff

-like; the black eyebrows have

the concave of Spinoza’s139 – in

the eyes there is the character

of a dog’s – something kind &

fixed & not of men – yet

devout.

[K.B.]

Feb 24 th

Yesterday, of his own nature,

Fay came, & of my[?] grace stayed

the evening.

– I cannot write my own gospel; I

leave it to the loving S. John140.

[E.C.]

Feb. 18th

A Word from Fay141 on the Ring Sonnet

“I like the Sonnet immensely – it is

quite admirable in texture & the last

line very fine indeed. It is a pity that

its subject-matter makes it obscure to

anyone who does not know the ring, as

domes, towers, floors &c do not usually

form part of fetters[?] of troth plight or the

guerdons[?] of joy with or without economy”.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 74; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 36v; Ahmed Alzohairy, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_074.jpg

[E.C.]

Feb 24 th

St. John begins.

Black pansies, & purple Hellebore –

A long waiting –

As the late tea-bell rings, the

door-bell rings[?], & Michael

descends with welcoming

bloom, a single long curl

on her shoulder. That has

immediate welcome, with

enthusiasm – Another,

a shorter one, is, as Alice

Trusted says, “desiderated”

Yes – the curl is a triumph!

It winds into the warm

pulses that admire.

Man certainly is Curl-

ridden! Michael boasts

the curl that the Babes[?]

rejected is become the Corner

-stone of an effect.

Man has a sentiment about

the curl – some little wriggle

of silliness in his estimate of

it – something of Richardson

emergent even in a Son of

the 20th Century.

In telling Fay 142 about Georges Rodenbach’s

prostrate grief over the ruin of Bruges

we refer to the way in wh: we

lost a year’s happiness in woe over

the loss of our view. We must not

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 75; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 37r; Ahmed Alzohairy, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_075.jpg

[E.C.]

depend for life on these things – we must

rely on our selves – There is nothing

reliable but oneself . . . one must

make a self on which one can rely.

Fay speaks at tea of Christianity, &

its failure among men – through

some lapses of judgment in

its founder (turning the other

cheek – e.g.) it destroys the

sense of Honour, wh: in men

has been of the highest importance

to their perfection. The difference

of the effects of a virile & of

a feminine creed are⟨is⟩ sharply

marked among Eastern Christians

& Mohammedans, when they

are in juxtaposition.

The passive virtues are not of

the essence of manhood.

“Not that I am speaking with favour

of Mohammedanism, like Strong143;

for it has blighted wherever it has

fallen” he adds. “But it is a great

pity Christianity made an initial

mistake.”

Upstairs Fay pockets the 6d Letters

of Lord Chesterfield144 – a little old book.

Michael had been most brilliant

& dramatic upstairs – the Curl

was an inspirer.

I am all the time wrapped up in a

Persian Scarf, clouding face-ache in

a tangle of gold. Fay stays to

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 76; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 37v; Ahmed Alzohairy, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_076.jpg

[E.C.]

Dinner, receiving his ambergris

just before descending.

We give him Sabbataї to take

back. Will he like it? We

guess No on the whole. Its rhythms

may confuse him.

Then we talk of “Anthony &

Cleopatra”. She has not held

him profoundly. He gives me the

impression that to him she

is lacking in sensuality (of

the Cochon d’Or kind145) & in

mysteriousness – the spell

is too rattling & voluble.

In the same way Anthony is

wanting in that sudden

self-question that comes to a

man even when he has

broken up under infatuation –

“Is the spell worth all this?”

These humiliating are felt

by all in love.

There comes a crack into a

man’s nature in these matters.

Love is not of the substance

of his very life as with woman

& when it comes to him

it leads ⟨sometimes⟩ to the holy un-

accountable.

Fay feels the relation of Anthony

& Cleopatra, except in the wonderous

early scenes, is of a divine

rhetoric – perfect in its mighty

tone. He has so far valued

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 77; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 38r; Ahmed Alzohairy, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_077.jpg

[E.C.]

Julius Caesar more intensely, as being

more on a human level.

We should read Troilus & Othello

constantly. Othello is so modern

that even the lovely rhetoric of

the Sibyl passages startles us

back three centuries.

Fay likes Lady Macbeth & would love

to see her come on, with a roller

in her hand, & flour on her arms,

like a good housewife.

I tell Fay of Callirhoë & the the

swift horseman bearing news

of the first Review.

Then Michael tells charmingly

of the defection of her youthful

lover & her surprise – while

Fay bubbles at the rosy drama

she enacts from her perch on

the settee.

Still later we talk of his parents –

of his English father who re-

-sembled Holmes & called

his only son Madmoiselle.

Fay was 17, when he met Shannon,

still a ‘fluffy’ boy. Shannon

does not care to talk of the

past – so uncomplimentary of

him!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 78; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 38v; Nancy Capone Beeman, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_078.jpg

[K.B.]

29th. Feb. Ember Saturday

– So flees away into Eternity

another month!

–But we turned with prayer for the

Creation of Cleopatra in February –

Cleopatra is created. The floods

are subsiding. With mere patience

we shall do well. Only the cry of

the Saints is us ours – O for a closer

walk with God!

Full thanks for our lives, & the

accomplishing of our lives!

March in its “devotion” considers

S. Joseph. Let it be with us the

month of “fostering” – gracious fostering

of all gracious things.

Yesterday I arrived tired at the

Palace146. Fay147 was fresh-shaven, & had

the bleak appearance of an

East wind. Late a Count –

arrived, a well-bred personage, full

of easeful tact. The speech was

formal; but the eyes need not be

formal, even with strangers.

Tall & injured by illness & suffering

Helen Fry148 came in to Miss Toplady’s149

yesterday.

Very simply she said she was

going to pray –

Ah, would it were so with us!

Would indeed we all went forth to

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 79; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 39r; Nancy Capone Beeman, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_079.jpg

[K.B.]

Confess & be shriven, & to pray.

Worship as spectators – without the

crooked[?] knee & the contrite heart – without

the real, personal sacrifice – is disinterprating[?]

We do not meditate, or pray, or believe...

God keep us in our little home; it is

unexpressibly dear to us, & we ask to

live no where else.

[E.C.]

I must suppliment this time, from

what Michael150 told me by the

fireside.

Fay is “woolly” & ill. He might

have been seen that morning

running from the Marble Arch to his

book-shop for an Anatole France 151,

running though he felt ill. He

returned also with a bottle of Baltic

herrings – “Would you like to see

them?” They appear; & Michael

remarks “they are as beautiful as

precious stones” They lie silvering

round the sides of the bottle,

in white wine, with corals & pink

sea-weed, as it were, a’shimmer

between. Anatole France gives him

great delight, though he knows in

ten years the books will be

intolerable. “Oh yes, you are so

strictly contemporaneous now”

scolds Michael.

He brings out portraits of Mrs Richard

Green & Mrs Hacon 152. He rejoices in

Michael’s remark that Mrs Hacon

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 80; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 39v; Nancy Capone Beeman, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_080.jpg

[E.C.]

has a beauty as if born of itself

like true apple-ness of the

apple. She has also that great

mark of beauty the breaking

of the lips into flower.

Discussing women’s beauty,

Michael says that eyebrows

are the most important

point in the face for appearance.

Fay assents & rejoins that

any woman if she arranges

her hair properly, takes care

of her eyebrows & tries to

have a bit of black velvet

at her neck will look well.

Michael repeats praise of Shannon’s153

portrait. “Shannon always did

appeal to the vulgar taste of

the vulgar” Fay gibes.

He has to confess he will have

no pictures ready for the spring

– not till winter. O Fay, frittered

Fay!

He opens a box by Korin 154 – “full

of Illusion & Disillusion” . . . .

The little ball of ambergris &

two opals given by Michael

& some designs for Omar155.

Michael pleads that the opals are

not disillusion & is referred to

the unused set of designs for Omar.

Mrs Tommy’s pendant is on view –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 81; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 40r; Nancy Capone Beeman, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_081.jpg

[E.C.]

it has been drawn out a success

by its marvellous little Inventer.

The modelling of Psyche156 & the Dog

of Hell157 is magnificent – the

effect is gorgeous.

Birny’s[?]158 bride only has a Holbein

Pendant159 – this is well.

Birny[?] is to the true poet what

an adopted design is to a

created one.

When the Count comes there is talk

of Fay’s birthplace – Geneva. The

Count proposes as a game

to find the place where each ought

to have been born. Fay had a

narrow escape of being born at

the right place – Naples. Michael

would like to have been born in

London. Fay says “that is where

a poet should be born”.

The rapidity of the river at Basle[?]

is mentioned. Michael says the

rushing of a river along gives

her the sense of perfect repose.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 82; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 40v; Nancy Capone Beeman, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_082.jpg

[E.C.]

We have had a card from Tommy in

Rome. He thought of us at the

Borgia apartments where he went

not with subtle poisons

“To thin the scarlet conclave of

old men”160 but to stare at

Pinturicchio’s161 pretty, mellow

frescoes. He picked a leaf & violet

-bud off Keats’ grave for us –

“that is if you have not already

got several. It is a delicious spot,

covered by violets, shaded by

beautiful pines & ilex-bushes, &

strange with stone-monuments,

looking at one another like

foreigners with different tongues

but the same thoughts &

business . . . Woe, I must out

with it! I met Arthur Symons

yesterday. Duse162 has accepted

a play of his on Tristram & Isolt163

& is going to begin to study in it

in May. I felt so angry with

him. We also thought of you

at the baths of Caracalla &c

It is well to be thought of in Rome.

O blessed, O Empire of our

Imagination! – Than⟨Even⟩ if Duse

takes Symons’ Tristan – Little

Arthur, who lifted me up to see the

Procession in Notre Dame de

Paris!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 83; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 41r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_083.jpg

[K.B.]

March 2 nd, Wednesday. S. Chad’s Day

Henry has read to me the scene at

Sundown[?] between Herod & Salome

– the waiting for Mariamne’s death.

– It is level up with Othello.

It has made March already a

month of huge experience

And there is verdure & quickening

green all round[?] the smaller

scenes. More & more the

story is tightening[?] to the throttling

love-grip of Mariamne. Herod’s

passion in its curse, its cheeks,

its headlong fall into the sea –

the theme. He asked the

Infinite in his affections, the

infinite of Woman, Child, &

God. He was infinite in praise

and in the art of praise-

building. His memory built

in monuments.

The vacant memory of regret he

could not bear, – that is why he

carried Mariamne about with

his embalmment[?].

In Herod I create myself Man –

– the make of Herod’s nature is

mine.

How wonderful Heaven is to us –

– setting us on the track, giving us

the clue to its hid treasure –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 84; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 41v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_084.jpg

[K.B.]

3rd Sunday in Lent.

“Yesterday I bought a T.P. to help me

on my[?] underground way to a

matinée – Behold the sixties[?] & George

Dawson!

Question at the Birm: School

board of the introduction of an

unsectarian hymn-book. George

Dawson turns over the leaves.

“Lord I ascribe it to thy grace

And not to chance as others do,

that I was born of Christian race,

and not a heathen or a Jew.”164

“Would members have any objection”

he said, “if this were altered to run

“Lord, I ascribe it to thy grace,

And not to luck, or chance’s work,

that I was born of Jewish race,

And not a Christian or a Turk.

I am proud the worth & influence of

my first great teacher, as in this

T.P., should be recognised nearly

40 years after this his quoted saying.

The matinée was Ray Blas.

Mrs. Pat should be Mariamne –

Lewis Waller might be Herod. His race has

some power of inflection.

If Mrs. Pat’s voice is her own, & not worn

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 85; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 42r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_085.jpg

[K.B.]

like false hair. What a fungus creature

she is – not a wholesome growth for

blossom & fruit – well-coloured & of

the abnormal-earthly.

– I speak of her as shown in Ray Blas.

[E.C.]

Thursday, March 3 rd

The Artists dine. Shannon

comes first – vengeful from a

committee. He is looking &

confesses to being well.

His sanguines[?] are fluent

& his eyes have a transparency

they have not had for very

long. He immediately admires

the blouses & Michael’s

stronger-curl.

Then Fay comes, hurried, looking

very small, meeting Shannon

with amity, & the Curl with

the assurance it makes its

mistress look years younger –

“into three figures” she intensifies.

Dinner

Clear Soup

Cod à la Crême

Black cocks

Chocolate Jelly

Pine-chunks & Junket

Champignons Farcis

Fay has been reading Josephus’ portrait

of Cleopatra. This [????]aised Queen of

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 86; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 42v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_086.jpg

[E.C.]

Egypt lends herself to farce. She

is a fruit of a putrescent

civilisation like the Chinese

Empress. He is greatly interesting⟨ed⟩

in hearing about Dryden’s

All for Love, in wh: Cleopatra

becomes a Nell Gwynn. He

specially enjoys Dryden’s

fine bit of psychology, where

Anthony, forced again to meet

the deserted Cleopatra, Ex

Exclaims “Gods, I thank you:

I formed the danger greater than it was,

and now ’tis near, ’tis lessened”

Michael & Fay get up to betting

a box of chocolates to a

green tie that Duse will

not play little Arthur’s

Tristram.

When the mushrooms come

there is exhortation:

“Hush! No-one is to speak to me

for several moments” – & he

begins to listen. No flavour

is so full of itself as a

mushroom’s.

Fay has been talking to an

Architect, named Wilson, who

has pleased him by realising that

the Greeks & the Japs are the

only two peoples who have lived

for beauty – & the Japs have per-

-sisted for centuries, while the

Greeks were blighted only too

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 87; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 43r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_087.jpg

[E.C.]

quickly.

In the Drawing-Room there is

again betting that Dr Garnett

will dedicate Shakspere, Pedagogue

& Poacher to us.

Then Fay reads Verlaine’s

marvelous Langeur (“Jadis

et Naguère”)

I shall always hear his voice,

low as an underground

rillet – now & then with

petulant emphasis – as it

gave:

“O n'y vouloir, o n'y pouvoir mourir

un peu!

Ah, Tout est bu, toute est mangé – plus

rien à dire.”

And again:

“L'Ame seulette a mal au coeur d'un

ennui dense”

And the massive first line

becomes of fate, yet altogether

personal, in his convinced

voice –

“Je suis l'Empire à la fin de la décadence.”

Fay says this poem is that rarest

thing, that had only been known

in English & Italian, a Dramatic

Sonnet, as Browning wrote Dramatic

Lyrics. Michael grieves Browning

never found the Dramatic Sonnet.

Rossetti has several examples. Fay

hates specially the exquite exquisite repetitions

– A special charm in Verlaine – & the even

more wonderful diminutive “Seulette”.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 88; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 43v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_088.jpg

[E.C.]

We end the Evening by an hour

with Bernhard’s Italian Florentine

Drawings – specially the Leonardo

Drawings & the Michael Angelo

Drawings.

Fay keeps wandering nearer

& nearer as Shannon & I

look – then he stands

over us, pouring[?] into

Shannon’s ear the wondrous

story of how this figure is

for that picture &c. Always

he judges by quality

of draughtsmanship or

modelling – the life

under the bodily forms,

the life of the line.

They both agree with me

the youth with Curls,

& the face of the Louvre

Bacchus, is no Leonardo –

& Fay holds that the attribution

of the Pieta of Michael

Angelo to Piombo165 is a howler.

Nearly as bad is the ascription

of the Casa Buonarrotti166Mother

& Child to Bugiardini – the

supreme masterpiece of

child-modelling! These out-

cast Michael Angelos are of

the Master’s very essential

might; the trouble seems to

be that Bernhard seems to

have⟨has⟩ gone initially wrong

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 89; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 44r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_089.jpg

[E.C.]

on Michael Angelo, because he

takes him on the side of the

Windsor Drawings, wh:, if

genuine, are fluffy & in-

essential in technique, &

not by his salient

& inapproachable work

in black & white.

When the Artists hear that

Bernhard is coming to England

simply to see us, Shannon

maintains this is the excuse.

He does not like Land’s End

& remembers the Calais

passage.

Ah, so deeply have I been involved

with the doom[?] of our Edomite. I

have not written a word of

Mary’s letter from Washington

Feb. 18th that undoes all the

harshness of the letter that

struck the last night in the old

year. She writes

“Dearest Michael,

Your letter was a perfect joy – no, I

can’t possibly tell you how the Doctrine

& I enjoyed it, nor how we hope you

have, by this time ‘happy feet’! [ Michael

had said she thought as she was buying

new stockings ‘What is the use of stockings

for feet that are not happy? ]167… Our

feet are happy for we are turning East

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 90; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 44v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_090.jpg

[E.C.]

again. Logan says we must bring

home something equivalent to

Columbus’ cocoanuts & parrots to

show that an[?] America really

exists – the wonderful, genial,

tolerant, growing New World

we have discovered! We shall

bring home a tongueful of things to

tell you at least; & may we

come & tell them some evening,

either the 23 or 24 of March??

For the Doctrine is stopping over

just to see you two, dear Michael

& Field, who mean so much more

to him than you can possibly

know.”

It is curious how crocusy I feel

under the yellow fog, how

white-violety under the

abortive snow-flakes. I

pretend to live with the Muses

& not to notice Aphrodite is

among them.

Friday, March 5

I am in bed sick to misery with

the cold fog. Michael ventures

out to take Grace Worthington[?] on

a visit to the Palace. All the

hollow time of her absence I

read Anatole France’s Histoire

Comique – a secondary book

as all his are, with moments

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 91; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 45r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_091.jpg

[E.C.]

of amazing psychology & sudden

new views opening on humanity.

The haunting Actor-lover is well

Done, & the little Actress herself

has biting traits of personality, while

the situations frankly due to

her temperament are not fantastic.

How naked & unashamed a

French Writer can be in his

story! It prevents one fall – the

sins of stuffiness in a work of

Art. The last scene of the

Nude Acting before Love of the

part that would be dressed before

the World is a fresh piece of

achievement.

Grace was wild with joy that Michael

appeared – she was waiting arid.

A plumed hat, much admired in

America, fresh new gloves, a

whiteness of front had all been

put on that Michael should not

feel ashamed of her at the Palace.

Fay would not let his visitors move

about at first “Not till they we

are a little more used to each

other”. Grace praised the beauty

of Neville Lytton – Fay dispraised

Cockerill “You must not speak

against him – He is in Egypt: he may

be ill” warned Michael mock-heroically

then they talked of Tommy’s child-like

appearance. Then Fay gave the

two notes of the robin – one ordinary,

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 92; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 45v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_092.jpg

[E.C.]

One a divine delight of four notes.

He spoke of the “sour” note

of the swallow. He cannot touch

birds. He babbled very unattachingly

of the Dogs. They so barked he

often almost turned from the

door, till he remembered the

Stone Cream inside.

Grace saw with happy recognition

the Toplady glass pot, still

half-heaped with little love-

apples. “Still alive!” exclaimed

Michael “ – ah, I see, you put

the top on & keep them without

air, like your enemies!”

He showed the Tommy-Pendant, & –

let Day hide its face! – a broach

for Marie – a white bird.

Never will he see my blue bird

again. Like the Bride of the

Riccardi it disappears.

Then the Villain remarks he is sorry

he did not do a more elaborate

pendant for Tommy – a Muse

riding on a Dragon with a Sphinx

behind. Michael claims to see

the design. The Diary is opened –

there among the leaves is the

great, thorny Michaelian Script.

More vital that custody than

the depth of drawer or chest.

The Muse can only be found ‘in

small’ – it was only brought

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 93; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 46r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_093.jpg

[E.C.]

up as a subject with wh: to sting &

blandish Michael. It was designed

some years ago.

[K.B.]

March 12th. Sat.

Tommy’s poem – the Gazelles.

A real poet, a fresh note – Oh to wake

to it!

Desire musing desires sheaf the loved

one’s lap with scented cones, Fir cones!

They remain fir. Good for Tommy.

This morning Henry & I formally give up

“trying[?]” – We will see what mooding

does. No fighting with Satan – no more

giving the least heed to him[?].

– More prayer & creeping up to God –

as if there were no devil – & indeed

can there be where God is.

It has been the sharp[?] fighting that

is not defence, but a sort of ineffective

assculing[?] & striving. Striving is a

mistake. Of a spiritual-teacher, I

should urge absorbing – being interested –

– best of all last.

Of course when there is no echo

Death comes. Death is the unechoing

Herod died[?] of this disease, & not of

worms.

– I ordered a pot of white violets

for Painter. A pot of green leaves arrives

& a name[?]– the White Czar!

So Painter has no blooms[?] – merely

a title. The unreality[?] of things

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 94; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 46v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer, (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_094.jpg

[K.B.]

– the giving one ghosts, when one

wants blood – is changing one

from man to inanimate

I heard the other day blood was

the best nourishment for roses –

– a scripture[?] of life –

– the best for the renewing of the best

March 15th.

To-day Bernhard sails.

My hatred of Fog is becoming cumulative –

everyday 24 hours more hatred.

To-day full of spring scowl. North &

South East, & the cawing of rooks.

I go forth excited even over the

pipless orange & the first English

strawberry.

I buy Devonshire Cream, &

brown, fresh eggs. Heaven sends

me down 2 bunches of grapes[?] by a [????],

white & blue with which to crown

my Loved.

I keep walking in & out. The

River from the garden is silver-

gilded, in a dusky grove.

We are reading Jane Harrison’s

Prolegomena[?]. And as one approaches

the deeper mysteries of one’s own

Christian faith, one gives thanks

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 95; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 47r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_095.jpg

[K.B.]

That it is late, that it says Yea, &

that its mysteries are spiritual.

On an aspic found gliding towards the

seer.

Who art thou, Aspic of the dazzled eyes,

And swaying as a drunkard from his drink?

Seaward thou glidest, in the sea to sink,

A sacred alien, a sacrifice.

Who hath devoted thee? What hast thou done?

that wound is as a jewel ’mid thy scales;

thy forkèd tongue still tenderly assails.

As some amazing honour thou hadst won,

As thou went stricken by too vast a doom,

And to the gods must recommend my plight,

Thou foamest through the sand. Back to a tomb

I follow thy fresh steps. Ah, there in sight

the golden spindle that devised thy wound,

And Cleopatra marvelously swooned.

Tuesday March 15th. (Bernhard sails) 1904.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 96; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 47v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_096.jpg

[K.B.]

Saturday March 19th

A rain as of April has fallen –

Hennie’s heart is broken to Herod.

We work together; Bernhard is on the

high seas, Fuk[?]Shope[?], is still reading

his Sonnet, & the clothes of spring

have been arriving post on post.

I am happy after an arid, desperate

week.

One afternoon I recall.

It is Wednesday, &, as one abandoned

of hope I am curled up on my bed

-room sofa, reading Jane Harrison’s

Prolegomena of Ethics ⟨Greek Religion⟩. A bee-hit – & the

gods are tossed over as nine-pins,

while I wrestle into my Albrect Dürer

gown.

The talk is chiefly of Don Giovanni –

but in truth we meet to wail.

With Painter it is a season of

absolute barrenness – he is lying low.

I tell him I shall say to Bernhard

“There is not a sign of him” left, “Not

a sign” he murmurs, “When Bern-

-hard is by – I am in eclipse.”

I amuse him from a heart, dropping

like a stalactite-cave.

O Child of Helène, Cornelie[?], Pia[?], Decclata –

What place is there for you in this

world?

I tell him Shife[?] he is come to say

good-bye before starting for Italy. –

No, he is only come to say it is the only day

this week he can come. the minutia –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 97; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 48r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_097.jpg

[K.B.]

The microbes of clothingness are eating him up.

I cannot write of him . . I should not

mind unhappiness or hardship for him

– I cannot watch him fall into disuetude.

I have sent him mignonette & forget-me-nots

& “Image & Superscription”, & I have written

comfortable words …

But this kettle of fish, with the live

eels leaping about in their agony,

is too much for me.

One or two friends, his peers, a little

fame, consciousness of “a welling up”

–– & the threat of poverty withdrawn – wd.

so change him – my Publisher, who

must roam the earth a Poet!

[E.C.]

Yes, there is strangeness about Fay –

he seems blank as an unsown

plough-field; & yet there is bustle

about him of endless en-

-gagements & fritter … But

the mystery! He is not in

the World – in Society – Philanthropy,

Business … With what

Keres has he then engagements?

He says he has been reading

interesting books, & when we

question he binds his brow with

his hands & recalls nothing,

with a willowy, ghost-like

laugh.

He really warns Michaels against

writing a play on Don Juan

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 98; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 48v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_098.jpg

[E.C.]

when she shall have heard

the story from him – “It would

not suit her – it is strictly

copyright”. Then as if

playing a last card he

tells all the mad rigmarole

of the libretto – chuckling

over its formal bits of

Eighteenth Century “business”

& humour – sliding

lissome eyes down the

discreet innuendo, or

unabashed follies of

the plot, & ending on a

note of veritable awe

at the grip of the Stone

Hand.

He sees a play – I do

not – Opera & Satire seem

to me to exhaust the

story. I suggest “Does he

mean a Moral Play in

a few scenes, like Maeterlinck’s

Beatrice; in wh: the first

unrepented sin of a man

becomes his eventual

doom & death warrant?” No –

he would make a play

of manners, like Measure

for Measure.

Michael tells him the story of little

Florrie[?], who questioned her father

one Sat. night “Dada, have[?] you

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 99; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 49r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_099.jpg

[E.C.]

got the chocolate for me?” & when

forgetfulness was confessed

by Dada, sent remarked “Then

you’d better go for it at once,

before you forget again” – adding

when he reached the door

“I have noticed you don’t[?]

think so much of your

Baby lately” Of course he

flew for the chocolate, with

such perfect womanhood

ordering & pleading from

the tiny bed. Fay was

enchanted.

Then wicked Michael told of Dara L.’s

remark, after she had praised

Shannon’s beauty, his sweet

mouth (“He hasn’t got one at

all” interpolates Fay) & turned

to Fay’s own portrait “He is

exactly like a Mr Wright, who

taught me drawing 30 years ago;

& very like a clergyman I

used to know”.

At the end Michael, pointing to

her velvet stomarcher, asks

“Do you know what this demands?”

“No – ”

“A Cochon d’Or” ___ & he flies.

“Mind you remember Mr to

tell Shannon of the drawing-

master of 30 years ago.” So Michael

harasses the flight. “Let me see – Wright

that’s the name!” “Yes – 30 years ago!”

- - - & he is gone.

Notebook 18, Page Image 100; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 49v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_100.jpg

[E.C.]

Saturday – March 19th

After sultry days of inner

sand & East-wind outside

a ripple of life – Herod

is alive – there is fire in

the heart & ⟨a⟩ long the roads

& bridges of the brain.

All the scenes, all the

situations are ductile

again – one can win[?]

them from their source,

& follow their interaction.

Then tonight comes a letter

from Fay – greatly thanking

Michael for flowers & Sonnet

“Mr Wright that is Mr All-

Right thanks you greatly – &

likes it (the sonnet) very much

as a poem – in fact as much

as a likeness”

“Only the Ear is bright”

might lead to immediate recognition

on[?] the part of the public (He

always seems to see his

Sonnets printed!)

“Mr Wright’s friend (Ireland’s only

hope) is also appreciative though

he read out the title of the piece

as “Image & Superstition”

Then comes the usual plaint “I

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 101; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 50r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_101.jpg

[E.C.]

am writing in a dazed condition,

having spent the morning in

letters of evasion & excuse” –

to what Keres?

“Small, tiresome events have been so

thick of late that I think my

star just now is “with the

Russians’.”

Tommy has had a two-column Review

in the Times Suppliment – very

welcoming, not ungenially

laden with blame, as most

reviews are now.’ We have

sent it to Rome, marking

the judgement “He lives too much

with painters”.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 102; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 50v; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_102.jpg

[E.C.]

March 23rd Wednesday.

It is a now afternoon, & we are

expecting Bernhard168 this

evening. The Rooms are

full of lilies, & keenly

red roses, & growing

purple crocuses & the

ice-crevice -white azalias.

Outside the East & North

discourse of futility &

disillusion, while the

river wells up into

wavelets that press turbulently.

Before me is the wonder

at mortality & Eros in

their possible fusion.

I feel such a congeries

of dust, that I cannot

conceive of myself as

in relation with the

immortal God of fire

& life. I am faded with

springtide & with the tide

of time. I feel as dust.

And he too – the beloved –

is a little thing of dust &

of the years that pass;

& yet there is a god between

us, & all our atoms of

dust, our moments of time,

do not discourage the Immortal.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 103; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 51r; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_103.jpg

[E.C.]

On Sunday little Dodge, who came to

hear Tommy’s Gazelles169 read,

told us that B.170 was not expected.

On Monday Michael going to

Miss Toplady’s171 heard B. was

not expected, & broke into

torrent of wrath . . . Then in

stepped Logan172 & announced

“Well, they are here, as large

as life” – “Is B. come too” –

“Yes – I can’t think what for.

He is only coming for two days.”

My beloved hoped to tell

me the birthday of my Love

had come – but just before

her arrival a telegram came

from Mary. “Wednesday,

with so much pleasure”.

Yesterday Michael went to the

palace to enlighten Fay’s173

Eclipse, bearing a box of

lustrous purples crocuses – I

never saw such quarry;

they looked like shining

young stags in a heap.

Who else would sickle

crocuses thus in their sleek

abundance . . . And Fay had

gone, his fellow did not know

where – thought to Richmond.

He had not turned up to lunch.

It made us most down-hearted

& anxious last night, & lay

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 104; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 51v; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_104.jpg

[E.C.]

heavy on going to sleep. However

as we have heard nothing

& Shannon174 thought he had

come here we conclude all

is well. Dear Fay – for him

to disappear even for a few

hours is like a mistake

of the sun or stars.

Mary175 & B. are to go to tea

at the Palace tomorrow.

I must go & dress – the

rooms await Eros; the

congeries of dust is still

unadorned for the

visitation.

When we come down dressed,

the river was⟨is⟩ silver, grown

into a strength, silver on

the march & on ‘war-footing’.

I never have seen such an

attractive flood.

It is obscured all too soon –

the lilies swept on long stems

the frizzled radiance of their

flowering over⟨in front of⟩ the flood.

It was marvellous.

A voice at the door! “No – it is

not Bernhard. – Some-one bearing

a parcel” – The door opens . . .

but the voice was his! He comes

alone. Mary has had a delayed

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 105; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 52r; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_105.jpg

[E.C.]

attack of sea-sickness. We are very

sorry – her jollity would have

transfused blood into the

meeting. From the first I feel

he is God-forsaken – a little

desecrated shrine. There is no

God to meet. My heavy

premonition is tragically justified.

At dinner he burst out into

silly blasphemies, Michael bravely

stems, while Lillias176boils behind

me. Nothing makes me more

angry than this profane attacking

⟨of religion⟩in general talk at table – it

ought to be impossible – bad

form. Of course one forgets nightly

there are servants in the room

when the thousand things of

converse flash & more: but there

is one thing that should never

be treated with contempt in

their presences, because they are

bound to be silent – & that is

religion. It is noble manners to

humanity to remember this.

All Bernhard says is of that the f[?]

kind that comes near to

braying. “That cut-purse, that

unspeakable Cad – the chosen

of God – your psalmist David” – is

a mild specimen. By the way

he speaks of Herod as another

David – another Chosen of God –

When we try to turn the subject

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 106; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 52v; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_106.jpg

[E.C.]

of the Bible & introduce Josephus.

Bernhard is an American –

convinced, but not (as Michael

wittily puts it) infectious.

He has with a certain wisdom,

that has overdeveloped into

infatuation, tried to get the

best out of the men he has

met – the gigantic pork-

-butchers & cold-storers & c

– till they have become

“The eponymous heroes” of

America – indeed, they have

become America. It is silly

as it would be to call

our indispensable Cook

Paragon.

He never wearied of their financial

marshalling of their facts –

he could have listened for

months & years. There was

friendship too among them –

Achilles & Patroclus could have

been seen in the pork-butcheries.

There is no rippling of conversation

– only a dull current – &

Bernhard looks dusky, like

a golden lad who, like a

chimney-sweeper, has is come

to dust. Where is the light

of him?

He is only ‘life-enhancing’ on the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 107; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 53r; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_107.jpg

[E.C.]

subject of Ricketts’ 177 Art. He realises

that Ricketts, like all real

artists, has themes in the forces

that condition his art – that

he is illuminated to treat

in the great manner the

pressure & recoil of human

bodies, with the ⟨a⟩ resulting

rhythm – the Samaritan, the

Centaur, the Entombment

are all variations on

the great laws of repose

pressure & resistance.

And being therefore elemental

in theme, they are important

as a drawings by Leonardo

are important.

Bernhard seems to be desirous

of attaching Fay; I cannot

help suspecting, in this swell

of appreciation the meshes of

a drag-net. He is the man

who counts as a spiritual

force on this side the channel.

B. seems a gorged little thing –

no charming words about

the roses, the lilies, the dainty

cates that almost cost us

ruin on a month of the year.

No heart-felt word on health

or happiness! Yet nothing

inimical – only a friendlessness

of soul. At dinner he

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 108; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 53v; Andrew Walt, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_108.jpg

[E.C.]

says he does not come to eat,

but to talk – “I would go anywhere

to talk” & I feel how futile to

say so. There can be no

talk after; & there is not. “I

am giving you an American

evening” he sighs out, as

if dissatisfied. Just for a

short space, when left alone,

I tell him of my pleasure

in his chapter & notes, on

Leonardo, & my appreciation

of the more restive & athletic

style of the Michael Angelo. And

I tell him of touches I

have given to his most

enticing & personal sentences.

We are warmer a moment –

a gulf-stream just fringes our

apartness – no more. Even

then he says with dusky

petulance “You know, Field,

I am a great person in

America”.

I cry when he is gone.

If it is tragic for a God to

take on human limits – it

is abjectly painful for a

man to keep his poor limits

& not take on some deity.

He goes through the door a

small, trim man; & therefore

full of disappointment to

himself & to others. He is dust –

he is trivial. I have seen him once too often.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 109; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 54r; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_109.jpg

[K.B.]

March 24th.

He has lost all power of mood. All

atmosphere is withdrawn. One would

suffocate if one entered into his soul as a

dog suffocates in a Lethal Chamber. His eyes

are worse than blind – They are there, not

perceiving. He has drunk of the sweetness

of adulation, of the bitterness of spite;

for inspiration he believes the pork-butchers

are making the world go. Poor little Bernhard!

God has to bear all this from us; but this

Easter we will try to offer Him Souls, as

fresh & welcomed as a bit ofwormful[?]

turf to a pris lark!

Palm Sunday

March 27th.

We have provided our palm-seedling[?]

aforehand. We have put them

away, for they stink.

But I feel soft & open toward the

world where these feasts are

kept – I read hymns – hymns

that bring before me the brows

– the seas of the dead – I read

Herrick’s 178 “Sweet Spirit Comfort me”179

there is fog outside, & even the birds

forget to cry out.

Day of sweet blessedness & triumph –

I bless it still with its ⟨tossed⟩thyrsi[?] & lifted[?]

hearts.

Yesterday I visited Mary lying in

dazzling white silk, & face as dazzling,

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 110; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 54v; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_110.jpg

[K.B.]

After 24 hours [ delayed ]180 sea-sickness.

Ricketts was going to call on her,

yesterday afternoon.

Janet and I assist at Yeats’181 play

“The King’s Threshold.” To my

surprise the lovely, clear verse comes

flowing up to me in the back rows

of the dress-circle.

Only Yeats, I think, could have

made that scene of the poet lying

starving on the steps, not ridiculous

the cumulative force of the speech⟨poet⟩ is

very strong. The lover’s kiss will

be more fervent & more golden for

his resistance, in ages to come –

but there should not be a petty[?]

triumph at the end.

He should starve & die in his

Misery – the king perhaps visit

him a little shudderingly ⟨after death⟩, & with

orders for a great funeral.

There is sufficient force in “182 the Defence

of Poetry183 for one to be sure of the issue –

Helen Fry184, magnificent, was there

moving about – on another plane.

Bernhard185 was there – a dusk &

dusty fly. Old Archer crossed

me, a genial[?] of other years.

I return & read to my Beloved

with something of the sustained

cadence I have heard, the whole

play.

The other two plays are unclassed.

[K.B.]

Monday, March 28th.

But this is the gay Fairy man of

years ago! He knows I wanted him

“to run down the Lamb,” & to discuss

the Irish plays. Mary is like the earth

or the sea, – very comely, a little crude.

Bernhard was very polite at the palace186;

but he is christened “Wopsie-Topsie”,

& one feels that the apparition of 94187

has been caught.

Yeats’s play is clean, & very Greek –

the poet of course should have died

& the people of the court should have

shown a great coldness to the king

after his death ⟨(Yeats’ chief actor)⟩3Fay’s acting impressed

Painter.188 Tommy189 has been rebuked in

a letter for dealing as he has with so

great a gentleman as Don Juan.

The mood of trouble has passed from

Painter, & the frolic of a breeze is

round him, as a halo.

Wednesday in Holy Week

From a letter to Amy7190

“And now ha’done, for I want

some fun. I am feeling very

happy in my spirit, & the hail

and the thunder can’t hurt me. This

Paragon191 looks so sweet. It is

decked with pots of azalea, & the

growing, living flowers bring

the Blessed near. Then my Painter

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 112; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 55v; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_112.jpg

[K.B.]

was[?] very wonderful on Monday, & this

morning I have the picture of him

ringed – matter of triumph to any

woman to have ringed that perfect

hand – more to have been poet to those

grave, Southern eyes. Henry192 says

with truth his eyes in their gravity

are as sunless olive-groves.

And now no more. I cannot

write at all these great Feast

times – but do “oo” write, & give my

love & blessing to John[?], & let us hear

of the parlours & Alice”

[E.C.]

Painter’s visit is delicious – It

has greatly enlivened him

to dish ‘the Lamb’ with

much mint sauce. I cannot

help admiring the touch of

crisp ridicule in his pose toward

his rival. The way in

wh: he says he was getting

on beautifully with Mrs Mary

when ‘Wopsy’193 came in from

the play is a masterpiece

of sleight-of-wit.

He gives a sportive & adulterous

airiness of suggestion that

is mirth-provoking. Yet

his real gravity of judgment,

for when he judges he is

serious as Minos194, is shown

in his phrase, ‘Mary has

diminished Bernhard – This is

[Page]

[E.C.]

greatly observed, because Mary

impresses him as so large &

buoyant in herself. But a

grea⟨large⟩ sea-shore of wind

& salt & sun does not always

cultivate our fineness or

the reaches of our sympathies.

Logan he is interested in — he is

like the Liftman, who died

because Michael did not

recognise he was a sonneteer.

B. came to the Palace in a ‘topper’ –

this was offensive: he put it

down on a satinwood table,

under flowers specially arranged

to irritate him, – this was

more offensive. He was questioned

on America, so as to give the

replies he didn’t want to; then

was taken round, & made the

artists richer by assuring them

a drawing they held in question

was a real Andrea del Sarto195.

Fay196 finds him elaborate, & in

mind, rather “sleepy”. He diag-

nosed him as shrewd rather

than intelligent – slow in his

judgment. But, of course, we

all know the real Bernhard

is far away, not in America,

but in a long cloud-land

journey.

As soon as Fay comes into the

[Page]

[E.C.]

grot he exp⟨exclaims⟩ “What a

He quite adores the lacquered

little piece of 1820-30. He is

& mint sauce’ make the

Painter’s heart gay

Fay remarked that Yeats’ second

the two kinds of music

that is like a woman’

made him quite uncomfortable.

There are aesthetic mistakes

that strike one as improper

– & one glances at the ladies.

Bernhard, coming back from

Yeats’ play, after some demur

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 115; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 57r; Wendy Walter, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_115.jpg

[E.C.]

& hedging, admitted he felt he had

been present at the birth of

a new something new.

Fay noted the Greek directness of

Yeats . . I attribute it to his

having drawn, like the Greek

Dramatists his subject from

Epical sources – where narrative

is direct.

We show Fay La Jeunesse de

Balzac198 – the frank portrait of

his bursting youth. Balzac Fay

almost hates – except his Contes

Drolatiques.199 In these he finds

a quintessence stronger in its

imaginative force than Cervantes200

or Rabelais201compassed[?].

It is a new creation in a sphere

where there is so little novelty.

Fay agrees that the actor Fay,

who directs the Irish Theatre is

one of the best alive, in spite

of amateur-training.

Fay shrinks from writing to Yeats

lest he should call – His presence

is disquieting – there is something

paralytic about it. And it is

so tiresome to hear him talk about

“po-etry” & wave his hands

round it

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 116; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 57v; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_116.jpg

[K.B.]

Good Friday –

A dazzling day – almost it

glitters as on the classic-Good

Friday morning when I paused from

my hoop[?] – & felt in the air endless burr[?],

the sky & ecstasy. It is a pure spring

day, & even the first little catastrophe

in thibet[?] cannot damp it.

Talk of swallows – When the first

little flotilla of boats lies on the surface

of the Thames then[?] to our waterside

There is spring.

We have spent the day very simply.

We read of Christ’s parting with his mother,

& the "It is finished", &, after breakfast,

Henry asked for my two Good Friday

Sonnets. We have been busy with a

scene of Mariamne – the⟨her⟩ last.

And I have written 4 lines of the

second Sonnet on Painter’s202 picture.

But what is the Beloved to behold

More than another? – He is pure

As substances that grain on grain endure,

As ambergris eternal in its gold.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 117; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 58r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_117.jpg

[K.B.]

Easter Day.

We give each other, not eggs, – fine

cigarettes & liquid ambergris.

– We wake in the dream-bed room

there are green-bay leaves on Father's

altar, & we turn to look at the portraits

of the parents.

We speak much of the ideal qualities

in Father, how Henry’s genius is from

him – And I drop into recollection of

the dismay my family experienced –

– & the congregation of the Church of

the Savior, & all who knew &

reverenced her that Emma Bradley203

should marry one so unworthy

of her. Well, he was worthy of in heart,

& infinitely finer in endowment.

He had brain; Henry's brain, & a

consciousness of unused power.

He made himself absurd to our

stupid ears by declaring he could

astonish us in preaching, or writing.

Alas, no: with us the eloquence, the

tongue – as the Euphrates in its abundance –

he could not speak; he could fashion.

Mother – the very bloom & flower of

religion – seemed no fitting bride for the

old-fashioned countryman with his

traditional faith & manners. Once

[????] – in a glow over some ⟨evidence⟩trait of

acumen in Edith – said "But with a

A Mother like Emma, the Bradleys VP[?]."

“But Emma married[?]no[?]fool[?]" was

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 118; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 58v; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_118.jpg

[E.C.]

The portrait of Fay204 is a wonderful

thing. It is Pan – the eyes

know the true[?] secrets of the universe

so intimately, they caress &

fondle them – are lazy with

them, ⟨are⟩ amused.

And the lips close as if at

rest from a shout, or a

syrinx[?] – some of the startling

sounds that make us

aware of secrets or create

them in our blood. There

is a touch that is grim

in the soft undulance –

something disconcerting

& of the power of austerity

in the midst of suppleness.

That month is closed, because

the god is under a cavern in

the efficiency of his contemplation.

He dents his cheek with one

finger & gathers up his jaw

in a hand that supports the

world as easily as Atlas’

neck.

One feels the ears must crenulate

into leaves – so much the

hearing will be extraordinary,

as in the alleys of a forest –

and even the month prepares

one for the goat's beard – the

malice of it is a little heady, there

is the touch of roughness, that

is solitary, in its civil, star-

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 119; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 59r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_119.jpg

[E.C.]

charmed quiet.

One could beat him with squills

so heartily, if opposed to one –

& then run a g away as if

a phantom made you ⟨one⟩ cold.

Yet he is too balanced to be

Tragic – he sits in his cave

& thinks, not of catastrophes

but of consolations, till his

eyes grown gentle & have

entertainment in them.

Pan – with complexion like

the air in sensitiveness

of life – Pan who can be

boisterous & ⟨can be⟩ evocative as

an upland pipe – always

mysterious, on watch, not

to be resisted. Pan whom a

poet has ringed.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 120; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 59v; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_120.jpg

[K.B.]

Easter-Day continued

– the deserved retort.

We speak of emotion – of our own

fitness for each other. Without me

Henry says, you would have been no

poet.” "Yes," – Longfellow.” Henry says

emotion grows could through contact

with the air: emotion must be from

the bubbling cauldrons within

He says how he & Fay have cleaned

my genius – that Fay has cleaned it,

as with emery powder.

I am able to spring out of bed, &

read “Christ the Lord is risen to-day”

from the old hymn-book. Henry

repeats "Christ ist erstanden"

& I read "Christ on passover is

sacrificed for us, therefore let us

reap the feast.

Now I commit Henry to Heaven's

care in the perilous hour of her

communion with the dead.

I should not like to meet her

that way, nor do I believe the

attempt would prosper; side by

side – the chink[?] of two oboli – & one

boat – that is my prayer for us.

– the first taste of the real life together

– the wonder in each other’s eyes –

my Easter prayer.

We have bay – bay triumphant over

each altar – Victory!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 121; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 60r; Ayah Hamed Falatah, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_121.jpg

[K.B.]

–and on Easter-even I rowed [?] across to fetch

black poplar from the other side.

– black poplar for the mother.

She has received it & I am blessed.

The growing crocus is in the boxes,

– ⟨in⟩& the ⟨grot the⟩ little couch[?] of rest.

– the crocus & the poppy are both flowers

I could have migrated into, & the

impatient poppy most of all.

There is nothing inhuman in this Easter

Day of spring-gale & sunshine.

We hear[?] the rooks in their nookiness[?]

as they caw, life is so excellent; we

give thanks for life; & for redeemed

life – life made holy in its very blood –

we give thanks.

-

“What is thy Beloved more than another Beloved”

But what is thy Belovèd to behold

More than another? – He is pure

As substances that grain on grain endure,

As ambergris eternal in its gold.

More wonderful & in aloofness bold.

His looking forth, more sensuously sure

than Pan's when from great caverns that immure

He looks abroad with all his flocks to fold.

More than another he is beautiful,

Nor is there any balm that gathereth

His sweetness up, or flower that you can pull:

From his own ecstasy he incenses

Even as a camel feeding on myrrh-trees. Finished205

Blows from his nostrils aromatic wreath Easter-Even

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 122; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 60v; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_122.jpg

[K.B.]

April 7th.

There was a Spanish heat-

wave yesterday. For a few hours

Loved & I walked to & fro in the sunshine.

To-day extreme scowl & flutter of wind:

Henrie curled up by the fire.

I have sent a chocolate Easter Fish

for little Dolly (the blind woman's

child of the Norfolk family.)

Mrs. [????] writes her thanks for

Dolly's nice fish. ''I wish you could

have seen her. O my pensent[?]. She

claspt her little hands danse

jumpt about when that came

& my word we were as pleased

as the child. I had to take her

to Grandfather. He laugh till the

water ran down his face.''

Infinite jest of the chocolate fish! We

have brought tears of mirth to an

old man's eyes – & our own run

down with laughter!

A child at the zoo said '' Tiger, look at

me''. At last she threw into the den her

own infinitely precious Easter egg.

The tiger pushed out a paw – no egg, but

a shriek that waved its way even

to the monkey-house.

Frances Power Cobbe206 died on Tuesday

April 5 th. A very brave, a very gallant

woman. But for the sake of the most

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 123; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 61r; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_123.jpg

[K.B.]

precious things of the spirit, for the sake of the

Saveur of the vines, and the fragrant substances

of earth. One must make protest against

her. First of all – born as every Woman

is to be man's helpmate – She hated man ⟨(as man)⟩, &

boasted that she had not been desired of him,

or desiring. She did not produce flower

or fruit after her kind.

May she energise in Mars somewhere!

– perhaps – there among the canals she will

do less harm!

Extract from letter to Amy.

– ''You have never made the tears

roll down Grandfather's face! Our

reward has been a black bird's nest,

with four blue, spotted eggs. Our re-

-turn eggs; & clear sweet throated Dickie

feeling suddenly choky in his singing –

for his beautifully-built cottage, & those

four mysterious little music-books

all gone.”

April 9th

The languor, the melancholy of the spring

– My mind is an almanach full of the

probabilities of low tides. I calculate every

morning the possible extent of my

tenure – How long this machine will be

to me – Life as it might be, seems so

attractive in age, & the drinking of the air

so sweet! It is the season of the Spring

that searches & gripes!

In the autumn I feel contemporaneous –

like a nice, ripe plum. In the Spring – like a

goose-berry flower, dropping ⟨turning⟩ off.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 124; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 61v; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_124.jpg

[E.C.]

April 8

Such primroses from Janet Dodge!

I have written:

A fresh & immediate note of thanks

for the primroses, dear Janet.

Among the difficult Arts of

Beautiful Living the Art

of gathering & presenting primroses

is scarcely ever learnt. Janet

is perfect in it. One usually

receives primroses with a sense

of nervous prostration, such

as a picture-gallery produces;

& with an inarticulate hatred

for the giver. But I lift out of

an orderly box little separate

nosegays, their tender stems,

that always make me think

of the feet of Arab girls that

have the heels & nails flushed

with henna, all ready to be

dipped in water. I bring out

the great ivory Leeds bowl,

I set the primroses' feet to

shine under its deep bath; &

there are the primroses in their

orient yellow, giving out their

languid perfume. – sweet girls,

but not to me of the West.

I bless Janet & so will Michael

when she returns from town.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 125; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 62r; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_125.jpg

[K.B.]

April 13 th

April is with us – the river sucks like

a young babe.

White rooted violets are come to us –

violets that look their scent. We hear

of the Manor Garden a sheet of violets

daffodils.

I frolic with the small leaves.

I write to Louie[?] who wanted us

to visit her Rugcite[?] Cottage on Saturday.

''Why do Widows always spoil one's

happiness?'' as the widow's Son

remarked, licking the oil from his

lips, when restored to life by Elijah.''

On the Priory Park from Gray's[?] letter.

''this morning Babs & I paced slowly &

reverently as if in church over the

Priory ridge – the old monks paced there

of old-feeling the same silence – the same

music too – the heavenly choir of larks

vying with each other in their sweet

sopranos – a lowing cow in the distance

chanting the amens in bass, a

chanticleer further off, still with a contralto

solo – trying to put out the larks. At our feet

little, wild strawberries in blossom, &

small wood violets. I have taught

Babs not to pick wild flowers & c.”

Monday, April 18th

Henry has been ill since Friday with a

strange, & most disquieting numbness

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 126; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 62v; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_126.jpg

[K.B.]

in her lower limbs. On Saturday, the Doctor.

“The thing is superficial, but mysterious, &

it creeps. It is like a growing tide.

Panic seizes me, not in the superficies;

Henry trembles.

On Sunday Henry is in bed all day. The

widow & Tommy – These adverse souls –

encounter at supper. What is that “lilac

boss[?]” the widow asks of the ring?

''And what is the loose emerald for?'' to

look bright and to run about'' – retorts Tommy

tartly . .

The widow reports Tommy ''quite satisfied''

but there is more than quite satisfied in

the deeply-beaming face. He does not

speak of Marie she is present as fresh

verdure to his Soul – a ⟨fresh⟩ gentle, human

element discernible already in his

ways & words, especially the way he

flaps his soul.

He is soundly the same to us

Of Monday April 18 th

Painter comes in response to command.

I am still in tumult of anxiety – concerning Henry.

Painter speaks of the 1st act of Sabbatai.

He has liked the beginning of Act I – the

scene with the Spirit.

I read to him 2 sonnets – averring

that one of them is addressed to Tommy.

He vows he will punish that Sonnet.

Afterwards he remarks in reference to a

fine simile – Tommy is like a camel.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 127; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 63r; Samah Damanhoori, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_127.jpg

[K.B.]

It is now Wednesday – my dear one is growing

better.

''We welcome each rebuff

That turns the smoothness rough.'' &

even a corn that dances is hailed[?].

Yes, Henry is better & the tips of everything

exquisite: the garden wall-flowers, grape-

hyacinths, fritillaries, auriculas.

Pols.[?] Newman on May Day (Sunday)

May Day. & Milton-May[?] 1904

Morning

Never hasting[?] Paragon greeted the

May with such pride. The air

of the garden is sweet with gilly-

-flowers. There are fritillaries, red

& white daisies, pansies, forget-me-nots

& tulips on the beds.

There is Henry …

The wide, fragrant leaves lie in the sun,

& that is how I feel.

I have written little in this fortnight

Henry has been busy fighting the Devil

at his nerve-ends. I have been

helping. His illness is, I believe,

for the strengthening of our wills.

&, if we have grace to use if so, will

infinitely enrich us.

Last Friday Painter dined with us.

He came fagged, & angry; & gradually

recovered & grew young.

He was full of enthusiasm over

[Page]
