Congreve’s play. The Way of the World.

Mr. Wright full of force & blood-power.

[E.C.]

Illness & Convalescence

On Thursday April 14 th I went

to the Manor House207 & had

delight with Jan208 & Amy209 in their

sheets of double-daffodils

in the Knarled old garden –

now a town garden, stranded

among trams & rail-lines,

with all its gold flowers,

its fruit-buds, its bowls

of Persian-lilac-trees, dusk

with coming clusters – its

glowing new gravel, with

worth £15.

The return journey was hot,

as if lined with thunder, &[?]

Michael & I were sundered

at Kew-Bridge. She assisted

an old lady in a wedding

garment of gray satin, on to

the platform – Puff! The train

glided off & I saw a face like

a wind-tossed rose, under the

black hat with its plumes of

white & matching them the

reef of the dear white teeth.

However we were soon re-united –

but we did not like the severance;

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 129; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 64r; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_129.jpg

[E.C.]

it had suffering for us.

All day I had had numb feet –

I had passed a pumice-stone

over the soles the night before

to make them whiter (o foolish!)

& at night I was over-heated.

Next day the numbness grew –

it was like the Shroud in

Rossetti’s King’s Tragedy210 – from

ankles it rose to knees, then

to loins. In panic I sent on

Sat. for the Doctor, & breathed

again when I heard that the

anaesthesia would not affect

the heart (on Monday I had

been for a too long day in Town

& standing in Sloane Square

banished from the Tube by the

fatal air & unable to settle

a way home I had felt the

remoteness of collapse). The

dismal man said my case was

“very unusual” – nice comfort for

the stricken Michael.

I felt like a cold dead body from

the waist – the rest of me like a

disembodied Spirit held by the

leg to its corpse. The weather

was lovely spring-tide – sun sprang

out of the trees & behold there were

rays & sparkles that were living

leaves. The softness, that is

the circumstance of growth, ruled

the temper of the hours & time.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 130; Vol XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 64v; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_130.jpg

[E.C.]

My beloved gathered round me

tulips blowing forth like roses.

Amy brought me the very red

rose of June.

I had an excited sense of

panic – Continually, like

a general on the field I had

to give responsible orders to

my unfeeling limbs.

Bed after three days seemed

to do no good – Only when

I first got up did the

gaunt queerness of my

state make me weep

at first. The fatigue of

that generalship! Should

I always be at the point

of battle? Should I never

let the will act unconsciously

I could make my unfeeling

feet dance – but the dance

was to me that of winter

thistle-down.

Cheer quickly came back – Were

not the windows rimmed with

white fritillarias in front of a

mist of grape-hyacinths? Did

not the river look bright as a

snake in his new skin?

Amy came & we had two or three

happy sisterly meetings. Fay211

came & brought snow-flakes.

Sir George Douglas212 & Tommy213 conversed

with Michael below & I heard their

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 131; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 6793, fol. 65r; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_131.jpg

[E.C.]

histories. On Friday Feb April 21st

Fay spent six hours with us.

He came chafed – but handsome.

Every inch of moulding caressed

by the breezy rain, a start of life

in every end of hair.

We laughed & let him rage.

“I want to say very nice things”

he protested “& soon he was

good & entertained us on

Congreve’s Way of the World214 –

Unfortunately my memory could

bear no tax at all – The

delightful things he said are

in the bridge-less limbo.

And he was long discoursing

on Anatole France’s Mannequin

d’Osier215 – on its infinite civilization.

He finds the characters touched

with an infinite conception of

temperament. These qualities

make him read Anatole – not –

as a great writer, but as a finely

modern one. The moment when

M. Bergeret lifts his hat to Mme

Grimace is a mile-stone of

progress.

Fay is for prescribing Shakespeare’s

comedies to us in place of the

Bible. That is primitive in style –

the Comedies full of the lightness

& ease of Culture. His tongue seemed

to dance as he talked of Love’s Labour

Lost – even of The Two Gentlemen.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 132; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 65v; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_132.jpg

[E.C.]

The painter, who came like a naughty

boy, left (having lost one late

train) restored to Panship –

auriculas & great white-

shouldered fritilleries in

his hand.

Amy Bell216 (Waterloo) came

next day – a pleasant

visit. Amy amplifies

detail, till the air is soft

with what would be hard

fact with a lesser woman.

And on Sunday Louie Ellis217

& Ysoude[?] came early, carrying

from town, for my sake, a

great Longiflorum Lily.

I set it against the fritillarias

& the river-grain. It makes

a tapistry Morris218 could

not have woven. Henry

Havelock Ellis sends word

that there is no peril in my

state – it is frequent with

brain-workers & will go.

Such encouragement!

This last week Amy has been

again; Shannon has been

expected & failed as usual.

My Love has been to town & heard

Leigh read the great scene in

Othello with vibrant passion

centred profoundly.

We read the Bed-chamber Scene in

Herod219, after reading the Othello

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 133; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 66r; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_133.jpg

[E.C.]

Scene – it actually remained

bonneted[?]by ⟨in⟩ the presence of its

great challenger! It is, as it

were, of different nationality, but

of the same humanity.

On Sunday, at breakfast, I said to

Michael “Our passion has a

tendency to walk the ground

with burning feet; it rarely

takes wings & flies”. This was

well said of our later work – but

with Herod there is more flight,

in this nervous Arab’s passion.

Dr Dot came on Friday – she too

thinks my ill is transitory – &

indeed it is much less of a

weight on my being – use &

improvement both assist me.

And the dismal doctor has at

last vouchsafed to say that the

cases of anaesthesia he has

personally known were due to

Influenza. So all our panic

might have been reduced to

this suggestion, wh: the “hollows”

in my head seem to justify.

Today – Sunday – is May-Day &

we are expecting Tommy & his

bridg bride Marie. The meeting

must be momentous – because

such people are involved in its

issue. Sturge Moore, Michael & Field &

the Artists! How glad we shall

be if she can become our friend.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 134; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 66v; Mia Vodanovich, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_134.jpg

[E.C.]

She accepted our invitation with

“Yours respectfully”. Poor Marie!

She is not of our country –

therefore doubly a guest.

Such May Day!

The clusters on the wisteria

en-groupe. Full of buds &

bells is our little garden.

The kind Oxford Widow has

sent me wild-flowers for the

festival – the yellow wild tup

tulip of Oxfordshire, white

wild fritillarias, wild anemones

(one even flushed with the country)

wild hyacinths, white cottage-

primroses & vast wood-primroses.

I am quite unable before Herod

as yet, but I travel into Arabia

with Burton, & discover more

& more how the man described

by Josephus had the Beduin

Shaykh at the centre of his

character.

May Day – o the gladness! And

a little garden worthy of Flora.

Now to meet the Bride & the Guest!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 135; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 67r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_135.jpg

[K.B.]

Written on May Day 94

She dies; it is our prayer that she should die:

With what sweet music shall she fall on death,

For jarred is all the music of Love’s breath

And she much hear all noises that pass by

Without His muffling wings? She will hear the cry

Of laughter from the streets: what the street saith

Rises through open doors: she shuddereth

As one had stripped her to the open sky –

But who is this, with face that none may mark

Bows over her, & silent spreads the shades? –

Within her hand there is a flower that fades,

And a great grove behind the scepter shows

O Venerable, draw her to repose,

Keep her for ever with thee in the dark!

_

Marie is like a sod of green turf.

When Tommy peeks, he will find the

daisy, the grass, the wholesome worm.

The May Day is – as not before for years.

From the Terrace range on range of

low hills, as only on clearest days

everything soft & growing.

Alack! Heaven cannot just now

supply iron for the will: Heaven is

doling out all sorts of fostering[?] foods.

How foolish is the naming of the moments!

Brides & Priests, & Kings – the Blush,

the Vocation, the [????] of God. We

cannot see these things; & a rage

of disappointment seizes us, when

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 136; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 67v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_136.jpg

[K.B.]

we come in after the event.

[E.C.]

Marie is dusk, responsive to the

country air as blue-berry.

She has ableness of character –

the true Protestant strain, &

ability – her English is

wonderful in attack –

& a bright-eyed independence

of phrasing makes one

laugh as at the motions

of a healthy living creature

in the meadows.

Now & then she has the

gesture – a trick of the brows

that reminds me of Michael’s

old friend of Paris days –

Miss Gérante – who, strange

to say, Marie describes as

almost a “great-grandmother”

to her! So it comes about we

learn from Tommy’s bride

how the good little soul,

the sister of Michael’s

supreme love, Alfred Gérante,

came quietly to her end

in the Deaconnesses Home,

with pasteurs to pray with her,

& by favour, her beloved objects

round her – all her mementos.

How strange is life – how strange!

Tommy read the Gazelles – but

badly, monotonously.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 137; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 68r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_137.jpg

[K.B.]

I send my May Sonnet to Painter. The next

day – Tuesday – he comes.

Yes, but the surveyor has left a long[?]

perfume; we are still agitated, & close

upon Painter’s heels presses John. I decide

they shall not meet. I am frayed with

weeping; feeling already only the walls

of me are left standing, – I must enjoy –

so the devoted Henry discusses leases

downstairs with John; & we in the sun

– roam, speak of Dryden’s Antony & Cleopatra

of Sabbatai – of Eleanora[?] Duse &c. & the

Sonnet.

He is disappointed in Sabbatai –

because he conceives Rénan’s

Jesus, repeated dramatically in the

central actions of his life. He would

even have the cock crow thrice. He

holds with Rénan, there was absolute

disillusion when Jerusalem was

entered; he regards that Life as to itself

failure.

But we have not touched that divine

Figure. Rather we give the uncertainty,

the error, & forsakenness of one called,

but not chosen – one who for a moment

had confidence in himself from within

– & then went about seeking a sign.

In Christ, I, Michael, find a fulfilled

Ideal, in Sabbatai the wreck of a man

who is not a hypocrite – who is rejected

– who cannot lay hold –

Every endowed & doubting Soul is

a Sabbatai. Sabbatai has nothing[?]

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 138; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 68v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_138.jpg

[K.B.]

in him of the fluency of faith.

Painter has always felt profoundly

the tragedy of Christ – he would have

liked our Sabbatai to have something

of his richness of allure, his tenderness.

This was not in our scope.

We speak of Rossetti. “You are like him –”

“No, Michael, Rossetti was one of the original

minds of his time. I am not that.

I am a spectator, doubled by the actor.

That means I am a critic.

I am the greatest spectator I have

ever known”. Of his painting he will not

speak, but much of its his life, in its

current of change & fate –

He likes the Palace, it is not hostile to

him. He likes its sense of solidity – that

storms do not shake it. And he likes the

mid-night landscape from those high

windows – Kensington Gardens he

does not like.

There are brief glances of Henry –

but when I find her with Amy[?] – long

after John’s departure – at last, after

Painter is gone - She is fallen petals.

#

Yesterday May 4 th, we kept my Mother’s

wedding-day (70 years ago) with finer

fritillaries than ever. Round the

honoured[?] portraits flowers grown

in the garden clustered.

To-day My Dearest has been with me

– gathering the long-peach tulips from

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 139; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 69r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_139.jpg

[K.B.]

our garden-bed. She is always exquisite

in convalescence, & I am grieved to be

but dull cloud to her gaiety.

I have written to Mary – “the leaves

have come out gallantly. – but I hate

the gallant leaves.

I love to see my dearest gathering

flowers. I like to witness that action

best in all the world.”

Philosophy.

If it be space that makes long distances,

Beauty it is that brings our joys to pass,

Drawing together that that severed was:

As a cut branch of blossom from the bees

Cut off, is, in its cluster, full of these,

The drag, & all the murmur of their mass;

So I behold the features in a glass

Wherever Beauty is, & smile at ease,

Feasting at leisure on thee, though thou lack,

Feasting at leisure, counting all thy praise.

So is it with thy love, I have thee back,

All thy perfections subtle in my gaze,

If I but look on Love – so am I sure

Of thee, while Beauty & while Love endure.

May 6th. 1904.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 140; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 69v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_140.jpg

[E.C.]

The Week from Marie’s Sunday to

the Apparitio Sancti Michaelis.

__

Tuesday

We expect Amy – I look out at a

rap & see Fay’s pilgrim cloak.

He has arrived on the top

of the pert Surveyor who has

comes ⟨been⟩ to chronicle repairs,

leaving my breast full of

aspics.

He looks ill – like a white

flower tired & purpling in

its shadows: no question

but he has had influenza.

Another rap! I slip out to

receive Amy, past a heap

of Sabbataї Acts, a vol. of

Anatole France & a vol.

of Dryden’s plays. I open the

door – . . It is John, with

apple & cherry-flower from

the Manor, come to read

over the Lease. I draw him

down into the Gold Room, where

strawberries smile – swiftly

order up ⟨tea⟩ to the Sun Room

for Michael & Fay, & tea to be

served with the strawberries

for John & me, excusing ‘Auntie’

on the ground of literary talk

about a play. Alas, I miss all

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 141; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 70r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_141.jpg

[E.C.]

refreshment in ideas while welcoming

John’s kindness & the touching

blossoms. Amy, looking charming

in green comes later to join

the Gold-Room Party. When John

is gone, Amy is sent for to

receive the mannered greeting

of Ricketts, noisily bantering &

filled with laughter.

I am tired– tired . . .

Since then my adventures have

been with flowers . . . Darwin

Tulips of wine & oyster-violets,

of peaches in awe at the satins

they stain – great boughs

from the orchard, pinions of

a Sun of the Morning . .

lifted strands, petal over petal,

flowers over buds[?] – a ‘ruffle’

for flight on the wind that

will carry them away.

On Thursday little Dodge came,

but danced about my nerves,

tired & needing discreet sympathy

Mary220 is ill at I Talti221 –

Bernhard222 ailing.

Perry Feilding[?] has married a

Flaxen-haired Architect –

Maysfield,223 the Poet, has received

a daughter.

Michael sups with Cockerell224 & two

young people – poor Michael!

The young person is not for us.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 142; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 70v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_142.jpg

[E.C.]

When we are very old the young

may sit at our knee

“as if we had a mystery

and wonder to unfold”

That is the only way in wh: we

can touch youth – its crudeness

subdued; its self-importance

must be made gracious by

that gift of the wise Graces –

attention.

After the kindly insult of the

company Cockerell adds the

injury of setting his trio of

guests to picture-books.

It is terrible to trust converse⟨entertainment⟩

to the Eye, the most weariable

of the Senses – flatness &

exhaustion of all society

result. Poor Michael!

But she returns to find me in

a rosy garlanded hat from

the good Véréna,225 & some

cheer is born.

The hours of May have been cold

– very cold in manner.

How slow have the days been!

I progress at first with the

movement of a glacier – now

with that of a wakened serpent

or tortoise.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 143; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 71r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_143.jpg

[E.C.]

Yesterday (Sat.) Michael, who is jarred

& prostrate in nerve, went to the

dentist only to hear nothing need

be done – So she went to the

new gallery & reveled in

Watts’226 Fugue227 – the living

counterpoint of its colour.

Meanwhile I am struggling

with sickness, the Schedule

of Repairs is sent by the Trustees,

the cheerless Doctor comes to

me out of our air good for

neither man nor beast, &

over the River boards are

set up offering sites with

a river-frontage – our worst

fear & anguish realised.

When Michael & I are together

again we suffer the most excessive

crise des nerfs.

All day my nerves have been as

tops & whip-card in a substantial

tangle.

I cannot conceive infamous houses

directly before our eyes.

I cannot conceive us without

Paragon –

And I have a deadly fear of

the country & the indigenous

cow.

While Fay’s hate of Kensington Gardens

is a warring against town.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 144; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 71v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_144.jpg

[E.C.]

Today we have been enabled to

put by our trouble – we have

been strengthened, stabilised,

settled under the Appearing

of St. Michael.

We have finished Twelfth Night

It teems with Michael’s

youth . . it is full of the

honey & cloves of youth.

Sweet, sweet fooling –

sweet, sweet love-making

& a key of music set from

the very first.

Our beautiful yellow Puss Ruff

has wandered. I love all

our animals to be in fold.

But today we have the gaiety

of some kind of hope in

us. Michael has even

wrought at Herod.

I have sent Act I to be typed

for the garlanding of lovelier work.

A Snatch

It is the Spring –

O Eros of the Garden & the trees!

There are leaves & unforbidden

By a void my birds are hidden –

Each bird a quick May-breeze:

and the birds sing.

_

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 145; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 72r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_145.jpg

[E.C.]

Anatole France’s Contemporary Books:

A Kaleidoscope[?] of the fragments

of today, shaken into patterns,

not by the hand of a child

but of a much grown-up man.

The irony alone is in the

shaking – there is innocence

still in the result.

We have from him mockery

out of the very gentleness

of civilisation[?]. He is not

too serious for Now – whenever

there is seriousness in a man’s

work the past preaches or[?]

the future idealises.

Anatole France lies in the

atmosphere of our breath,

& sees the light of on our

Days, & focuses it on some

individuals, & watching how

it characterises them with

pervasive tenderness.

He is kind toward fellow-men

as our sun toward the suburbs,

the occupations of modern life.

And in his light we can see

a little light – for he is patient,

& humorously deprecating.

Anti Semitism

Putting aside the influence of science,

I believe that most of the

irreligion of today is due

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 146; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 72v; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_146.jpg

to suppressed Anti-Semitism.

Judaism is Oriental & Christianity

alone conquered the West by

its foreign elements – all

in it that could be affiliated[?]

to Greece & Rome & the North.

In the Catholic Church

we have an Occidental

Creation, full of the philosophy

of Greece, the practical

functioning of Rome, the

old Pagan latitude & beauty⟨loveliness⟩

– the Western solidarity with

Nature that man enjoys under

temperate suns.

There came Protestantism

to destroy, & to offer a Jewish

Book for an European

Church. Protestantism holds

to the Bible & nothing but

the Bible, & it has gone

very near to destroying

Christianity by an Orientalism

abhorrent to the genius

of Europe.

The Wisdom of the World-

Snake was in the Church

of Rome when it withheld

the Bible & disavowed its

Eastern origin.

Peoples, like individuals, have

a tendency as they age to

revert to their early ideas &

tendencies, & our developed

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 147; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 73r; Jenée Crayne, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_147.jpg

[E.C.]

civilisation will not endure a

superimposed Asiatic dominance,

but breaks away to the real

& free sources of its inspiration.

Protestantism has done a

dangerous harm to Christianity

by re-attaching it to Judaism –

they must be severed – if

Christ is to be the Star, the

Morning Star, of the white

races.

May 15th Chestnut Sunday 228, &

“Mid-May’s Eldest Child”.

After a day of hot wind – a killing

loveliness[?] that made the⟨wrung⟩

the wide young leaves & brought

aches into one’s flesh, today

comes a spring-triumph.

We have been by the river glad

of the air & of the benignant Sun.

Every object is a fountain springing

up as an ecstasy of light,

streaming down as a benison[?]

of light. How the lilacs are lilac!

How the breeze chucks them under

each tuft. The old Bridge is a

centre of a [????] of boats & steamers.

On the bulk of the steamer

the surface-motions of the

river dance – they are soft, diffusive

as the movements of fire – they

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 148; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 73v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_148.jpg

[E.C.]

grow out of their activity in the

same way.

The reflection we is a net of

living fire, made from the

silk of the Thames.

And our bowery little garden –

so cool to the head under

the roses & such a blaze

of tup tulips in the open!

We are hoping to start for Parrock

Farm on Tuesday – the boxes

are half-packed & Music’s

eyes are solicitous.

Vincent Hayahi – the Jap. Ambassador

will touch life with us in

June – having taken Bingham

House – one ivy-wall between

us & the ally! Well, the

Japs find our situation desirable

– & Old Furkes[?] is bankrupt.

The view may still be saved . . . .

if I could believe it rock-sure

it would.

The Great Event of this Year is the

arrival of Fay’s Prado –

An Astonishment! He writes –

there is dignity & subtleness in

the English; there is Craft, just

what Bernhard lacks. Fay

would not have written if Bernhard

had never written – so far a

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 149; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 74r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_149.jpg

[E.C.]

debt – all the rest is a fortune.

How cautious Fay is! – a hedge

all round to keep ‘little Charlie’

safe from attack – a well-grown

hedge of noble modesty, not

a cowardly pallisade.

I suppose the photo gravures are

the best possible, but the pictures

are half-lost, & far more truly

revealed in the text. I

have read little yet.

As Browning said to us –

I discrown no-one to crown

Fay. He is a natural King.

Now of his last visit –

He breaks in at tea (Tues. May 10th)

creative gaiety about his head

like bees. He has been painting.

On the settee upstairs we have

Max Beerbohm’s Poets’ Corner.

Fay draws our chairs into a

crescent that we may all in

enjoy it. Then such laughter!

Divine laughter crackling like

a god’s. He does not (as

Michael says) laugh with us, but

to & of himself; as the thunder

thunders of the cloud. When he

passes it is to sob with joy

“O My God!” – or to ripple into

encomium “It is a beautiful book –

beautiful, beautiful” I think

Rossetti in his back garden evoked

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 150; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 74v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_150.jpg

[E.C.]

the roundest agony of peals –

Swinburne in his old maid’s

bonnet of hair with his finicky

mischief under Watts-Dunt’s229

finger is a delight to kill

with. Stupendous in cruelty

& power is the Matthew Arnold –

Whitman inciting the obstinate

bird of freedom sets the

laughter to such volume

I only hear the tremulous

shriek “this braces!”

The soft abundance of

humour in the Omar & “Thou”

does not liberally strike

on Fay, & he is not well-

acquainted enough to realise

the chalky perfection

of George Moore face

as he meets the Fairy

Queen under Yeats’ encouraging

arm. The little toes & legs

of the good-boy-realist, his

nice shining manners – ~

perfection, perfection! Yeats is a

rather cruel caricature –

though the attitude & pose are

convince one’s deepest amuse-

-ment.

Max is a wonderful critic

by distortion – the novelty

strikes to the centre of a

characteristic & brims us with

delighted recognition of it.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 151; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 75r; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_151.jpg

[E.C.]

Perhaps Fay enjoys Browning drinking

tea with the Browning society as

much as any – Especially the

portentous matron of the

lower-middle class who supports

the fabric of the Fad.

Deliciously suggested the flesh &

blood presence of a great man

in the midst of non-sense he

has evoked … the Kingly,

genial head having its

amusement above the body

that is not severed from

the class of its neighbours!

East Grinstead

The Crown Hotel230

May 21st.

We have had adventures.

On Tuesday, May 17th – we start for

Upper Parrock Farm – To begin with

the wine runs out of the lunch basket –

Bacchus231 unfavourable!

As we approach Forest Row 232 we en-

-counter lustrous country. The trees

shine – the lie of the fields & copses

seems to enhance the youth of

in their spring brightness. But

alas, our Cab climbs in the wrong

direction – away from enlightenment.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 152; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 75v; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_152.jpg

[E.C.]

Even here the great speedwells cry

out Speed well! The strawberry

flowers are as lambs for the

slaughter. Indeed all the

flowers are ready for the butcher –

so round, so clean fat!

We draw up by a ribbed house

– that suggests colonial life, &

wait on the grass, in our cab –

while the mixen gapes on

one side, & the yellow-ball

flowers gape on us from the

other. All is silence & great

horror. Then at last the door

opens & an ageless old woman

in black, with the manners of

an unf underfed Cat, creeps

up. Entering a door that looks

as if no mere human soul

ever passed it, & feeling the fingers

of a vicious guardian-rose

plucking at me, I am in a

little mouldy den of a hall – &

then in a large colonial-looking

room, an oak rafter the only

signature of antiquity, &

mould as of the family vault

for atmosphere! Such a black

chickenette on the soiled

table-cloth & butter with the

breath of mutton. A window

fixed as the manure-yard &

its central treasure – the Well.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 153; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 76r; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_153.jpg

[E.C.]

As Fay would say – “My God!”

we left the violeted chick on

its dish, & out on to the

common grass! Our very souls

stuttered before the mutual

confession We must go. But the

cab was away in the remote

roads. We learn a telegram

can be sent – we re-call the

parted cab. Pussy behaves

very well … has she not been

stroked for five winters by old

Lady H …. who has recently

died at Hampton Court?233 So she

understands those who have recently

left the royal borough of Richmond.

But we have to pay little short

of ₤2 . . . & the future is a blank.

&[?] . . . . . . . . . .

Here follows bits from Michael’s

letter to Fay.

“The old woman, our hostess, boasted

she had “suckled” the herd of

young creatures in the meadow.

She had the guardianship of a

Doctor’s son (species, I should say,

idiot) whom she had set in her

energy to build a greenhouse.

When Henry saw the patient’s childish

garden of polyanthus, rising out of the

grass, she turned the head of our

luggage back to civilisation.

Behold us at The Crown, E. Grinstead.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 154; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 76v; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_154.jpg

[E.C.]

Our great excitement has been going

over a fine old Elizabethan house to

let in the street. It has the most

perfectly proportioned rooms I have

ever entered, panelled walls &

a chimney-piece : – Beside a little

dark-panelled library, for all

the world like the famous

Supper-Room at Holyrood

from the diamond panes one

reads the date 1599 – about

the date say of the “Sonnets”;

& other sonnets might be written

There . . . but the repetition of the

Rizzio234 tragedy makes profounder

appeal to Michael’s imagination.

Henry’s pale eyes burnt. I

checked her by reference to a

neighbouring slaughterhouse, &

refused to look at the folded eyelid

of a far, fair country beyond

the diamond panes.

Next Tuesday we start for a week

at Court House Farm, Rottingdean

(your old quarters) There I will allow

Henry to open the Prado. Here

I remember lines & verses of old

hymns. The rustic dead have,

I suppose, left them on the air . . .

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 155; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 77r; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_155.jpg

[E.C.]

I continue:

The chickenette is torn up, but not

Eaten – Then the hostess proposes we

should have a look round, & presents

us to a brede[?] of free Chase, on

which a stable⟨confused⟩ pattern of

sunny green rests from the bits

of underwood here & there. We

almost yield to the wine of air,

to that free Chase. Further, we

see Louis Napolean’s fish-pond –

without an imperialist desire to

reach it. Food, is rather a

negligible circumstance here,

it seems, just as a doctor is –

people always have their health

here. “But if you feel frightened⟨lonely⟩

I would not have you stay.”

The good woman drives off the

young cattle & assures us she

has suckled them all. There is

no family here of human kind.

But deep in bents[?] I see a

scrawled bed or two, & some

polyanthuses235 in turf – they

can’t be there by nature, & if the

ground is not the pure garden-

bed their tufts are almost super-

-natural. I shudder; & hear

that the plot belongs to a doctor’s

son, who had come here ill from

India – sunstruck in the wits I

opine. He becomes the denizon

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 156; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 77v; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_156.jpg

[E.C.]

of Parrock Farm, & the hostess a

priestess & the suckled animals

a temple-herd round the Idiot.

When I speak of my illness,

I am greeted with nerves!

Old Lady H . . . was never allowed

to be ‘grumpy’. The keeper of the nerve-farm,

the nerve-farmer . . . the lady

nerve-farmer herself . . is a study –

she has the thin lips & thin

eye-lids, the cheerful thinness

in the voice of a being of

single experience – Parrock Farm.

She is original as the cuckoo-

[????]⟨wild-arum⟩, among the hedge-flowers . . .

a temperament of curious

colour & a noticeable quaint

tongue.

The parted Cab – back again &

for us! We run on the grass

to it; we bid farewell with

hysterical assurances we shall

never forget the kindness of

the woman with our ₤2 in

her black pocket & her troublesome

guests going beyond the chance

of giving trouble. But we nearly

weep with sentiment! It is

the shock of that Cab, that

reprieve in a mounted square,

standing up by the mixen.

We are light as air . . . The boxes

groan over us, we are weak &

weary, the world is before us

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 157; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 78r; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_157.jpg

[E.C.]

unprepared for us – but we are light

as air & jauntily accost those[?]

speedwells for their irony in

calling up to us their interjection

of encouragement to Parrock.

Various inns are looked at

& rejected . . through the glancing

Maytide we drive to East Grinstead

& its Dorset . . Cycle-motor manners

there & no possible room!

Am dead with weariness – the

sensation of gyves round my

knees . . . sent[?] on to the Crown we

find goodness core-deep in the

land-lady & her daughter. Joy,

very exaggeration of joy, for a

harbour above a street where

man goes by & old houses still

shelter the modern shops, &

shallow gray steps lead us up to

pollard limes[?] – joy for all this!

But the cost of this trying day

is utter depression which lasts

after a night of assoupissment[?].

Whym is not well – he repeats

our mood in fur.

No-one knows where we are –

We drive to the Forest – a glory

of sun on the leaves where there

are some . . . but the forest is a

name & no wood-gods rule

or have forest-nights there.

On Thursday we seek out a lady – a

distant friend, as it were, of friends –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 158; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 78v; Kellie Saul, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_158.jpg

[E.C.]

The road is suburban – everywhere

the retriever in wait for Chow, &

no-one at home . . .

But coming back we find Spanish

irises growing with fresh stems

& a sparkle of edges in ⟨a⟩ box of a

flower-shop. Michael brings me

twelve dewy bannerets[?] of

flowers – misery is at an

end. I begin to make our

room more harmonious.

I wonder what blossom will

reconcile me to the Other Life –

What Tree over the Grave or sweet

plant will make me at home

with myself:

Then we seek & find the only green

way out of E. Grinstead – the East

Court Estate – of course offered for

building sale. But, oh, the

verdure of this May! How we

have seen leaves – the plentitude

of their shapes! There is grass

to the feet, & rooks to the ear – Each

is the Carpet of peace to a sense.

And for the eye, there is greenness &

a square red house looking on

its distances unexcitedly.

Peace – perfect peace & abundant

month of the May!

Thursday

Another drive beyond suburbs into

a country[?], so indiginous there

is little wonder that Roman roads

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 159; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 79r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_159.jpg

[E.C.]

are not to be found. What of the Latin

could tread this rusticity[?]? The air

is dull, a glorious dull thing – where

are there any associations save

the honourable local births,

marriages & deaths? A forest,

desecrated for iron-smelting,

has left no boscage in the

imagination, such as Keats says

of to Psyche. Where is there a

Genius in this large country there

is only View – a complex of ground

views, a[?] singleness of

platitude?

But we enjoy the lanes – the leafy

hedges, the herby-flowers. At

last we are on the ridge of

Ashdown Forest. O air of a

sea that has caught as its

amber & seaweed, the substance

of the gorse-scent, the rocking

of the pine-scent! In the

Warren – little strewage of

cones – Dionysus! Here we

could be happy.

We cut through a body of air – this

spine is a quick division of

airs that are one in their

Essence.

Below we look at Golf Links &

a small house for borders, kept

by a charming creature – like

a leafless stem in blossom! But

how impossible to be among new

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 160; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 79v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_160.jpg

[E.C.]

villas & hicks[?], in small surroundings!

After tea we go over Cromwell House –

Such a room there! The proportion of

it a blessing – over a hundred

little panels expressing its walls –

a mantel-shelf 1599 – one high

window on the street, the its

other ‘soul-side’ turned to

the weald & forest – The

passages mossed with damp –

the poor garden cloked with

quicken, full of set strawberry

flowers – a cast-off firmament[?]

of little planets.

Here a ruckle[?] of Scotch rose-trees

in bud, there a giant white

Columbine, with first few

flowers, spirred spurred &

profound[?] in romance.

Upstairs the Cabinet Michael

calls[?] of Holyrood – a little reliquary

to hold a Queen . . .

But the damp, the desolation,

the shorn[?] garden – & the

slaughter-house! No, not here

is the finger of God pointing us –

Save for a half-hour of ravishment.

We leave it for the green of East Court, blown

over by a North Wind.

In the night Chow’s licking is joined

by the lick of rain over all!

Poor Chow – poor Michael!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 161; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 80r; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_161.jpg

[K.B.]

The Crown Hotel East Grinstead

Whit Sunday. May 22nd.

We have flowers of flame. We are growing

well. Heaven, at Rottingdean, give us the

life of the Spirit

It is unloving of the old to wish to leave the

earth. What have I, said Tristan, but my

body & my country. To the earth, to our

body, we bid eternal adieu. We shall be

dearer loved of those who love us, if we

do not want to die. We shall be

less remorseful in heaven, if we

have loved human things to the end –

if we have been good, & indulgent to

human things, as to the excessively old

and childish. this ancient, honourable,

earth, how good to be an inhabitant thereof

for a season.

Therefore to have witnessed this season⟨spring⟩

of the gallant leaves is good, & many

a saint in heaven may be sighing back

to us. Afterall, the white robes of the saints

don’t brush against the ground ivy –

or cuckoo-pint 236, or the shut daisies.

The gorse 237-scent has brine in its blood.

If Apollo oiled his locks, like the curled

Antony238, he wd rub in a gorse pomade.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 162; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 80v; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_162.jpg

[E.C.]

Whit Sunday

Very gray – but we achieve peace.

In the afternoon, going to East Court,

We see the sky dove-like brooding

over the expanse of country.

And we visit a nine-year-old

Garden round a red brick residence

that proves how Love is enough –

it is spaced by rose-arches

firm enough in leafy architecture

for Mantagna239 to put his

visions of stone in front of

them. At every corner the

loved herb, the cherished

flowering bush, the adored

plot of old-fashioned flowers:

colonies of columbines, iris both

high & low, flamy[?] avens,

rosemary – ah, so many

loves!

Whit Monday

Morning spent down Blackwell Hollow.

A heavenly May-day! In May,

there is a largeness of style

in the Earth one does not get

again till October – a diversity

& sweeping of the light – something

Pre-eminently vital & therefore

large in the aspect of the

land – a beauty of expansion,

before limit is reached, that

is full of In infinite sway.

The fields that end in harvest are

but pile of green grass – they teem

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 163; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 81r; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_163.jpg

[E.C.]

with buttercups, they skip with

daisies – the trees that will be

a slowly withering shade are

now ⟨but⟩ lights to lighten the

brows & pastures. The skies

have sweetness of temperance

as sense of [????] discipline

makes them noble. And

The forms of leaf & flower are

innumerous. Birds fly &

babble, till the air has rillets

of its own – singing bl brooks.

And there are all the nebulae

of sound from the voice of

insects.

Though we have been wretched at

East Grimstead – with Chow 240 ill &

the air a melancholy outside

us & drawn in, we feel kindness

after taking the two ladies of the

Mantagna-arched garden to see

Cromwell House. That parlour!

So full of quiet ages, when the home

was nearly as quiet as the grave!

Nothing of the streets in it – a hold

against them rather.

Then the brede of country between

the town & Each Court is so full

of greenery, full of mellowness

& blossoming under sundown

we feel contrition we have not

loved it more.

The oaks are just in their youth – hung

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 164; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 81v; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_164.jpg

[E.C.]

as with Baltic amber241 – beneath

them blue-bells hyacinthine 242,

the discord of a master!

To change the simile, this

sharp thick violet is the

right syrup to be served

with the goldenly-embrowned

substance of the foliage &

shows Earth a Chef who can

dare the utmost.

Michael will remember from

East Grimstead –

(1)243The daisies, the shut daisies,

over the graves, on each side

of the way where we passed

with Chow – there they rested

& seemed to wish to give us

rest as they had found it. Happy,

shut daisies!

(2) The mead that was flowing

from the sycamore-flowers,

wet with rain, on Whit Sunday

morning.

(3) And a spray of hazel on which

the nuts were but stripling leaflets

with a queer little morsel of

promise among them.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 165; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 82r; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_165.jpg

[E.C.]

Tuesday In dense wetness we leave

The Crown. Such nice people – the

rosy old Mother weeping fresh

tears over the cheeks her artistic

daughter (a pupil of Herkomer244)

is now experiencing); the younger

daughter, thin & blue-eyed as a

corn-blue-bottle, playing her

piano, making good cakes, &

bowing to her Mother’s orders –

quickly made by her effective

orders to the house. We shall

always keep in mind their

human kindness.

Sealed up in our 1st Class Carriage

we make a long, depressing journey.

Brighton at last! Always cheer

in its robust conditions – immense

sea, bright shops, houses too high

to be ignoble, inviting donkey-

shays & victorias.

The old downs, ugly, unchanged –

there the roofs of dear Rottingdean!

Court House farm – alas, spoiled

by cork floral boxes, formality

of beds – but quiet Mrs Johnson,

the fidelity of quietness in her

there is in the b beautiful lines

of South Downs, to receive us.

Our rooms – nearly the same, but

cut off at the folding-doors – &

beatitude!

Rottingdean is to us as a Beloved –

plain to others, a compliment of

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 166; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 82v; Hind AlJarboa, Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_166.jpg

[E.C.]

qualities to us – what we need,

what we needs must love.

This power of places as of

persons is a mystery.

behold we adore Rottingdean

– we are happy.

Now we know the intensity

of the wretchedness we have

known. I wondered if I

were too broken in nerve

ever to feel natural joy

again. Though I cannot

stir from the house I lie

& picture Fay by the mantel

shelf like a Michael Scott

be-wizarding Michael – or

looking down the road I

see his demon-motion, as

if his cloak bore him over-

ground.

And when we came down to

dinner there is a witty,

wicked letter from him to

Michael. She had “begun

to remember the lilacs were

fading” on wh: she had sworn

he should have his copy

of The Prado245 back: on this

he remarks “I do not intend

discoursing on the moral aspect of

your seizure of the Prado as I had

intended the copy for you, Holmes

having received a duplicate copy for

review.” So the Prado is ours, even as

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 167; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 83r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_167.jpg

[E.C.]

The Florentine Drawings –

I don’t know what makes us love

Rottingdean so much – it is like

true marriage. Others may

wonder at our joy but there it is.

The Downs set me in order as

God’s command gave genesis

to Chaos – it is fundamental

as that.

We found that on the Weald the

sheep-census equalled the

human – The are ⟨air⟩ was rural

& sheep-heady. Here the sheep

are but a cloud or two on one

element, Earth; while sea & air

sweep the curly creatures

limitlessly.

Michael writes to Janet –

“We are here among the rock-gardens

& rose-daisies of Rottingdean. We are

in this country of the Earth & Sky

& air – A nightingale would know

that she was naked in this country

& be ashamed. But bareness in

Maytime & the cowslip with a sugar-

dew of its own, & at the sweet old

florists where I used to get white violets

for the artists, storms of purple stock &

purple columbine! We have a

hostess[?] I call the Flemish Madonna, &

Henry calls her the Dove of the Ark.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 168; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 83v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_168.jpg

[E.C.]

Our news is most exciting.

My copy of The Prado is with us.

It is a glorious book – rich,

invigorating, modest, arrogant

& enjoying – full of exquisite,

suggestive phrases & sentences.

In a word I have the joy of

recognising the Painter as a

Writer. How many Kingdoms

he conquers! For the rest – doubtless

the Eagles will gather together

over the body of this book.

Another bliss has been to us

Max Beerbohm’s Poet’s Corner

– a series of divinest caricatures.

One evening, just before we left

Paragon, Painter, Henry & I gathered

our chairs close together to

laugh in chorus over Rosetti’s

Back Garden &c. But doubtless

you have been to the gallery? In

any case we possess the book,

& this & the Prado Janet shall

enjoy when we return for (a.b.w)[?] in

rather mid-June. Dear Henry is

re-gaining her famous Rottingdean

beauty – a face as clear & placid

as the seas. She is growing better,

& is not only herself, but more than

herself.

It is nearly two years since our last

visit to Rottingdean: the infant

just born (the fruiterer’s infant) then,

has now eye-lashes that over-shadow

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 169; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 84r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_169.jpg

[E.C.]

his cheek like sycamines”.

Wednesday 25th of May.

We wander about, about –

after tea we ascend the White Way –

The ⟨several⟩ planes of dawn are each stretches

of vari-colours in their most

delicate bloom. We meet the

Shepherd – cheeks like washed

coral – dog, a young pure-bred

Sussex sheep-dog, with Kindliness

of eye, a pot au feu of goodness.

The sheep are all ba-ing

in their wattles.

Cowslips of the turf, never more

than two together, cowslips

on short stems, with a few large

flowers cherished by sea-wind . . .

we pick – the fresh little stems

break like glass.

There is sundown over the slopes;

& in the meadows the lit

dandelion-clocks are nature’s

Japanese lanterns for the fête –

the daisies are⟨become⟩ a presence, a

multitudinous white half way

up the grass, so that they seem

to float.

We each stand by Burne Jones’ grave

– that dear grave that taught me

Tristan’s mood in [????]

To think we were living with Cesare

& Alexander when we were here last!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 170; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 84v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_170.jpg

[E.C.]

And now our Bedouin Herod

is taking the great air with us!

Tristan – Julia Donna & Caracalla –

Cesare, Alexander, Lucrezia, &

Herod the Idumæan!

What company! – & add the

Artists.

Thursday 26

A thunder-cloud lies over our

down all day, growling

like a nasty old lion –

My vases are full of flowers, my

brain of infinite curves & my

chest of air – so the old brute

may growl. We climb up

to him, & he shirks off, leaving

a rill of breeze & a space

of light where he has been.

Friday 27 May

But he is back at night –

Oh! The heat! Whym nearly bursts

with his pants, our slumber is

a stifled & prolonged groan.

This morning the air⟨rain⟩ – a vision

of rain in the midst of blackness.

The rooks have been disturbed – it

is sacrilege; rooks are the genii of

security.

Michael writes to Painter –

“Cowslip-time on the Downs & the grass

at her closest mysteries. The rooks alone

are wheeling about angrily. They are

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 171; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 85r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_171.jpg

[E.C.]

mourning their murdered young – shot

unaccountably & in glossy multitude.

They mourn on the wing – so I will

not stay to be sorry.

Such a nice letter was laid on my

dinner-table on Tuesday. It fell in

deliciously among the cowslips &

soft brines of my mood.

Henry & I are now reading the Prado

through.

Don’t write “output” – that is what

Bernhard would do!! I cannot

give you the right word . . . Sometimes

you can say work or production

(or creation) “Output” is vile, worse

than “You have deceived me” in

Sabbataї.

You have fine sentences hidden away

like violets under their leaves. If

one is impatient one misses them.

More & more, with delight, I recognise

in you the appreciator. Instead of

cheap abuse, or apology, you make

us feel the virtue, or, at least, the

gift or attractiveness of the

poorest little Artist. And I laugh

at your struggles to be just to the

Spanish school. Whenever you

are really naughty you must be shut

up there.

Would you like to hear the old florist from

whom I used to get white violets

for you has storms of purple stocks &

of purple columbines? We have

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 172; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 85v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_172.jpg

[E.C.]

memories at Rottingdean – memories

of Caracalla, of Tristan, of Caesar

Borgia, of ___

but it is lunch-time!

Michael.”

Trinity Sunday.

Last night Michael stormed across

my sullen sky – ⟨for us⟩ so miserable,

so unnecessary! – Only nerves . . .

& the vast mystery of that which

was & is & is to come lying

lying before us in the relation

of its Love!

Our feast retrieves its Vigil.

The sky beams after thunder-

rains – in the grass for mowing

the blaze of the buttercups

is such one can hardly look.

And the grasses themselves are

motes & web of planetary

brilliance.

I re-read the Gold Tristan – an

achievement in secousses de

passion . . . but wanting its true

end. All the scenes, except

the death-scene, have reached that

point where an element utters

itself – that point in emotion

when, like the cloud that must

thunder, the cloud that must rain,

the season that must be spring,

the season that must drop every

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 173; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 86r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_173.jpg

[E.C.]

spoil, need becomes actuality.

In the death scene this moment

– the capture of wh: is the method

of the play – remains neglected.

In fact it is avoided & a

sense of levity triumphs.

The radiant morning glooms . . .

Before tea, while at wander[?] in

front of the house, we see a thunder

cloud over the north, from which

the air takes hollowness.

A malignant pallor begins to

turn Eastward . . . At our return

the doors, the windows are all

open as they are before a coming of

death.

Afterward on the Downs we see the

storm stream smoulderingly out

to sea, while we are in a light of

keen relief, almost a shimmer.

Before the lines of down I

pace, leaving Michael & Chow on

a summit-mound, & concentrate

my passion on Tristan’s End.

Gradually the vision of a new

last scene forms, different from

the fine situation in the

Flame Tristan, where he grips

the wall, supported by his old

father-in-law & his old servant.

It was is difficult to sweep clear

of that so arresting group.

[Page]
