[K.B.]

May 31st. I write to Fay – from whom I

have a charming letter – speaking of

his horoscope &c, & complaining we must

not treat the Prado seriously –

“Get up, dear Serpent, from your smallness

Don’t play at being a small serpent, like

your great hero in Paradise Lost. Be

cloudy blue, & sorcerous, & elusive at

pleasure, so only you are not dwarfish

For – listen, – I have a secret thing to tell

you – destroy this letter – for Shannon must

never read it – since I have been at

Rottingdean – I have found written on

my heart – not Calais – but Diane. Diane

de Poitiers – & the French Renaissance (for

which I have been thirsting) the

Heavens are with this theme. I

hear of a vital book – speaking to me

already from Bain – with portraits –

But already – She is the Fair Rosamund

of Age . . . If the stars tell you anything of her,

your horoscope will be of supreme interest

I am in that most blessed state

of rest before creation – of which

the Lord (in Genesis) knows nothing.

It is like the rising of the dew, & as secret

. . . . .

But, until “the prophetic Soul, the Uncle” does

his worst, write to me, Painter, of the

plays – The Electra[?], & The Phèdre.

I am mad to miss them. We stay here

till June 7th or 14th Henry is growing so beautiful

I cannot[?] withdraw her from this air.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 175; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 87r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_175.jpg

[K.B.]

It sets a halo around her. I am growing nothing

except fierce eye-brows to frighten the

sergeant --

Be well, Painter, & enjoy the June. I

have white-balls from Paragon. In mid June

you shall have some of my gathering.

Michael.”

June 1st 1904

On our breakfast table. – crimson[?]

Saintfoin[?], milk-white campion.

And Bain sends the book.

It is the third book that arrives at

Rottingdean – ① Tristan & Iseult

② Autumn des Borgias – ③ Diane de Poytiers.

I found Diane graved on my

heart. My grief is with Henri, bowed

by this inexorable goddess.

“Je vous aie[?] appartenu parceque je vous

aimais; je ne soufrirais [?] pas qu’un

arret du Parlement me declare votre

concubine”

La Seule Princesse.

[E.C.]

June 2 nd Wed.

I write the Prologue to Diane

– or rather finish it. It was

begun on the first day of June

in the evening. What a joy I have

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 176; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 87v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_176.jpg

[K.B.]

To Tommy.

We are here in great happiness

We have learnt the May for the first

time. We are more at home here than

at Paragon. Tristan, the Borgia – Julia

Domna have all profited from the

sound drawing of the place.

Here we broke open the seals of the Tristan

Book, the Borgia book; & yesterday a

wondrous book on a new & secret

subject arrived. All the country is

laid out in sheepfolds & acts – the

mystery is open – it is in the air, & in the

circling of the wind.

[E.C.]

__________________________________________

in this god-child of Diana –

this woman in whom all

the elements of freshness &

clarity meet & are operative.

Like Art itself she is cold,

& yet not virginal. Art to

which all things lie apparent

can never be virginal, & yet

has the ice & cold of a chastity

that is elemental. Dianne

is very like La Beauté of

Baudelaire.

In to the Prologue all my

bee-work of the last weeks, all

I have drawn from Maytime

has settled into poetry.

Michael begins the Scene between

Dianne the Widow & Henri the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 177; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 88r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_177.jpg

[E.C.]

Spanish-eyed Dauphin of fifteen.

Oh, these buzzing tranquil

mornings of creation – Each

brain & right hand at their

proper joy!

Thursday

A gray windiness – We walk

far into the downs beyond the

White Way. We are with the

matron Earth, the nurser of crops –

where she dangles the little

green oats, & has the wheat

asleep on her knees – no

flowers yet obvious, except the

campion, like drops of milk.

How such a walk, while invigorating,

fosters one! Earth has given

her breast to one’s spirit as

well as to the wheat. All

The Bread of Life there in its

infancy, with the Power that

has produced it, & one’s very

being in ⟨natural⟩ harmony with as it

breathes with them.

I write Dianne with Palissy – Michael

finds dear Francis the First in the

room with her.

Friday

Michelet cares – the protestant

bigot, who cannot help negating

the Renaissance – the Humanism

that would not take up the attitude

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 178; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 88v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_178.jpg

[E.C.]

Of mind that ⟨wh:⟩ has starved man –

till he is the ugly, motoring

individualist of today.

Michelet has details, viciously

presented, that are illuminating –

but truly if one had not

Dianne first in his pages

Fay’s remark that there is

neither play nor tragedy in

her life would be justified.

The day veers & I am ill –

Saturday

It is delicious to walk wake to

our sycamine-tree throwing its

leaves in shade on its bark,

& sending out a hive-throng

of twitters.

The Wind is a bright North-East –

After walking in the mowing[?]-

field I write Dianne & Goujon[?]

by the Cascade – Michael still

works on her Titianesque

Francis

She has a letter from Fay, full of

chat, as ordered, of Gilbert

Murrey’s Hyppolytus. “I sat next

to little Arthur, who seemed quite

intelligent. We had tea together & got on

quite well. He agrees that good tragedy is

in reality good melodrama. He hates

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 179; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 89r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_179.jpg

[E.C.]

any mock music added to verse, which is

speech refined by intensity of mood & emotion.”

That judgement of tragedy is true in one

aspect – that the appeal to the

eye watching for movement on the

stage must be melodramatic to

arrest it boldly. And both Fay &

little Arthur would be swayed

by the peculiar mode of

today – viz. the artistic. The

world tries to see like the painter

now-a-days, not to feel & express

like the poet. Great Tragedy

will have its bold moments of

melodrama – may even have a

melodramatic construction (Hamlet)

but however good the melodrama

may be, the tragedy is not good

unless the creative mood

behind it is essential &

dominating & ominous.

We have had a letter too from Sturge

Moore, about publishers – the

all too necessary Evil we have to

face. It is helpful – but, ma foi,

how it exasperates by a slip

in taste! He tells us publishers

regard us as the French tried to regard

the Dreyfus case as a “chose jugée”.

No doubt you will come up again as the

Dreyfus case has” This from a

younger poet to one of Les Vieux –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 180; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 89v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_180.jpg

[E.C.]

It is cruelly strange, now the

noble shelter of the Vale Press

is lost, to have to meet publishing

as if we were young things of

eighteen – we who have lived

& suffered such experiences to

give man a few more emotions.

But Tommy’s sting warms my

inertia – The Gold Tristan shall

be published.

Sunday.

Glittering North East. Admiration

is possible, not a mood.

We have seen a great thing

– a land-sea flowing round

its ship . . . the wind in

live current of waters over

a field of grass, sweeping

it, lilac & silver & ripples[?] toward

the furled old windmill.

Below the land-sea – some

stakes of a wire-railing & a

quiet strand of buttercups

– a golden rim to the

billows of grass & the black

sails of the Mill.

One has a sense of such high

vitality when movement is of

a surface rather than a mass –

when the blood-horse shivers

along his flank, when the aspen

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 181; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 90r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_181.jpg

[E.C.]

trembles in its outer leaves, when a

thought passes through the aspect

of a forehead – or again when reflections

move over things. I have never

felt more the talismanic power

of life than I have have⟨d⟩246 in this

flowing meadow-hillside, as an

ocean above me.

I have two tall glasses full of grass-

-flower & ⟨green⟩ barley, bound round

at the brim with ranunculuses

of a Venetian opulence of colours

– & in a glass vase by them wide

lemon ranunculuses with black

eyes. They were gathered by our

old, old man, who will suggest to

one the weed-heap, who laughs at

his own ⟨old⟩ jests as a babe laughs at

the new world – a very feeble,

amused creature, with the

weed-heap not the flower-bed

before him.

Now I will try to put down what I

saw last week as the thunder storm

drifted.

I saw a hall with three windows

facing, the middle one reached by steps.

All the windows wide open & the

door under the by the fire place on the left,

& the door on the right wide open as

the windows. Through the windows

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 182; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 90v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_182.jpg

[E.C.]

a brooding thunder-cloud that

growls low.

Tristan is seated against pillows

in a chair by the empty hearth.

Behind his form, like a strange

glory, his great golden harp

stands – across his knees the

gold cover of the harp. He is

asleep and alone.

Suddenly Iseult of the White Hands

runs in – but stops arrested, by

the open doors & windows.

“It will be today” she shrieks.

Her mind strained by the effort

to “stand alone”, to keep the

secret she has overheard – breaks

into madness before the omens

of the open window, the growling

cloud. Light my Lightning, like

the brilliance of a bird’s motion

in the sun, shoots on her eyes –

she shrieks & cries out. Her

old father comes in, angry at

her break-down, insistent that

she shall go away. Firmly he

drags her out.

Tristan wakes – alone in the storm

– the wind blows now, the doors

close with a thud, the windows

beat. He is alone in Hell – alone

with his doom, that everything he

does is sin, that he is in the velocity

of a great anguish forever – in the Confusion

He feels Death is coming – intrepidly

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 183; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 91r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_183.jpg

[E.C.]

he rises. He will die on his feet, erect –

He is a knight – he loves, & death

is not a thing he can fear.

The op closed door is opened – there

are cries deep below “The ship[?], the

ship”. Iseult of the White Hand

rushes in, like a bird is storm,

& is hurled by her passion against

the sill – He stands dying . . .

What is the omen of his death –

is it cruel or merciful? The

cry rends them him “What colour

is the sail?”

With frenzy at its height, Iseult

of Arundel tells her lie, &

he falls, like column, straight

on the ground dead . . . .

I saw no-more.

Tuesday June 7th

A sea-day. The North-Easter crashes

down on the place, so we take

refuge under the cliff & I visit

His Majesty the Sea for the first

time. I do not like his glitter,

his indifference – There is no

living ⟨flow⟩tide; & the shore is like a

lion on his side after a good

dinner – & all about people burrow

in the pebbles, sit about by boats

or on machines, read their news-

papers, or tie up their children’s clothes.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 184; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 91v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_184.jpg

[E.C.]

All this smugness on one side

of the infinite limit, all the

vast indifference on the

other! – No wonder I keep

away from this grim contrast

with a spiritual fervor on me!

Late I go in to the closed church

& am alone with Burne’s Jones’

windows.

That Jacob’s Dream is just the

Symbol of Rottingdean – as in

a cypher its spell is rendered

to the initiated. It is a place

where one lays one’s head on

refl restful turf, where one is

at peace, while a firm

ladder rises from the downs,

& angels rustle up & down.

There is no effort for the mind –

it sleeps & is full of wings

& presences.

I like that St. Michael, with the

dear aestheticism of the eighties

about him – his eyes wide

like Tristan’s – his blood-red

shield & plume & banner – in

the folds of the banner the

Dove spread in blessing.

And I like Michael’s business.

Like fight with against the jewelled

malevolence – the little Dragon.

Michael has been just before me, & loves

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 185; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 92r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_185.jpg

[E.C.]

the little Coming of Gabriel [?]– it gives

the trouble of the annunciation

(“she was troubled”) – the Angel not

yet being through the door.

As we return home together it

is written on Michael’s heart

that we should try to get the

promise of a grave here on

St. Michael’s ground.

Death is so different if all its details

are conquered beforehand.

We should like to enrich this

little church in some way, & to

lie near it & the great Dream for

those who are dead that flashes

from its wall – Lux perpetua.

Michael has written to the

clergyman to come & see us.

Wednesday June 8th

The Wind – but of gray plumage.

Amy may come for two days –

she has left us wondering . . .

We have been passing by the mowing-

-grass – the aristocratic clover holds

itself veiled from the multitude, but

in high-set colonies the buds of

ox-eyed daisy grow white, as

proudly. For the rest, flowers of

no race – beloved hawksweeds

& the like – shoot up in a few

hours.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 186; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 92v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_186.jpg

[E.C.]

Michael writes –

Dear Painter,

I have nothing to record, but a long, wakeful

night. I was left clear-brained by

the tossing wind. Through the long

hours the nightingale & the cock

sang to me. The occasional re-

-minder of Time &[?] cheerfulness

& not betraying rose up so[?]

wholesomely against the long,

liquid vibration of that other

throat. The nightingale’s song

comes up from a chalice of

rich liquor; it proceeds from

wine. There is no lament in it &

the Greek story is all wrong.

I have privately preserved at the

old florist’s a bed of ranunculus

for you – the pale lemon flowers

we love won’t come out. Some

shall come out in sheer terror at

Michael’s will – to manifest

to you that Rottingdean remembers

your feet of flame.

_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ .

Painter, I like to hear of your plays.

Soon you will be write some.

But first I want you to paint me

“a Flight into Egypt”. There was one

at East Grimstead that consoled me.

The Mother with the Babe all to herself –

& that Babe a predestined God – the

way by wh: she travels, unknown, yet

provided for – St. Joseph, careful,

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 187; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 93r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_187.jpg

[E.C.]

anxious & allotted . . .

How mad are the artists to take such

disquieting disgusting instants as

the “Noli me tangere” or Transfiguration,

where everything is embarrassing &

contorted . . . .

Forgive me for being dull – it is that

night with the nightingales!

Michael.

Amy comes in the wandering cab

after lunch, before the letter announcing

her. The first windy walk up

the White Way leaves her silent

from any expression of fealty to

Rottingdean.

Thursday

While Michael & Amy are sea-gazing

Mrs Johnson comes in to tell me

Rudyard is returning & will build

a house on his own site, next

but one to Lady Burne Jones’.

So Rottingdean will have its

potentate as well as its Genius

Loci. I am excited at this

triumph for the little place.

And we hear that the old house

above the Church – The Challoners[?]

will soon be to let. It has a

heavily-pannelled room & a

chimney-stack through one of the

bedrooms, & a scullery where old

farmers dank⟨drank⟩ as the dramatists at

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 188; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 93v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_188.jpg

[E.C.]

“the Mermaid”.

We have a destined feeling of

home at Rottingdean.

. . . I wander by myself in the

grass – ⟨coming?⟩ rain as from a vase

makes the breeze cool.

I return to the Death-scene of

Tristan & almost finish the

new version.

Michael brings me violet fleurs-

de-luce & white roses.

The clergyman comes to see

Michael – a pleasant interview.

Unless one of us dies here he

cannot undertake our burial –

but if we were to die ⟨here⟩ the grave

cd be made large enoght ⟨enough⟩ for

both. Not even to parishioners can

he promise any special site . . .

so we must hurry here for our

end or live here.

Now the rain is come, as it always

does, giving the shy sense of

a stranger to the atmosphere

– that becomes subdued &

delicately mannered.

Friday

Amy has a sog of heat to bear –

I am very bad inside & house-bound.

A silly letter from Tommy, suggestive[?]

that through a woman he could

get an opportunity of reading a play

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 189; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 94r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_189.jpg

[E.C.]

of airs to a Junior Partner – he

also a budding poet. If he is

interested he will ensure the play

having a good hearing with

his senior –

Michael replies –

“Merciful heavens, how can we

thank you for this opportunity of

being read by a “budding poet”!

Out of the mouths of these babes

& sucklings wd you perfect our

praise? Not for one instant

would I abide being sniffed

at by these doubtful tomorrows,

not one of them capable of

considering the matter in

hand. Surely you forget who

have welcomed us, who have

given us their homage.

Browning told us to wait 50 years,

& apparently we must wait.

I asked you to help me, & you

have diligently tried – but on

impossible methods – as if you

should propose the pawn broker

to me if I were in sore straits

for money.

Like the Duke in My Last Duchess

I choose never to stoop.

But I choose to publish

Tristan, & I will.

Sincerely yours

Michael

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 190; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 94v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_190.jpg

[E.C.]

Saturday

Amy leaves us, after an affectionate,

little visit – very sweet.

We go out for a long walk

up the Lewis high road into the

folds of the Downs – the walk

Amy loved yesterday.

There is rain about, & rain over

downs is stealthiness over solitude.

One is haunted.

Then the rain steals out of

apprehension, & a wonderful

singing of birds at a height from

the ground, as it seems, of the

tall grasses, takes its place.

The great downs are tawny or

dove – they lie so soft & wide.

Here one learns that solitude

has wings – they are stretched

out here, where she sleeps –

we can measure their

pinion-breadth, we can stroke

their irised plumage with

our vision.

There are hollows where a

God could lie naked & create,

because his dreams are ⟨would be⟩ so

generative.

This country ⟨of downs⟩ is perfect for us

while we are incarnating

Dianne. She was ample & plastic

as they. If[?] a base or evil thing

had to be done, she brought[?] it, by

the great art of her amplitude & sculpture

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 191; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 95r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_192.jpg

[E.C.]

into a noble relation that purified

it, as the Downs transmute a

turnip-field. There was air on

the bosom of all her deeds – light

over them & a lovely gravity.

Sunday, June 12 th

My new version of the Death-scene of

Tristan is read to Michael. She

realises at once it is under

command of necessity up to the moment

when Tristan’s hand falls through

the hollow of his harp . . after

that . . . . well, anticlimax

reigns. In a few moments she

ends the scene – self-same with

its beginning. The whole is an

entirely new end to poor

Tristan’s agony. Laus Dei!

The loveliness of today is heart-rending

because we have to leave Rottingdean.

Oh, why is the sunshine so sweet

a flood – & the air, why is it of

God’s nostrils – Why is the note

of today In the Beginning – &

we must go?

We sit at sun-slope hour behind a

rick – the summer lies on the

grass of grain, on the winy[?] clover-

studs. Michael gathers holy clover

– & we talk of Dianne in the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 192; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 95v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_192.jpg

[E.C.]

severe[?] gentleness of the hour.

Monday June 13th

Our last day, & as if to help us

a hot & cold South-Easter blows

on our nerves. A cold sweat

of mist comes up from the

sea – I put together the

scenes of Dianne with Palissy

& Goujon[?], but the day is

not of Art. We grows nasty

with weather.

After the fret of packing &

paying, we go to the Dianne

Downs, round High Barn.

How great is this Earth, that has

to ripen & shed itself of its crops,

to receive the furrow & the

seed before we are likely to look

on it again in October – yet

there is calm without the least

accent of hurry – trust &

pervasiveness at their highest.

I think my life in these terms

&[?] try to fix it to their influence.

Then I think of Dianne, so

tranquil when her King is dead –

like the moon, full to completion

of the dead sun’s light – a

world in herself. I see her as

I shall part from her – in the

moonlight that is as her orbed

remembrance of the glory of

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 193; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 96r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_193.jpg

[E.C.]

her love – she fills the world

with her vital mourning,

with her plastic light

of consolation. She is the

moon left in Love’s Universe.

We see a ring-dove by itself – in

a small cage.

We see a great dog running &

a rabbit – they are more like

two elements than two

creatures in the play of their

passion & rapidity.

We see tufts of sainfoin

here & there, a tartness of

carmine in their just-opened

pea-blossoms.

We hear the folded sheep as

they ba ang⟨ba-a: it is⟩ like the clanging

of iron bells &[?] & the chittering

of silver bells as ewes are

answered by lambs.

We walk on the dim cut

grass by the side of an elf-forest

of wheat-stems & leaves – the

dim & the sturdy sharp over

against each other.

We come home to a delicious

dinner – the chop & tomatoes

& the gooseberry-tart are sweet &

sturdy in effect as the wheat-field

– we long to have more

containing[?] admiration – so good

they are!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 194; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 96v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_194.jpg

[E.C.]

Fay is in Paris, gone after Les Primatives

[????], the new disease –

We must not be surprised to see

him next Sunday, not to sup.

Well – I must go to my bed now –

I have been bothered by moths . . .

Ah, if I could only stay on at

Rottingdean & go on with Dianne!

This little place is the Lourdes of

Imagination – it loses all its

ailments, walks & sings.

June 14th

We part from Rottingdean on a

a day of sultry westerliness.

Dear Mrs Johnson continues humanly

the effect of the Downs themselves

on us till we leave Brighton Station.

Then we unfold her egg-

sandwiches, & their nourishing

gentleness continues her influence.

We are delayed by Ascot[?] trains.

The air is morose with heat &

damp.

Rush, the soldier, has proved dastardly

in faithlessness & forsaken the

dogs.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 195; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 97r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_195.jpg

[E.C.]

Never has Paragon been such a

white economy of loveliness

among its manifold leaves & its

stretched curtains of roses.

The green & white striped curtains ⟨hangings⟩

are clean & the matting like a

Jap. Welcome to the New Year.

The Maids have had a portrait

of Music whom they guard under

ivy wall, most successfully

taken by Herbert – all so

grateful & lovely, yet I am

sad. The air weighs on

nerves I must confess

turned parlous[?]. How hateful

are the follies that play about

over the abyss, when nerves

are chaotic.

I put irises of brown banners

in Murano glass – This

does not comfort me.

We sleep in blankets of

combed wool, on feathers

piled like the living breast

. . . in vain! I wake to

Lease – No Rush – Summer

haunt – Publisher & c..

June 15th

But after a few hours collapse

the new force asserts itself.

Michael seeks town – I work

out our accounts . . . there is great

improvement this June.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 196; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 97v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_196.jpg

[E.C.]

I take Whym on the Towing-path,

meet the Rivett-Carnacs, look

at their old garden roses next

door, bring Lady Rivett into

our garden with its new

ramblers – its curtains of

glowing hybrid-teas, & after

she has left me, I cut

roses, bringing in an

aromatic heap that challenges

vision & nostrils alike.

I am really happy today, as I

always am when not bothering

about leaving Paragon.

The joys of faith seem to be

vouchsafed when one does

not seek to betray one’s heart

that loves Paragon.

Lady Rivett says whenever

Sir James is limp[?] he swears

he will let the house – As soon

as ever he is better no power

will make him reject it.

‘Oh, you’ll stay, you will see!”

Michael comes back from the

Peacock Room – charmed by

this little cosmos of the Eighties

– the peacock on one side repeated

in the mirror opposite, as sole

effect on that wall such

an exquisite bit of economy in joy!

She must write of the Peacock.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 197; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 98r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_197.jpg

[E.C.]

And[?] then she went on[?] to the Siennese

Exhibition, &[?] has made me

laugh with the fantastical

self-revolted attitude

the madamas. Their baby

has been suckled on suet-

dumpling. Michael was

tired & her mind simply

vicious toward the poor

Siennese.

[K.B.]

Paragon June 18th.

My Beloved is as brave as a Japp. Controlling

nerves, she has been with me in town

& again at Tommy’s to tea. Eye-bright happiness

is with Marie. From Marie’s Mother I

learn how Eliza Gérante[?] died. God is pitiless

to his Virgin old. They die in solitude.

She died in sleep. That is to die unawares.

I love my Paragon, I love the shrine, for the

rest I am as dumb as a Midsummer

bird.

[E.C.]

Thursday, June 6 th

To town to see Whistler’s Peacock

Room; magnificent tour de

genie! Ah! How good it was to

be alive in the late 70 Seventies

& the Eighties – such enthusiasm,

such adventure & romance

in Art – The Japanese Victory –

The Aesthetic Triumphus[?] – all

the Artists fantastic & gallant,

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 198; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 98v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_198.jpg

[E.C.]

yet always artists! And I

was young.

Dear Peacock Room! Typical

of our Inspirer, the Peacock,

the bird of the great Queen

of Heaven. He set our scheme

of colour, he watched us

from his bronzes as we

accomplished our Dream

in our little Rooms – his

blue was our firmament,

his green our Earth, &

we knew of no nb

nimbus so victorious as

his – the glory of the saints

& the Rose of Paradise were

melted into one gilded

flush of rays for this Paraclite

of AEstheticism.

And here Whistler has set him

up for the Ages – superhuman

as a Buddha. On the shutters

we have him swelled into

godhood – his tail became[?]

a second heaven, his eyes

at last one eye – that of the

World, or of God.

He is the fountain reaching

Heaven from its earthly source.

He is Vision having reached

Wath Wordsworth’s “bliss of

Solitude. Then on the great

Wall panel we have his

drama, set religiously before

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 199; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 99r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_199.jpg

[E.C.]

us in gold. Here as Oberon &

Titania he braves his mate,

his double, & she braves him!

Mutual jewels flash at each

other from their eyes as

they shriek –

“Well⟨Ill⟩ met by moonlight, proud Titania.”

What, jealous Oberon!

Tarry, rash wanton: and I not thy lord?

Then I must be thy lady!"

So the great drama of passion goes on

among liquid stars licked-up

stars, flashed phospor, eclipses of

crescents, frecklings, streaks, bars

& golden mail, such as

convulsed Lamia.

And every where over the common

-place, uninspired Room the

divine peacock exhibits an

epos of his power – dazzling

thin form with iris-colour,

filling corners of dizziness

with the glance of half an

eye, the roguish divinity! – yet

never forgetting the pomp of

his Essence, the amplitude – not

for the second of a moment.

Hail Whistler, Court-Painter to the

divine Bird of Heaven! What Jap.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 200; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 99v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_200.jpg

[E.C.]

sence of the value of spaciousness –

⟨& of⟩ that suggestion of the

illimitable in Nature by a

detail of Art – a symbol!

Every decorative stroke is

organic. I have seen nothing

in Jap. Art more vital than

the angry trains of the

mates – not lashing the

eye into sympathy by line

only, but by organism – &

decorative life in the mass.

All Hail, holy Peacock – Bird of

Rossettian Creation – Bird

of the Japanese Victory in

the Nineteenth Century!

And this Peacock Temple &

its ichons[?] is going to leave

us for the New World that

never knew our native

ecstasy!

Ave . . atque vale!

We have an afternoon hour with

the Sienese School at the

Burlington Fine Art.

The Early Sienese in the Subject-pictures

have a passionate emotion that

has is expressed with sensitiveness

too austere in the best Masters to

be hysterical – yet a thing of

beauty & of the nerves.

The attitudes have an emotional

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 201; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 100r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_201.jpg

[E.C.]

value in some of Duccio’s works &

Lorenzetti’s that a great

actor might be inspired with.

The Renson[?] Dussios & the Crawford

Crucifixion are dangerously charged

with realisation of the heart.

But how noble – how feelingly

rich the contour of his Christ’s

head!

The Simone Martini from Liverpool

“Christ returning from the Doctors to

his Parents” is a delicious picture –

both in heart and Humor.

Poor St. Joseph! he finds it a

business to bring together the

sullen fair-haired God-boy

& that Mother looking up

queenly from her book of Hours.

We have looked in on just had

a glimpse of Holman Hunt’s new

version of the Light of the World –

it us a jumble of Vision &

Illustration. The face & set

of the form are intensely beheld –

all the rest is an appeal

to sentiment. Even the figure

& face make appeal – How

different all this from a

Sienese panel (attributed by

Langton Douglas to Bernard da

Siena – whoever that may be)

of a Christ in seamless red

robe – with lines sweeping as

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 202; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 100v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_202.jpg

[E.C.]

Mountain-lines[?] who tramps

the Universe with his Cross,

immutable in sacrifice, calm

under his

paramount destiny –

followed by the prayers of a

little monk no more asking

them than the sun fulfilling

his course or any other

journeying element.

He steps on, the Cruciferous

– the God – the timeless.

The Liverpool Preaching of S. Bernardino

– whoever painted it – is a little

gem of life & life’s jewelry.

The blown trumpets by the

high altar give a glorious

sense of Voice to the old

man’s sermon.

Two portraits of Women – the

Maid[?] bust by Matteo di Giovanni

& a full face attributed to

Benvenuto di Giovanni – are finely

dressed & deserve study for

detail as well as for their

very direct drawing.

Then at the end I came on

delightful Beccafumi in his

Clelia. Strange how Siena

caught colour & movement

as on a breeze at the end

of its art-life in Beccafumi

– as mightier Venice did

in mightier Tiepolo!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 203; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 101r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_203.jpg

[E.C.]

Friday, June 17 th

We pay Tommy a visit. We are

forced by train to be early – We

find Tommy in proof, so

we wait in the pleasant

green drawing-room while he

gets into print. There is a

lily growing in the corner. I

feel as if a ghost from Paragon

hung[?] there.

Marie comes in – a topaz.

Yes, she is a topaz! “Her ⟨bright⟩ eyes

Reign influence & cheat the skies”

She has shone herself into

–marriage.

She has on the dazzling pendant

of Fay – a loveliest Psyche &

Cerberus, well-necked, among

scattered garish light of

sapphires, carbuncles, sky-blue

enamel, emeralds, a rose-

topaz.

Old Mrs Appia tells comfortable

things of Miss Gérante’s end.

She, of course, expected Michael

to wear a bonnet & protestant

elderly strings . . . She sees a

fiendishly gay creature in

a black & white Dürer Dress &

a wreath of little white pompon-

roses! Lutherism has too much

of the art art-nature to endure

such disillusion. Tommy’s

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 204; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 101v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_204.jpg

[E.C.]

oyster-white Room has the glory

of The Samaritan on its

walls. Ah! The sky is more

broken & more lovely, but

the wholeness of mood in

the compassionate head

& the sky as at first painted

is gone for ever.

Sunday - June 19th

Fay comes – not fresh, but stale

from the Primatives. The

love of one’s life becomes a

momentary torture in face

of the Paris motors &c.

Both the Fellows are out of

sorts & snappish.

I receive Fay & we sit & talk

ailments . . . to us enters

Michael in Dürer dress,

charming hat of little white

roses on profound black straw;

& with some Blush Ramblers

in her hand – Poor Michael!

As she says after the found

the two beings she loves best

in the world sad & [????]⟨ [????]⟩ [????],

like very old people. Her work

is before her & her wreath ⟨on her⟩

she does it⟨her work⟩ – the visit is made!

The Wreath does it, & admiration,

are of the elements in life, is

graciously present.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 205; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 102r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_205.jpg

[E.C.]

We speak of retiring to Rottingdean

by & bye – not yet. “It must be

never” rules Fay, & explains thus

the irony of his old remark

on residence at Rottingdean

“How intelligent!”

Fay brings as gift his Bibliography247

of the Vale Press – a work

as haughty & cock-sure as

Swinburne’s preface to his

Works.

Something turns conversation

to the feeling of smallness one

has in a crowd, & Fay, with

that gravity wh: is an emotional

value in itself, speaks of the

depressing tragedy of a crowd. It

is not that he pities, or has

any active charity toward it –

No, it is a sense as general as

that of going through a grave-

yard & reading the epitaphs.

A Motion of terror comes over

the one at the thought of the

place taken up by these, the trouble

to feed & clothe them, to keep

them alive for such a little

time & to so little purpose.

And it is terrible to belong to

such a race, with its brevity &

fuss, & the inconsequence of its

lives. The voice we listened to

took on a gray timbre, like a

curfew – a sense of style on the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 206; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 102v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_206.jpg

[E.C.]

air.

When we come upstairs, Michael,

fearing restless behaviour from

Chow shuts him out by one

door . . . the little flame of

a creature comes in by

the other. Fay springs up &

opens the door again most

severely; but Chow stands

& looks, & Painter looks at

him. I shall always see

the bland duel – Painter

yielding to the sovereign

quiet of marvel in Chow’s

gaze. Routed he suggests

“The Balcony, Chow!”

And the passage of arms

between the peers is a thing

of the past & of memory.

Michael is found out to be so

innocent she confesses

ingeniously to these crimes –

(a)248 She sacrificed her Fellow to

a mother-in-law (Mrs A.)

(b) She asked a Bride if she saw

much of these Artists – a Bride

who shd never think of anyone

but her husband.

(c) She sent out an innocent

Boy – Herbert – with two corrupted

Dogs (Rush, having habituated

them to the Bar at “the Pigeons”)

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 207; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 103r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_207.jpg

[E.C.]

“success”, Fay remarks, “is always

innocent” – à propos of Gladys

Deacon’s wicked French Songs.

Ah me! Painter posted 14 letters

on his way here! What is

becoming of our hermit?

And all next week he is

deep in engagements.

He has been deeply interested in

Herbert Spencer’s Autobiography

– it has explained to him so

many things in the English

middle-class mind that he

has never understood – the

genesis of so many of the minds

that issue even into distinction

from the middle-class.

June 24th Midsummer Day.

The weather is the very atmosphere

of this[?] day seven years ago – we

are in the gold, in the pregnant

silentess[?] – even solitude – of deep

heat – among the roses & the

haunted air of veritable

Midsummer. What a figure of

Romance the dear Father’s was!

With all his living passions warm

under the tent of his silver hair

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 208; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 103v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_208.jpg

[E.C.]

he went on into the Unknown,

lonely as the desert Saint,

magical as a Fairy Thrall

– on this day of strange

contrasts to the imagination.

Amy has sent from the Manor

Garden a box of Martagon

lilies – creatures of lustrous

mourning purple, denizens

of the Swiss Knolls, con-

-necting England & Zermatt,

at a time when we feel that

The Matterhorn is the

mountain of a dream

country, where Tragedies[?] have

their immortal being.

What privilege to think of

one’s dead in a mountain

country – so far from the

death-bed, the medicine-bottle –

in the amplitude of air, in

sight of everlasting snow,

waiting to become wholly

of Nature, under cover & under

the blossom-dropping charities

of a forest.

There was ⟨were⟩ in Father the personality

& the Epic characteristics that

would have made him ⟨in the early world⟩ a

Hero or genius to be worshipped

with the untouched victim

due to the dead. Fascination

would have hung round his

dark ritual – his grave would

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 209; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 104r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_209.jpg

[E.C.]

have prophecied. He was strong in

kinship with the Fates, & he was

faithful as those are who

centre an[?] influence.

He has not left a memory, but

a spell.

The men we know all believe

that a woman’s one need is

to love a man – that is enough,

for it is her ideal.

They think . . .

But woman’s own ideal is to

be loved – she wants herself

infinitely surpassed, her

power of loving left behind

by that in man. This is why

she is religious & Christian –

this is why the man who loves

is her adoration, & her dream.

Father had this talisman –

he loved. Sorrow & bitterness

& jealousy made desolation

round his love – but the women

he loved never forgot his love.

It is a prodigy – like a well

of sweet water in the midst

of the Sahara. Is the living

oasis ever forgotten – is it not

pondered on & dreamt of by

the wanderers over thirsty land?

He had ⟨in his degree & as a lover⟩ the Great Secret by wh: the

Son of God bewitches a universe.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 210; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 104v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_210.jpg

[E.C.]

Michael & I have been on the Towing-

-path & seen a steam-launch full

of holiday-makers loose from

the key & quay & away!

It is so hot, the heat throws

itself down under clouds

to drouse.

The flowers have an

apprehensive sense of their

frailty – one sees their

dread in the midst of

their beauty.

I mun I must now return to

Tuesday, June 21st – when we

visited Van Wisselingh’s little

gallery & found Fay there a

Master.

His Victim is suggested by the

woodcut in The Parables –

but there the noble figure is

shut in by the violence, the

ribaldry of the crowd – Now

the figure in the Act of Sacrifice,

is set before blue mountain-

hollows, & an ideal escape

into the limitless is provided

by Nature. The toss of the

Bacchant-crowd is rendered

in a large style, the colour is

glorious – of the October

Vineyard in its browns & smouldering

reds. I hear the figure on the barrel

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 211; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 105r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_211.jpg

[E.C.]

is held to be unaccounted for, & in

pictorial treatment that rejects

facial expression, the leering

Demos[?] on his Tub (of The

Parables) is not recognisable

in the bowed down head

of this other. Here we have the

stupid awe – a sort of animal

contrition – the crowd shows

when its destruction ⟨of a noble thing⟩ is

over. This sin-laden

habitude in Kin the Ring-

leader’s figure with the

careless blank child beside

it, seems to me a piece

of fine stability in the Conception

of the picture.

But the Victim is Sacrifice

– he is an incarnated

Act, felt perhaps more profoundly

because he does not hang

as is usually on the Cross, but

is giving himself to death more

actively, with the air &

mountains beyond his pain.

The picture abides on the heart, where

it has vision.

There is a little Centaur-Picture.

The young body of the Beloved reaches

up, among the careful hoofs, to

the Centaur’s mouth in a kiss

that springs from the ground

to the height of its own life – a

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 212; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 105v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_212.jpg

[E.C.]

fountain’s attainment.

Again in this little thing as in

all Fay’s work the construction

of the picture is emotional

– & therefore we have a

noble organic Art, an

inbeing[?] that shapes every

detail, that dominates colour.

Cold little thing! – how his

work moves me!

There is the Shannon of The

Bathers, I have seen twice – also

two little groups of women

against gray, with in lovely

attitudes, kept simple by

their intimacy. A lemon

as the omphalus[?] of one

design is an enchanting

motive of colour.

His picture from the Apple-

Orchard lithograph is

debonnair – the colour festive

in a midsummer way, but

the mystery, the heart of

the mystery – is gone.

Shannon’s pictures are self-

reliant; Fay’s are polarized

from a source of Emotion –

Shannon’s never take you

beyond their own beauty – Fay’s

strike you as with the

breadth of a universe.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 213; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 106r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_213.jpg

[E.C.]

In the same gallery there is a

miracle – a Daumier sketch

of Sancho Panza solid on his

ass, that stands motionless

as a little cloud of the night,

& Don Quixote, flying through

the rocky valley in a very

moon-shine of rapid motion

– all full of suggestion

& infinite in its rhapsody.

A Monticelli landscape – a rare

delight – has a breast of Earth

moulded with love, & a

tree that stands forth as

in the land of the Eternal

Ideas – a tree & a dream.

At Toplady’s I buy an Egyptian

amber necklace for my Love – fair in colour

⟨as the evening-primrose.⟩249

On Wed. June 21 – we meet a

cousin at Louie Ellis’. –a thorn-

bush. The pretty lunch in Louie’s

red dining-room has the blight

over it only kinship knows how

to spread . . . Still more doleful

Hertford House – Individualism

in a collection is a failure –

there is the monotony of one

mind, of one effort in this

house of Sèvres[?], among these

crowded pictures. Even the

Frenchmen cannot make joy

dance in one – only the profound

& melancholy Velasquez – “The

[Page]

Lady with a Fan” can arrest

I learn how to finish the

The Sultan has had the bad

Tuesd Sunday June 26th

Tommy & Marie came to supper.

The pendant the [????]

pendant glows, ⟨its rose jewels⟩ like the
