on southern azure.

Tuesday, June 28th

Dr Will Sturge comes down –

He demonstrates my trouble

is functional not organic, but,

spite of his wise presence he

makes the mistake of telling

too many tales of sudden accidents

to motor & sensory nerves –

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 215; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 107r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_215.jpg

[E.C.]

he speaks of ⟨“a⟩ warning”, & the twilight

time ⟨of life⟩ I am entering, after

full-work time. He leaves us

well-assured & thoroughly unstrung.

So may wisdom err.

Thursday, June 30 th

We dine at the Palace – The air

of the evening is as the touch

of amber – safe, immortal

softness. And the welcome

at the Palace! – Roses, stocks

muted in purple as if sea-pearl

were over their dye, mignonette –

a Feast, carefully bounteous –

asparagus that has been

fetched from Bond Street

in the sun. Shannon looks

fine in his summer lightness

of dress – the touch of austerity

is broken by it, & his form

touches Greek grace again.

Painter –

[K.B.]

July 13th The Forest

It is Emory Down[?] forest – the heart

& centre – the oak leaves making

a very crown, all round our head.

With all on broken nerve-ends we

strolled into the forest –

“And valley lawns beneath the waving trees.”

What glades, what golden beeches!

We plunge. Ivy-leaved verenicu[?]⟨campanula⟩ meets

us at the entrance – then the

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 216; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 107v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_216.jpg

[K.B.]

lucky vervain.

In the evening, we seek again

the forest. “Henry”, I have found⟨spied⟩ a spiritual

-lawn”, I cry – & Henry drops down into

sylvan[?] gold. We are very happy:

Henry fills me with most strong delight

by smiling – Diane is in these shades.

Saturday

To-day every thing is changed; cruel

south thunder-gales have swept

through the land.

[E.C.]

July 20th Wed.

Yes, the Forest here is Over-forest –

(Über-wald) a super-sylvan

magnificence. The sun is in

a creek of forest – all the

great oaks & beeches besiege us.

Last night the lightning flushed

& tingled the tree-top horizon

& mountain-sides of thunder

fell on us in avalanche.

But we had the great bedroom

illegally taken from us on

Tuesday & we swept – oh, like

Adam on the first moss.

We waked with the wish to

live on our bed. I was stark

& dumb with over-bearing

fatigue when I got here.

The first morning we went along

a rooty path, & at every step

I grew more miserable. At

last I broke down & wept as I

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 217; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 108r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_217.jpg

[E.C.]

rarely do. The same afternoon our

Land-lady said we were near

to Bank. Michael looked at me.

Now we had grown confused in

our minds & had asked in two

letters if Leigh were near – they

replied they did not know

its situation – so we concluded

all was well. But at the

mention of Bank, we realised

our error. By cross-questioning

we discovered that the rooty

path was the woodland way

to Bank. It is indeed strange.

I thought I was going crazy on

that rooty path.

Of course we never go that side

of the woods, & we refer to the

place as “Where the wild Thyme

blows”. I had remarked to

Michael “I like all the woods on

the other side, but I can’t abide

these woods”.

I am not a bit nervous or unhappy

in any other part of the Forest.

On Monday afternoon we drove

round by Stoney Cross to look ⟨in vain⟩ for

rooms. Actually this Kettle-

of-Fish-Year won’t let us have peace

in the Forest & we have to turn

out of our comfortable rooms

on Friday, July 29 th.

Stoney Cross is just the same as 20

years ago – except that the sun is

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 218; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 108v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_218.jpg

[E.C.]

new & exists for the Millionaire &

not for the Poet.

This is one of the Spots on Earth

to show to an Angel.

It was moving to stand after

20 years of work together by

the Rufus stone, with plighted

hands as then. So clear

that living past – as yesterday.

Rather weary to think of that

early fame & the 20 years &

now, except for a very few

of the minds of England, we

live unknown. Sic Transit . . .

yet I felt firmer in real

possession than in those early

days. And we vowed[?]Dianne –

our last forest drama to the

Power that is in forests . . . . .

At this moment roses come from

you & Amy – such wild roses to

break on us in their fresh crimson

& gold, till we are out of countenance

with their reality & think of them

as dream-flowers, as Rosae Mundi.

Such fervancy[?] of buds! Boldre

or Cadenham have no such

tints, no such sweet jets of

summer pulsing among their leaves.

No, no! –

But they have whole nations of

ivy-leaved campanulas, silent bells

lifted under ferns, while the cattle

make fay-music above with their

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 219; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 109r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_219.jpg

[E.C.]

foliage-hidden bells.

And I have never written about

that last night at Paragon –

Bernhard such a sweet little

thing, wholly himself, & living

over with us the days when he

was “so miserable & so happy”

& he was giving us his crude,

young doctrine in its insolence

& glory – the years of the red

cherry of La Grande Chaumière[?].

And now the house is gone &

the cherry-tree: but we the

companions in the spirit remain.

He said the days at Kingshott

last year were some of the happiest

& most precious of his life.

He met us with a kiss on our hands

as they clasped his; & he was

caressing & he admired from the

first “You are beautifully dressed,

Field” he said touching the black

taffeta with black & opal ruches,

that brought Shannon’s instant

acclaim of joy. Michael, in

shimmering-gray Eighteenth ⟨century⟩ gown,

was praised, as she reclined on

the little sofa “How Mme de

Recamier[?]!” At dinner he spoke

of Versailles e–n artiste – deliciously

bringing out its power . . that it would

teach nature a way – give it

a supernatural aim, set before it

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 220; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 109v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_220.jpg

[E.C.]

the ideal of arcade, arbour, grotto,

fountain. He was staying with

Miss Marbury – the great entre-[?]

-preneuse[?], to whom Oscar give

us a letter. He found her a

large creature, full of life &

life’s experience – a business-

woman, with a massive

Beyond. [ I wonder, if after all,

she could do anything for us ]250

She lives at Versailles, & all

the secrets of the ideal proposed

to Nature, all the more hidden

persuasions to its wildness to

become art were open to

Bernhard.

He talked of poets & painters &

how most of them are

“pockets” of gold – only the very

greatest – veins. Hence their

early work is a moment – they

only iterate after. Swinburne

was ever the poet of Poems &

Ballads, singing of death out

of the very superabundance of

life. So with the Painters of

the salon in 1902-4 . .They were

pockets – they are just where they

were then. But Shakespeare &

Milton in their old experience are

prophetic & not the sum of their

youth.

Then for long we talk of red-cherry

time, & Bernhard confesses how im-

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 221; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 110r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_221.jpg

[E.C.]

portant we were to him – how we cared

for us, but apart from that we

“helped his functioning” – far

more important than anything

else!! His Spanish Countess

now is where we were then –

but he is not exhilarated by

her – he is far away as we

are & therefore we are for more

vivifying. He is not yet able

to work, but he is sure it will

come all right, he feels such

volume of thought-capacity

behind him . . . But all the

while the little thing is thin as

a bird, & seems to go to the air

for his sustenence, having f

left off wine & coffee & most

meats.

Early in the Evening he referred to

having just seen “the one & only

artist” – I stretched mind over

the world; wondered if it were

Rodin, & then Michael solved the

phrase – “Oh, you mean Ricketts”

& we laughed at the rival’s

irony. But just at first the

eyes (that used to be ‘blue

various[?] weather’) looked very

gray, with a thunder-knot in them,

till our greeting & mood told

him he was ascendant.

I am still weary in head, & I find it

impossible to set down the charm

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 222; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 110v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_222.jpg

[E.C.]

of The Doctrine – the mellowness &

soft contrition[?] before the larger

years for the glorious brilliancy

of youth & its inadequacy – the

intimate bond of so many

years between our spirits, the

throwing of himself on the

mercy of our interpretation

& seasoned love, the paths

of his frail appearance &

high laborious dreams.

Religion is more & more to him –

inevitably the Jew. He spoke

of himself as “placqué centre

à l’Éternité.”

We had converse & touched

across infinitude.____

This Valley of trees over wh: the

moon rides at twilight!

We have been here at our

New Forest Inn, Emery Down,

just a week yesterday.

The wide breaks we find

too open for the gods, who only

come close to us in obscurity –

from pressed under-growth, or

profound shadow. Here the

shadows have space to dance

on, & the veiled Divinities

retire to the Forest Enclosures.

Only on the first day did I feel

the steps of Dianne close.

And we are too deep inured[?] in

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 223; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 111r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_223.jpg

[E.C.]

trees for the air of Poetry to reach us.

We must wait till we are in our

new rooms next Friday with their

breezes from over Stoney Cross plain.

Francis is with us – at a word

we lured[?] this tasselled gentle

to our side – he is infinitely right

to live with. No tax on one – less

than that of an animal; even

in mood, humourous in the

reception of the day’s happenings:

hot rapturous & disturbing over

scenery, always with the apt

word & the amenities of

humanism to give art to life.

He is a great acquisition.

This morning he is seeking at

Bank for psychic revelations

concerning Culter – the object

of my spirit-shaking Premonitions.

He suggests that Culter was a

true nom-de-guerre – a Knife.

We drove along Stony Cross plain yesterday

in gray-coated weather, of perfect

tone with the plain, & with the

masses of beech & fir. The air was

as a strong enchantment; & our

aim was Sloden – the old British

Bury⟨ing⟩ ground, with yews above, we

reached from Broomy[?] four years ago.

As before I was spelled by the

valley over wh: Sloden lies down.

The Dead are in it – they mould it

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 224; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 111v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_224.jpg

[E.C.]

appearance by their resting-places

& by their resting from the old

years till now. The yews cling

with their obduracy to the

slope, till the wood is tight

on the ground as a corded

tent. It is dedicated to the

Earth Service – it is awful, it

is close to the soil, low down

on it & sepulchrous! The yew-

-stems flap their skin on their

ancestral thews – like

everlasting snakes casting

their skins to the centuries; &

in the valley itself the curves

have the infinite bountifulness

of the burial-mound – womb-like,

fostering to the imagination.

And there is a width about

the air as if for big souls

to pass about & drink its

ever-renewed freshness.

There is The feeling ⟨is⟩ in it that

Wordsworth has seized in

Ossian’s Grave. The actual features

of the spot come[?] to one as a

Dream comes through sleep –

reaches the brain where it is

remote, where it has seen things

from the beginning of the world.

Whym Chow strained after rabbits –

when we were with him last, every

step was a pl pain at my heart.

How good to move with slowness

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 225; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 112r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_225.jpg

[E.C.]

only & no pain! We must haunt

Sloden & the Dead again.

Being at the heart of the Forest here, we

realise it is a casket of balms

& myrrhs & odorous gums –

it is just a casket of spices, & the

heart of the forest is embalmed.

As we came to it in the evening

its fragrance is solid before us.

Francis is back from Bank. He claims to have

laid the Spectre. No such name as

Culter is or has been known. And the

honour of this user of the Knife is

made free with – his name turned

into the mere producer of knifes –

Cutler (even this re-arrangement

of his written name brings no real

being to the local memories) & at

last the suggestion comes that his

name is that of some lady-lodger.

How are the mighty fallen!

We never thought is might be

the cat-like female assailant, &

I swear, by Hecate, it was not.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 226; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 112v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_226.jpg

[E.C.]

The Second Sunday

The top story of Paragon is finished.

We have heard that Bernhard has

been called to Paris on business.

So not⟨no⟩ Forest meeting! There is

such a small element of

Time in my relation with him

I scarcely feel this check. We

reached the perfect moment

ten days ago & within the

radious radius of its perfection

all time is included. Had he

come fretted to the Forest – had

he come conjoined, not his

single self, all my future

might have become temporal,

that is now infinite.

He returns Tommy’s Poems

unrepentant – he still feels as if

they were rather promising, but

hopelessly unmusical exercises.

The utmost they extract from him

is a certain consent, but with

no warmth.

The last criticism is merited to a

degree – Tommy’s hateful mind chills

the creativeness of his emotion.

But his work is not promising –

it is performance – it is

a little satyr of Pan, not a little

Apollo or Hermes – still the

whole God, born, not in the womb.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 227; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 113r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_227.jpg

[E.C.]

We are cheered by a delightfully

confidential letter from Fay –

Mary’s single visit – the Pelleas &

Melissande of Sarah & Mrs Pat –

these are lightly evoked.

Also by post comes a little

snap-shot of Bernhard – like a

bee just outside the frame of

his Domenico Veneziano (or

Baldovinetti) Madama. He

looks so small, & tiny bee-

thunders are about his brow

& lips – the rich storminess of

a summer buzzer.

We are getting happy in our Forest.

And the Down & brakes behind

Woodside where we go next

Friday are filled with greater

influence – some god has

local habituation there, altho’

we do not know him yet.

The oaks now are rejuvenating –

A colour of sun-burnt health

pulses all over them – a wine

of life is in their shoots.

The quoit-players haunt our grass-

-valley. One hears the quoits ring

as if of glass, while the dew

rises – & the few⟨rare⟩, broad acclaims

of success. One thinks of Discobolus

& of Hyacinthus, & poetry rests, even as

the moon, over the⟨our⟩ grass-valley.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 228; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 113v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_228.jpg

[E.C.]

We have plucked in the bog asphodel-

Spikes – Rufus’ hair.

I read to Francis

“O ancient Love” & c

But it seems to frighten people – they

get under cover & hide from it.

I suppose it is too widely

universal, for most of the

narrow lovers of Earth. They

love “mortal, if thou are beloved”

They⟨Their⟩ flesh touches its own warmth

in that.

I must return to Paragon – rather

to that visit to the Palace I left

unchronicled. It was delicious.

After dinner we were introduced

to 3 new Italian Pictures – one,

Early Tuscan, really noble &

hieractic in effect – a calm Dream

to live with.

My dress of black taffeta, with black

& opal rushes, is welcomed by

Shannon “What a beautiful

dress you are wearing!” The

pendants & jewels return on their

maker’s eyes with fascination.

Shannon takes us to the Shepherd’s

Bush station as guide to the

reeling Cabman, & Fay of course

follows on foot as demi-gods out-

pace mortals. We all wait the

train under a night-sky of so

velvet a texture it suggests fragrance

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 229; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 114r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_229.jpg

[E.C.]

– one seems to smell the softness of

the clouds.

Then on the Tuesday before we started

for the Forest – July 12th – The Artists

dined with us. Mary had got

up a Bach afternoon, & Fay &

Michael met there, & from

thence journeyed to Paragon

together. Unfortunately the

difficult great music had wrought

Fay to nervous fatigue & headache.

He looked white, as if dying

in mind, at his arrival, though

he was so excited he poured out

a stream of talk on Bach.

A prelude he heard was like

the outpouring of a bag of

jewels – dusk, with here &

there one flash to measure

the wealth of the cold gem-

cascade. Bach composes on the

brain itself, his music is organic

only on that instrument – as

some music is only organic on

the heart, or the nerve-centres.

He is the most taxing of all

musicians – his high demand is

almost of super-human quality.

When we dine the heat & the

festive dishes, meeting Bach in

the poor Painter’s body, produce

a deadness of nausea – we

quite fear the worst. But he revives.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 230; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 114v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_230.jpg

[E.C.]

Still the evening is spoiled by that

exacting Bach, though Shannon

is ruddily[?] merry & charming, almost

as in his youth. The talk after

dinner is obliterated from my

mind by anxiety & by the deadly

heat.

Such a terrible kettle-of-fish

week before we attained the

forest – contracts, the lease,

the packing, the arrangements

for 6 weeks’ absence, money

arrangements, two dinners

for our two rarest friends . . .

We were more than half dead

in the July hotness.

We read Hudson on the new

Forest Animals – on the voles,

the handsome hornets, the

lady-glow-worms who glow till

they frightened the male, & then

glow till they are lost in the

dimness of the wife. He tells

of the dead snake-skin that

for years casts its scales &

[????] becomes bright with spring.

What similes!

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 231; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 115r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_231.jpg

[E.C.]

Tuesday, July 26th

We drove in beaver-grayness through

Boldrewood & over Stony Cross Plain.

The small crab-apples I remember

so well on the road between Stony

Cross & Mark Ash at the point where

the driver mentioned the name

Bank & a horror fell on me – are

still there, small & cloaked with

pale red – tho’ I have not seen

them for 20 years.

As we drive over the rough-coated

plain a vast cloud of purple begins

to grow – a low-down purple that

has weeping as its promise. This

sense of tears on a great landscape-

verge is most moving. Michael

is absorbed in the greatness of

the influence & drives on, on – round

by Stoney Cross itself – a mist is

on us; & over the new Inn, that

desecrates the spot where⟨our⟩William

Rufus was born, a sheet of fire.

Then fire out of a sick vapour of

tempest – such⟨a⟩ rain, as⟨that⟩ runs

down the Professor’s ears, as if

from gargoyles & makes his chest

a bog. Our one thought is of hot

water & hot brandy & a fire.

Wednesday And all day the after-

rain of thunder drips und into the

soaked trees. Michael & Francis have

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 232; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 115v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_232.jpg

[E.C.]

a walk to Akers Down - of⟨to⟩ the exquisite

view in wh: Stoney Cross is reborn.

Meanwhile I place Henri & Dianne

in our New Forest, & all the fresh

sylvan discoveries we have made

throng[?] round their love at Anet.

Thursday

We have a glorious drive – mid-glory

of the Forest, before Francis leaves us:

The Manor, Castle Malwood,

Stoney-Cross (where we find with a

jolly M rs Whitehorn a set of cottage

-rooms engaged for August &

garnished with a snarly dog – alas!)

Rufus Stones (for Francis) Bramley

Woods & Broomy Enclosure – a

world of driven cloud, of sun-covered

wilderness, & trees in their own

expanses of light – the firs blue,

the hollies argent-dark, the

beeches tawny, the oaks rubied

with a new spring of leaflets.

Such air – such laughter!

The “peeps” at Castle Malwood have

the gracious civility of Italian

-Garden Art.

All morning we have been arranging

“The Tragedy of Pardon” – Tristan – to

send to Milsted (of Duckworth & Co.)

at Tommy’s suggestion.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 233; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 116r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_233.jpg

[K.B.]

July 29thWoodside, Emery Down.

The Professor leaves a weeping forest

unwilling to pack trimly for a 5 minutes’

transit, we let the live sponges

leap about in the baruche.

I have never felt so like sobbing

over my boxes – full of the “broken

meat” of our bottles & clothes.

It is a day of awful jostle & damp,

& towards evening, I fall ill.

Through an an⟨a⟩tmosphere still bleeding

vapours I drag myself to the past; –

then, perforce I must turn to the

sun, & its cheery sign – the glade, the

firm, fragrant high-road, the sandy

bank, the hem uncertain line of

railing, on wh: the mag-pie perched, to

the forest. Black swine[?] from Bank

grunt across the stream. All this

fair lot was ours yesterday – I still

see the glint of the Professor’s dress

-shirt, as we paced the glade, – the

sand-bank, the birds, the little noises

among the leaves, – all were ours.

Henry likes the modern rooms with

the round cherry-tree in front –

I cannot – for me the deep

humanity of an inn!

At Duckworth’s they are reading

“O ancient Love of Chaos bred”

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 234; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 116v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_234.jpg

[E.C.]

July 30th

A great letter from Painter –

– Oh, enchanting!

In response to a letter from Michael,

in which she said the real meaning

of Christ’s saying “Depart from me,

ye that work iniquity!” was

“Depart all ye that are out of

touch with me” – Painter comes

into magnetic touch with the

Poet.

“I have news. I have turned

sculptor. I have modelled a

man & a horse & now quite

understand the rather youthful

attitude of the Deity on the 7th

day when he saw that it was

good. Clay is a divine substance,

responsive, attentive, definite yet

liable to improvement also. I think

man must have been modelled

in some less admirable & ductile

stuff. In a few days my two

masterpieces will be cast in bronze

& be ready for sonets sonnets & epigrams.

One of the statuettes represents an

actor with a mask; the second a

Centaur with a sleeping baby-faun.

Tomorrow I shall make a weeping

Terminal, & tomorrow more Centaurs

and an Atys, & a dawn of Venus,

with her feet on the chest of a Triton,

& a drinking Sphinx, & a Poet bearing

his Chimera & a lot of “Goshey[?]” things.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 235; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 117r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_235.jpg

[E.C.]

The carpets in the pink drawing-room

look like a battlefield of dusty

foot-prints (the feet of the sculptor

are not beautiful) I have been

working like a negro, unable, in

fact, to stop away.

I hope you are well.

Yours, the Painter.

This letter blows from the Islands of

Youth – a fresh Art! What is a

fresh love to that?

When we came to our fr new

quarters here yesterday in the

torrent of rain I fell at the

door-step & wrenched wrenched my

garnet necklace – the rain continued

black; Michael became ill &

I numbed with anxiety & forlornness.

But we woke to the dairy-fragrance

of the air at dawn & to the

great leaves & Kaleidoscopic spaces

of pointed light, & to the the birds

& motionlessness of a great cherry-

tree. We had a saved feeling –

And this morning we ate cake at the

dear Inn, & traversed the lovely Boldre-

-wood high-road again, our chief

path with the Prof. – then rain –

then this afternoon a drive over

the Plain in thunder-showers, enjoying

the crisp dripping crispness of

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 236; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 117v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_236.jpg

[E.C.]

the fern. We almost slept in the

softness, with wet faces. After

that we met a storm-veiled

sun toward the West of Akers Down.

– It is the hour when autumn oaks re-bud,

Their farthest branches red, as if a priest

Had struck them into sacrificial blood

To scatter all the forest. –

Michael has been dreaming of

sea-mice.

And Painter is a Sculptor, &

divinely happy.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 237; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 118r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_237.jpg

[K.B.]

I write to Painter

This is of the god! It is subtle,

irresistible; it does not answer to the words: [?]

that you are a Sculptor – it is indeed news –

tidings rather, & of the kind that makes

a ruffle among the angels.

Henry & I go over the “to-morrow” list.

Henry broods over the drinking Sphinx,

but all my love – & all the foxity of my life[?]

is[?] for “a weeping Terminal” In that – but

I speak not: speech is not for that wh. can

be wrought.

Could you, Painter, I wonder, be some

year happy in the forest for a day or

two? Could you be patient to learn

the tongue of the moss, & all the accents

of the trees? Henry knows not. I wonder.

I would far rather you were at the

Palace with your clay. Painter, you have

been called by one who is not your enemy,

“an abstract eel”, & this too is for me your

charm. Abstractness with attention

is far better than “joy with economy.”

I cannot turn to the Forest now that

you have set me on the track

of art, – & yet there is a cherry-tree

the poets wake to at dawn – kaleidoscopic

in its light through pointed leaves, –

where the birds & they remember the

cherry-harvest – & twitter in their old

age of song; and there is the strange

reddening & re-budding of the summer

oaks, & shakings, & droppings, & sounds.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 238; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 118v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_238.jpg

[K.B.]

Henry is happy writing scenes in “Diane: Queen

of Earth” – our title for the new play. Ah,

Painter, Goujon[?] was her Sculptor –

who now? Just Diane sitting by the

stream of the River of Time – watching

the rise & fall of it – no stag, & no

crescent-moon – the symbolism in

the figure!

You have behaved ill over

Diane, not “fizzing” when I fizz, as

Bernhard wd complain.

Farewell, with good fortune, as

the Greeks say.

Michael.

[E.C.]

All the heavens are wide this third

Forest Sunday – the cherry-tree

is tongued & eloquent & little

clouds are harboured in a bay

of air, like a happy gala-fleet.

The moss of the forest glows

surprisingly; it has fattened

with the rain – its whorls[?] &

fronds[?]251 are tender, almost sleek.

The dead beech-leaves as we

pass over them give us the

experience of spiced & mummied

rain – over them, & the

sky & the lawns the sun

is sprinkled in droplets of

a golden shower.

We have an early greenwood walk.

Then I begin the last scene in

“Dian, Queen of Earth”, while Michael

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 239; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 119r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_239.jpg

[E.C.]

writes to Fay & to Francis.

Then we walk in open noon, the

wind over the sun, like a banner

across a festival. And after

lunch, still we walk, so warm &

fresh are the hours. Our only

trouble is a fear of the fierce

dog next door – a poor animal

tied up to become a fiend.

After tea we start for Renaissance

– the beautiful terrace at the

back of Akers Down.

The sun is hidden, & all the ⟨beech⟩ woods

expend as dark clouds do – an

awful deepening passes through

them – They are stranger than

the Sun, as they sit in their grace

while he passes.

Michael plunges in sylvan madness

on – on & bears the ardour over

her cheeks still. She says this

day is the last of summer – it has

attained, & autumn might begin

tomorrow. She is very much much

with the sky when we turn home

[K.B.]

August 1st – at last – & Bank Holiday

I drew in from the garden the 1st morning

-glory. The red algi shoot up in the woods

a sweet walk at sundown through

the shining of the sweet gale past the dark

water of alderdrop – on lo[?] the beechen ⟨& hollied⟩

spaces of “Amiens’ song” [E.C.] – & an

evening with Michael’s Wilverley Poems

& As You Like It.

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 240; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 119v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_240.jpg

[E.C.]

August 2 nd Tuesday

We walk ⟨wake⟩ in awful depression –

the purlieus of dying. The Forest

seems to choke one in the night

while one sleeps. We comfort

ourselves with the thought Amy

will soon be back at the Manor

& a refuge will appear.

Then out into a lordly autumn

day – to the dear Inn & the

Highway from wh: one looks

into Hyacinthian, Discobolan

glade. What sweep of light &

branches, & dragon-fly.

The webs lie on the heath like

fleeces of Fay-land, the beeches

have a brown shade, that

makes them look firmer to

the eyes.

“La Charmoire[?]” of the Algi is

very rich – the vermeil

texture of their substance

is worthy food for the

fervent-tempered squirrels.

This afternoon we have driven

in the by-ways at the heart of

the Forest, as never before.

Not a high-road, except for a

while our delicious Boldrewood

Road. We tumbled over the

beech-roots of Kit’s Hill, looked

down on the beech & holly antiquity of

Buckhill, paused at the Roman

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 241; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 120r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_241.jpg

[E.C.]

Arch & descended. Such a picture –

that such should never be painted,

because it is a picture, & man

should never strive to do what

nature has achieved. The water

is green, a delight, in the hollow

under the bridge – the roots are

twisted perfectly, the shale-bank

is perfect round about the

runlets of the water.

And we hear from our Driver

that the Romans built it to

avoid the toll-gate on the

other road – so his grandfather

told him ⟨many times.⟩ They made a straight

way to Cufnels . . . “so at least

he told me” – adds the man, feeling

the atmosphere dubious.

It is exquisite! The woaded[?]

Britons making their road-

charges; & the imperial Road-

makers cutting straight

a’head to avoid paying.

I bore it – but the laughter within

grew an immortal joy.

Afterward we came to Holiday Hill,

driving along three miles of

Greenwood like that of Wilverley.

Oh, the little oaks, crisped as

with a tool, green & sunny – the

wide green turf-way, & everywhere

like an [????] lapse of waves,

the brake-fern, flaked with radiance!

I could have gone on for an

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 242; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 120v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_242.jpg

[E.C.]

Enchanted lifetime. Gods & Poetry

live in these green enclosures –

only societies of men & the

forms of drama haunt the

great unenclosed woods of

beech & holly – Jaques & the

Court of the Elder Duke

Dianne de Poytiers or William

Rufus.

That greenest green road, over

wh: our horse sprang on! –

That greenery in curl over

it, & that rise of a subtle

sea of fern round every

trunk!

Tea at Boldrewood Lodge, now

demure under Lascelles’ despotism.

Silence about us & tea discreetly

brought out into the carriage.

Before this Mark Ash with its

memories of 20 years ago, & of

2 years ago with the Professor.

What small divine sorrel

under the ancient Beech-ghosts!

And I saw the fine Thorn[?],

named after Michael, flourishing

in a dim manner.

To night we have been up our

James Hill in twilight. From

a ledge we look down on the whole

Boldrewood – the effect is of naked

Forest caught unawares – its

body seen – all those trees of⟨without⟩ any

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 243; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 121r; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_243.jpg

[E.C.]

knowledge of their revelation[?].

A night-bird weighed its own

wing down, & in the distance

the owls gave their cry, as

if it came from that flesh

& bone of forest, incarnate

below us.

Wednesday – Another lordly day –

“herrlich wie am ersten Tag”

We sit on the Boldrewood High-

Road & look down on our happy

glen through the levels of gold

beech-leaves.

In this harvest-heat we sit in our

parlour, with the fire-slashed hawthorn

of the shades, suggesting coolness

from the mantleshelf, & pale &

crimson mallows in the vases

– rich & cool as old church-

windows ⟨under⟩ the hottest sun.

At sundown we wander away

to “Amiens’ Song” – from thence

through the solitude at the heart

of an old wood of beeches & hollies.

Those beeches! Under them the

Duke of As You Like It feasted, on

them was Orlando’s sculpture.

There is no question of their growing –

only that they had⟨have⟩ grown. The

Past is their OverLord – ‘Antan’ –

all that was before now. Yet our

each sunset brightens their

[Page]

Notebook 18, Page Image 244; Vol. XVIII, Add MS 46793, fol. 121v; Pearl Chaozon Bauer (Holly Laird); Add_ms_46793_244.jpg

[E.C.]

small leaves to a delicacy

of display, like an old Man’s

smile at a Child going to

bed.

They are very lovely & almost

terrible in age & experience –

Think of the millions of

birds that have touched their

leaves with a breeze – the myriads

of insects that have afflicted

or sung to their Centuries!

Birds & insects of the 18th century –

of Elizabeth’s days – of the

time perhaps when chivalry

was abroad & knights pricked

at each other.

And the little Dædalus-

paths through the hollies –

we had to leave scraps

of paper wherever we

turned, as faggot-gatherers

advised us not to stray

so deep. At last we sighted

the High-Road, & turned back

at the sound of military

music from the Army of

Volunteers, now at camp

about the forest. Strange the

sound of the drum accompanied

by the call of peace from the

Dove at the Core of our Labyrinth.

We were happy – freely happy to

ourselves – Michael & Field.

Notes
1.

A line appears directly above as well as below “Feast of S. Michael”.

2.

One of Bradley’s many nicknames for Cooper.

3.

Little Amy is Edith Cooper’s sister.

4.

Diana de Poictiers was a French noblewoman and a prominent courtier at the courts of King Francis I and his son, King Henry II of France.

5.

Whym Chow was a dog Bradley and Cooper had acquired. His death led to their conversion to Roman Catholicism.

6.

Francis Thompson was an English poet and ascetic.

7.

Ernest Radford was an English poet, critic and socialist.

8.

Thomas Sturge Moore was an English poet, author and artist.

9.

A king of Judea appointed by the Roman Empire who ruled during the time of Jesus Christ’s birth. He appears in the Biblical birth narrative of Jesus as the person who wanted to have the baby Jesus killed.

10.

A princess and the second wife of Herod. Known for her great beauty. Herod later had her killed out of jealousy even though he loved her deeply.

11.

Prince of Judea; son of Herod and Mariamne.

12.

Charles Ricketts and Charles Shannon move away from Richmond to 'the Palace' in Lansdowne House, Holland Park.

13.

One of the women’s nicknames for Charles Shannon.

14.

Refers to a friend who was a poet turned Catholic priest. There was a lengthy exchange of letters between these friends. Michael Field also had a friendship with a John Gray who was the curator of the Scottish National Portrait Gallery.

15.

English painter and lifelong partner of Charles Ricketts.

16.

A single rounded parenthesis is drawn to the left of the following 5 lines.

17.

Heinrich Graetz (1817-1891) was a German Jewish Historian. He was amongst the first historian to write a comprehensive history of the Jewish people from a Jewish perspective.

18.

Herod refers to a trilogy of plays Katherine and Edith were writing simultaneously around this time.

19.

Fay is a nickname for Charles Ricketts.

20.

The hyphen between “can” and “be” may be a stray ink mark.

21.

Queen Mary I of England, 1516-1558. Because of the many executions of Protestants during her reign, she was nicknamed Bloody Mary.

22.

Is “See 17” E.C.’s handwriting?

23.

Herod’s Arabian mother.

24.

A character in the Herod play.

25.

The love interest of Herod in the Herod plays.

26.

Aristobulus is the beautiful young son of Mariamne in the Herod plays.

27.

Lady Ann Blunt is the granddaughter of Lord Byron and a Baroness; she traveled extensively in the Arabian Peninsula. She and her husband raised Arabian horses. He was a poet. She wrote two books: Bedouin Tribes of the Euphrates and A Pilgrimage to Nejd.

28.

“we feel the white teeth of chamomile” is a quote from Thousand and One Arabian Nights.

29.

Josephus: Flavius Josephus was a writer who lived at the time of Herod, Governor of Galilee. Initially he was against Roman rule, but he eventually became a Roman citizen. He wrote about the Jewish war (75-79AD) and the dynasty of Herod.

30.

Aristophanes: A celebrated comic poet from Ancient Athens.

31.

Auguste René Rodin 1840 –1917 was a well-known and highly respected French sculptor. He became President of the International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers, of London after James Abbott McNeill Whistler died.

32.

Charles Haslewood Shannon (1863 -1937) was an English artist and life partner of Charles Ricketts. Both were close friends of Edith and Katharine.

33.

Charles Cottet, a painter who exhibited at the International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers, of London.

34.

Ignacio Zuloaga y Zabaleta (1870 -1945) was a Basque (Spanish province) painter who lived in London for a brief period before returning to Spain to General Franco’s nationalistic party during the Spanish Revolution. He painted Franco’s portrait in 1940.

35.

The Century Magazine: was an illustrated monthly magazine, published in London.

36.

Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, Massachusetts, was completed in 1903.

37.

Bernard Berenson, 1865-1959, was a hugely successful American art historian specializing in the Renaissance. Edith, Katherine and Bernard enjoyed an “aesthetically sexual” relationship through poetry and letters.

38.

Raffaello Sanzio da Urbino (1483-1520), known as Raphael, was a famous Italian painter and architect of the Renaissance.

39.

Romano: A Pupil of Raphael.

40.

Morelli: This might be a reference to Domenico Morelli, 1823–1901 an Italian painter, who was immensely influential in the arts of the second half of the 19th century, both as director of the Accademia di Belle Arti in Naples and due to his rebelliousness against institutions.

41.

Carfax: Carfax Gallery: The Carfax Gallery was founded in 1899 by William Rothenstein and John Fothergill.

42.

Bobbie Ross: Robert Ross was a dear friend and dealer at the Carfax (25 May 1869 – 5 October 1918)

“The Bard from Grey” by William Blake. This date of 1809, according to the Tate, is incorrect because it was shown at the Carfax in 1904.

46.

Sphinx, Poem by Oscar Wilde:

False Sphinx! False Sphinx! By reedy Styx

old Charon, leaning on his oar,

Waits for my coin. Go thou before, and leave

me to my crucifix . . .

47.

The River of Life: Watercolor by William Blake, c.1805, Ink and watercolour on paper, Image: 305 x 336 mm support: 442 x 432 mm. This work illustrates lines from the Book of Revelation. The River of Life flows from the throne of God to the Tree of Life. PROVENANCE (history of ownership): Thomas Butts; Thomas Butts, jun.; Capt. F.J. Butts; his widow, sold April 1906 through Carfax to W. Graham Robertson. EXHIBITED BFAC: Carfax 1904.

48.

Capt. F.J. Butts was the owner of the watercolor at the time of the viewing by Michael Field.

49.

Broadmore: The hospital was first known as the Broadmoor Criminal Lunatic Asylum. It was built to a design by Sir Joshua Jebb, an officer of the Corps of Royal Engineers, and covered 53 acres (210,000 square metres) within its secure perimeter. The first patient was a female admitted for infanticide on 27 May 1863.

50.

Symphony in White: “Symphony in White, No. 111”: The 4th Exhibition of International Art/The International Society of Sculptors, Painters and Gravers was held at New Gallery, January 1904; “Symphony in White, No. lll” lent by Edmund Davis.

57.

Desiderius Erasmus of Rotterdam (1467?–1536) was the most famous and influential humanist of the Northern Renaissance, a man of great talent and industriousness who rose from obscure beginnings to become the leading intellectual figure of the early sixteenth century, courted by rulers and prelates who wanted to enhance their own reputations by association with the greatest scholar of the age.

58.

Pater: Walter Pater, in full Walter Horatio Pater (born August 4, 1839, Shadwell, London, England—died July 30, 1894, Oxford, Oxfordshire) English critic, essayist, and humanist whose advocacy of “art for art’s sake” became a cardinal doctrine of the movement known as Aestheticism.

59.

Mary Berenson, Art Historian, Art Critic, Writer and Lecturer, a scholar of Italian Renaissance art, was the collaborator and wife of Bernard Berenson.

60.

Eleonora Duse, born Oct. 3, 1858, was an Italian actress.

62.

Roger Eliot Fry (14 December 1866 – 9 September 1934) was an English painter and critic, and a member of the Bloomsbury Group. Mary and Bernard, along with Robert Dell, Herbert Cook, Roger Fry and Herbert Horne, had a crucial role in the creation of the Burlington, the first issue of which was published in 1903.

161.

Pinturicchio: Bernardino di Betto, called Pintoricchio or Pinturicchio (1454-1513), was an Italian painter of the Renaissance. He acquired his nickname, Pintoricchio ("little painter"), because of his small stature, and he used it to sign some of his works.

162.

Eleonora Duse: An Italian actress (1858-1924), often known simply as Duse.

Tristan & Isolde: An opera, or music drama, in three acts by Richard Wagner.

Casa Buonarroti is a museum in Florence. The building was a property owned by (but never occupied by) the sculptor Michelangelo, which he left to his nephew, Lionardo Buonarroti.

Chestnut Sunday is the biggest day in Bushy Park’s calendar. Each year, on the Sunday closest to 11th May, people come from all over London and the South East to join the local tradition of celebrating the blossoms on the magnificent horse chestnut trees in the park.

A yellow-flowered shrub of the pea family, the leaves of which are modified to form spines, native to western Europe and North Africa.

238.

Marcus Antonius, commonly known in English as Mark or Marc Antony, was a Roman politician and general who played a critical role in the transformation of the Roman Republic from an oligarchy into the autocratic Roman Empire.

239.

Andrea Mantegna was an Italian painter, a student of Roman archeology, and son-in-law of Jacopo Bellini. Like other artists of the time, Mantegna experimented with perspective, e.g., by lowering the horizon in order to create a sense of greater monumentality. His flinty, metallic landscapes and somewhat stony figures give evidence of a fundamentally sculptural approach to painting.

Whym Chow.

Baltic Amber is an organic substance, a “fossil resin” produced by pine trees which grew in Northern Europe.

242.

Hyacinthoides non-scripta is a bulbous perennial plant, found in Atlantic areas from north-western Spain to the British Isles, and also frequently used as a garden plant.
